THIS ISSUE INCLUDES A RESERVATION OF UP TO \n2,80,000 EQUITY SHARES AGGREGATING TO ₹ [●] LAKHS (CONSTITUTING UP TO [●] % OF THE POST-ISSUE PAID UP EQUITY SHARE CAPITAL OF OUR COMPANY) FOR SUBSCRIPTION BY THE MARKET MAKER \n(“MARKET MAKER RESERVATION PORTION”). THE ISSUE LESS MARKET MAKER RESERVATION PORTION IS HEREINAFTER REFERRED TO AS THE “NET ISSUE”. THE ISSUE AND THE NET ISSUE WILL CONSTITUTE \n[●] % AND [●] % RESPECTIVELY OF THE FULLY DILUTED POST ISSUE PAID UP EQUITY SHARE CAPITAL OF OUR COMPANY. OUR COMPANY, IN CONSULTATION WITH THE BRLM, HAS UNDERTAKEN A PRE-IPO \nPLACEMENT AGGREGATING OF 2,86,000 EQUITY SHARES OF FACE VALUE OF ₹ 10/- EACH FOR AN AGGREGATE AMOUNT OF ₹ 200.20 LAKHS. THE ISSUE SIZE AS DISCLOSED IN THE DRAFT RED HERRING \nPROSPECTUS, AGGREGATING UP TO 57,84,000 EQUITY SHARES, HAS BEEN REDUCED BY 2,86,000 EQUITY SHARES PURSUANT TO THE PRE-IPO PLACEMENT SUBJECT TO THE ISSUE COMPLYING WITH RULE \n19(2)(B) OF THE SCRR, AND ACCORDINGLY, THE ISSUE SIZE IS OF UP TO 54,98,000 EQUITY SHARES OF FACE VALUE OF ₹ 10/- EACH. THE PROCEEDS OF THE PRE-IPO PLACEMENT SHALL BE UTILIZED TOWARDS \nGENERAL CORPORATE PURPOSES. OUR COMPANY HAS APPROPRIATELY INTIMATED TO THE SUBSCRIBERS OF PRE-IPO PLACEMENT, THAT THERE IS NO GUARANTEE THAT OUR COMPANY MAY PROCEED \nWITH THE ISSUE OR THE ISSUE MAY BE SUCCESSFUL AND WILL RESULT INTO LISTING OF THE EQUITY SHARES ON THE STOCK EXCHANGE. \n \nTHE FACE VALUE OF THE EQUITY SHARES IS ₹ 10/- EACH. THE PRICE BAND AND THE MINIMUM BID LOT WILL BE DECIDED BY OUR COMPANY IN CONSULTATION WITH THE BOOK RUNNING LEAD MANAGER \n(“BRLM”) AND WILL BE ADVERTISED IN ALL EDITIONS OF FINANCIAL EXPRESS, THE ENGLISH NATIONAL NEWSPAPER, ALL EDITIONS OF JANSATTA, THE HINDI NATIONAL NEWSPAPER AND ALL EDITIONS OF NAFA \nNUKSAAN, THE REGIONAL NEWSPAPER, (HINDI BEING THE LOCAL LANGUAGE OF JAIPUR, RAJASTHAN, WHERE OUR REGISTERED AND CORPORATE OFFICE IS SITUATED), EACH WITH WIDE CIRCULATION, AT LEAST \n2 (TWO) WORKING DAYS PRIOR TO THE BID/ ISSUE OPENING DATE AND SHALL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO NATIONAL STOCK EXCHANGE OF INDIA LIMITED (“NSE” REFERRED TO AS THE “STOCK EXCHANGE”) FOR THE \nPURPOSE OF UPLOADING ON ITS WEBSITE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SECURITIES AND EXCHNAGE BOARD OF INDIA (ISSUE OF CAPITAL AND DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS) REGULATIONS, 2018, AS AMENDED (THE \n“SEBI ICDR REGULATIONS”). \n \nIN CASE OF ANY REVISION IN THE PRICE BAND, THE BID / ISSUE PERIOD WILL BE EXTENDED BY AT LEAST THREE ADDITIONAL WORKING DAYS AFTER SUCH A REVISION IN THE PRICE BAND, SUBJECT TO THE BID / \nISSUE PERIOD NOT EXCEEDING 10 WORKING DAYS. IN CASES OF FORCE MAJEURE, BANKING STRIKE OR SIMILAR CIRCUMSTANCES, OUR COMPANY IN CONSULTATION WITH THE BRLM, FOR REASONS TO BE \nRECORDED IN WRITING, EXTEND THE BID / ISSUE PERIOD FOR A MINIMUM OF THREE WORKING DAYS, SUBJECT TO THE BID / ISSUE PERIOD NOT EXCEEDING 10 WORKING DAYS. Page 23 of 402 SECTION - II SUMMARY OF ISSUE DOCUMENT \n \nThe following is a general summary of the terms of the issue. This summary should be read in \nconjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information appearing elsewhere \nin this Red Herring Prospectus, including the sections entitled “Risk Factors”, “Our Industry”, \n“Outstanding Litigation and Material Developments”, “Our Promoters and Promoter Group”, \n“Financial Statements as Restated” “Objects of the Issue”, “Our Business”, “Issue Procedure” and \n“Main Provisions of Articles of Association” beginning on pages 32, 133, 295, 212, 220, 101, 154, 333 \nand 362 respectively. \n \nOVERVIEW OF BUSINESS \n \nOur company is engaged in the manufacturing and processing of 164 type/varieties of spices such as \nGround Spices, Blend Spices and Whole Spices under the brand name “SHYAM”. In addition to our spice \nofferings, we are also engaged in trading and distribution of Grocery Products such as Black Salt, Rock \nSalt, Rice, Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dried Fenugreek) etc. and a diverse range of Herbs and seasonings which \nincludes Organo, Peri Peri, Chilli Flakes, Mixed Herbs, Onion Flakes, Tomato Powder etc. \n \nFor details, please refer “Our Business - Overview” beginning on page 154. \n \nOVERVIEW OF INDUSTRY IN WHICH OUR COMPANY OPERATES \n \nTotal revenue of FMCG market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 27.9% through 2021-27, reaching \nnearly US$ 615.87 billion. In 2022, urban segment contributed 65% whereas rural India contributed \nmore than 35% to the overall annual FMCG sales. Good harvest, government spending expected to aid \nrural demand recovery in FY24. The sector had grown 8.5% in revenues and 2.5% in volumes last fiscal \nyear. In the January-June period of 2022, the sector witnessed value growth of about 8.4% on account \nof price hikes due to inflationary pressures. In third quarter of FY23, the FMCG sector clocked a value \ngrowth of 9.0% YoY — lower than the 9.2% YoY value growth seen in third quarter of FY22. \n \n(Source: https://www.ibef.org/exports/spice-industry-india) \n \nFor details, please refer “Our Industry” beginning on page 133. \n \nNAME OF PROMOTERS \n \nThe Promoters of our Company are Mr. Ramawtar Agarwal, Mrs. Mamta Devi Agarwal and Mr. Vithal \nAgarwal. Any such disruption may impact \nour ability to fulfil customer orders and could result in customer loss, thereby materially affecting \nour business, financial condition, and results of operations. \n \nFurther, the availability and pricing of our products may be subject to volatility due to factors beyond \nour control, including fluctuations in global demand and supply, economic and political conditions, \ntransportation or labour unrest, natural disasters, competition, import duties, tariffs, and currency \nexchange rates. Given the inherent uncertainties in estimating the impact of these factors, we cannot \nassure that we will be able to procure adequate supplies in the future on commercially acceptable \nterms. Moreover, our ability to effectively manage relationships with existing or new suppliers, or to \nenter into arrangements with new suppliers on favourable terms, cannot be assured. Any such \ninability may adversely affect our business and financial performance. \n \n2. \nWe may face shortage of Raw Materials because of the seasonal nature of our purchase. Our business is heavily reliant on raw materials sourced from the agricultural industry, which is \nsubject to various external factors, particularly weather and monsoon conditions. The geographical \ndiversity within our country results in differing weather patterns across regions, with some areas \nexperiencing heavy rainfall while others may suffer from drought or inadequate rainfall. Such \nfluctuations in weather, including abnormal monsoons or extreme weather events, can negatively \naffect crop yields, damage crops, and lead to an increase in raw material prices. In these \ncircumstances, we may be forced to purchase lower-quality raw materials to meet production needs, \npotentially increasing production costs as we source from alternative suppliers or regions where \nprices are higher. These disruptions could materially affect our results of operations, financial \ncondition, and cash flows. Page 34 of 402 We primarily procure our raw materials during the harvest season, typically from January to April. \nThese materials are stored in leased cold storage facilities for use throughout the year, including \nduring off-seasons. This fluctuation in raw material \navailability, coupled with potential price changes, may cause considerable variations in our financial \nperformance across fiscal quarters. \n \nThe imbalance between higher raw material costs and potential downward pressure on product \nprices could place significant strain on our profitability. Furthermore, the inherent seasonality in raw \nmaterial availability exposes us to supply chain vulnerabilities, as we depend on uncontrollable \nfactors like weather conditions and crop performance. Any adverse conditions impacting crop yields \nor raw material quality during our procurement season could have long-lasting effects on our \nfinancial performance, operational efficiency, and competitive position in the market. \n \n3. \nOur products are semi-perishable in nature and the shelf life of our products ranges from 4-18 \nmonths. Inaccurate demand forecasting for our semi-perishable product can result in excess \ninventory and waste which, in turn, could have an adverse effect on our business, financial \ncondition, results of operations and cash flows. Our products are semi-perishable in nature, with self-life ranging from 4 to 18 months. We \nmanufacture a wide variety of spices, including ground spices, whole spices, spice blends, and grocery \nproducts, each with different shelf lives. Specifically, ground and whole spices have shelf lives ranging \nfrom 4 to 12 months, blended spices range from 4 to 18 months, and grocery products range from 6 \nto 12 months. \n \nDue to the semi-perishable nature of our products, there is a risk that inaccurate demand forecasting \nor ineffective inventory management could result in excess inventory. This excess inventory could \nlead to wastage, which may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operations, \ncash flows, and reputation. \n \nWhile we have not encountered any material adverse effects from such risks in the past three fiscal \nyears and stub period as certified by the statutory and peer review auditor of our Company M/s G. \nL. Dangayach and Company vide their certificate dated December 02, 2025, there can be no Page 35 of 402 assurance that these risks will not affect our business in the future. As a result, any inaccuracies in \ndemand forecasting or inventory management could have a significant negative impact on our \noperations and financial performance. \n \n4. \nOur Company requires significant amounts of working capital for continued growth. Our inability \nto meet our working capital requirements may have an adverse effect on the results of operations. \nFurther, failure to manage our inventory could have an adverse effect on our sales, profitability, \ncash flow and liquidity. \n \nOur business is working capital intensive and requires a significant amount of working capital for \nsmooth functioning. We operate in markets with intense competition where some of our competitors may have greater scale and resources, enabling them to compete more effectively. This could result in a loss of market \nshare as well as decline in our revenues and profitability. The industry is fragmented, with both organized and unorganized players competing for market \nshare. Key organized competitors include Adani Food Products Private Limited, Ramdev Food Private \nLimited, MDH Masala Private Limited, Baadshah Masala Private Limited, and Everest Food Products \nPrivate Limited. We also compete with publicly listed companies such as NHC Food Limited and \nMadhusudan Masala Limited, along with local unorganized suppliers. The growth of the industry has \nled to the entry of new players with innovative business models, intensifying competition. \n \nIn this competitive landscape, players may lower prices to capture market share, which presents a \nchallenge for established businesses like ours. We face significant competition from other retailers \noffering similar products, with competition centered on factors such as brand recognition, product \nquality, pricing and supply chain efficiency. Increased competition could lead to pricing pressure, Page 42 of 402 reduced profitability, and make It harder to achieve sustainable revenue growth, potentially causing \nus to lose market share. Additionally, competitors may employ aggressive marketing or public \nrelations strategies that could damage our reputation and increase our own marketing costs. Some of our current and potential competitors have substantial advantages, such as longer operating \nhistories, the ability to allocate marketing and sales resources across a broader product portfolio, \nmore established supplier relationships, access to a larger customer base, stronger brand \nrecognition, and greater financial, marketing, and distribution resources. These competitors also \noften possess larger intellectual property portfolios. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to \ncompete successfully against them. \n \n14. The markets in which we operate are influenced by consumers whose tastes and preferences change rapidly, meaning our company may be affected by any disruptions in the industry. \n \nWe manufacture and market spices and grocery products primarily for commercial and household \nuse. Consequently, the markets we operate in are shaped by shifting consumer preferences, evolving \nindustry standards, and ongoing improvements in product quality and variety, often resulting in short \nproduct life cycles. Additionally, we are affected by the spending habits of consumers in India. A \ndecline in demand for our products could lead to significant fluctuations in customer orders and \nincreased pricing pressures.  \n \nIf the technologies or standards we rely on become obsolete or fail to gain widespread commercial \nacceptance, demand for our products may decrease, leading to lower sales and operating margins. \nOver time, these factors could negatively impact our business, financial condition, and results of \noperations. \n \n15. Our operating results could be significantly impacted if we are unable to accurately forecast consumer demand for our products or effectively manage our inventory. \n \nWe aim to maintain optimal inventory levels with wholesalers, distributors, and dealers to control \ncosts and manage working capital efficiently. To achieve this, we monitor inventory levels both based \non demand projections and in real-time. Although our manufacturing facility allows us to fulfill large \norders from distributors quickly, any unavailability of products due to high demand or inaccurate \nforecasting could result in lost sales and harm our customer relationships. Page 44 of 402 We manage our inventory by closely tracking current stock levels and keeping a reserve based on \ndemand forecasts. However, if we fail to forecast demand accurately, we may face excess inventory \nor product shortages. Excess inventory could lead to write-offs, discounted sales, and a decrease in \ngross margins, which may also weaken our brand strength. Conversely, a shortage of products could \nprevent us from meeting customer demand, which could negatively impact our business operations \nand financial performance. \n \nInaccurate demand forecasts can also result in an over-supply of products, driving up inventory costs, \nnegatively affecting cash flow, reducing inventory quality, causing shrinkage, and ultimately \ndiminishing margins. Furthermore, some of our raw materials may become outdated and lose their \nnatural properties over time. Any of these factors could affect our business, operations, and financial \ncondition. \n \nFor the period ended on September 30, 2025 and for the Fiscal Years ended on March 31, 2025, 2024 \nand 2023 our inventories valued at ₹ 4515.09 lakhs, ₹ 4,071.69 lakhs, ₹ 2,981.80 lakhs and ₹ 1,121.91 \nLakhs respectively. Additionally, if we fail to efficiently convert purchased inventory into finished \nproducts, we may have to write down the value of our inventory or pay our suppliers without \ngenerating new purchases. This could lead to the need for additional vendor financing and an adverse \nimpact on our income and cash flow. \n \n18. These risks could affect our ability to \nmeet customer demand in a timely manner, maintain the quality of our products, and manage our \noverall operational efficiency that could have a negative impact on our business, financial condition, \nand results of operations. \n \n23. Improper handling, processing, or storage of our raw materials or products, along with any spoilage, damage, or actual or perceived contamination, could lead to regulatory actions, harming \nour reputation, and negative impact on our business, operations, and financial health. Additionally, some of our raw materials \nand products need to be stored, handled, and transported under specific temperatures and food \nsafety conditions. Any lapses in production or storage, due to negligence, human error, or other \nfactors, could damage our products and lead to non-compliance with regulatory standards.  \n \nWe at present meet arrangements with the five cold storage houses nearby to our manufacturing \nunit and packing unit for store our raw material and finished goods but our raw material and finished \ngoods are also at our manufacturing unit or our packaging unit during manufacturing, processing, \npackaging and before dispatching. While there have been no such \ninstances in the past, any significant malfunction or breakdown of our machinery, our equipment, \nour IT systems or any other part of our systems associated with manufacturing activities (together, \nour “Manufacturing Assets”) may entail significant repair and maintenance costs and cause delays \nin our operations. If we are unable to repair Manufacturing Assets in a timely manner or at all, our \noperations may need to be suspended until we procure the appropriate Manufacturing Assets to \nreplace the same and we cannot assure you that the new Manufacturing Assets will be procured \nand/or integrated in a timely manner. In addition, we may be required to carry out planned \nshutdowns of our facilities for maintenance, statutory inspections, testing and equipment upgrades. \n \nAs our customers rely significantly on the timely delivery of our products, uninterrupted power \nsupply, supply of trained and skilled manpower, availability of raw materials and our ability to carry \non interruption-free production of our products is critical to our business. Further, our electricity \nrequirements for our manufacturing units are directly sourced from local utilities. We cannot assure \nyou that we will successfully be able to prevent disruptions in our manufacturing processes in case \nof non-availability of an adequate supply of power. While we have backup systems, such as DG Sets, \nand keep spare parts on hand, we cannot guarantee that replacements will be available or of \nequivalent quality, which could lead to extended downtime. This may impact on our manufacturing \ncapacity and delay fulfilling customer orders. \n \nFurther, we may be subject to manufacturing disruptions due to contraventions by us of any of the \nconditions of our regulatory approvals, which may require our manufacturing facilities to cease, or \nlimit, production until the disputes concerning such approvals are resolved. Subsequent to the listing of the Equity Shares, we may be subject to surveillance measures, such as the Additional Surveillance Measures and the Graded Surveillance Measures by the Stock \nExchanges in order to enhance the integrity of the market and safeguard the interest of investors. Subsequent to the listing of the Equity Shares, we may be subject to Additional Surveillance \nMeasures (“ASM”) and Graded Surveillance Measures (“GSM”) by the Stock Exchange. These \nmeasures are in place to enhance the integrity of the market and safeguard the interest of investors. \nThe criteria for shortlisting any security trading on the Stock Exchanges for ASM is based on objective \ncriteria, which includes market-based parameters such as high low price variation, concentration of \nclient accounts, close to close price variation, market capitalization, average daily trading volume \nand its change, and average delivery percentage, among others. Securities are subject to GSM when \nits price is not commensurate with the financial health and fundamentals of the issuer. Specific \nparameters for GSM include net worth, net fixed assets, price to earning ratio, market capitalization \nand price to book value, among others.  \n \nFactors within and beyond our control may lead to our securities being subject to GSM or ASM. In \nthe event our Equity Shares are subject to such surveillance measures implemented by the Stock \nExchange, we may be subject to certain additional restrictions in connection with trading of our \nEquity Shares such as limiting trading frequency (for example, trading either allowed once in a week \nor a month) or freezing of price on upper side of trading which may have an adverse effect on the \nmarket price of our Equity Shares or may in general cause disruptions in the development of an active \ntrading market for our Equity Shares. \n \n57. This circuit breaker operates independently of the index-based market-wide circuit breakers \ngenerally imposed by SEBI on Indian stock exchanges. The percentage limit on circuit breakers is set \nby the stock exchanges based on the historical volatility in the price and trading volume of the Equity \nShares. The stock exchanges do not inform us of the percentage limit of the circuit breaker in effect \nfrom time to time and may change it without our knowledge. This circuit breaker limits the upward \nand downward movements in the price of the Equity Shares. As a result of this circuit breaker, no \nassurance may be given regarding your ability to sell your Equity Shares or the price at which you \nmay be able to sell your Equity Shares at any particular time. \n \n59. A slowdown in economic growth in India could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. \n \nOur performance and growth are, and will be, dependent to a large extent on the health of the Indian \neconomy and consumption spending by households. Economic growth in India is affected by various \nfactors including domestic consumption and savings, rate of inflation in India, balance of trade \nmovements, and global economic uncertainty. Most of our assets and employees are located in India, \nand we intend to continue to develop and expand in India. \n \nInflation, measures to combat inflation and public speculation about possible governmental actions \nto combat inflation have also contributed significantly to economic uncertainty in India and \nheightened volatility in the Indian capital markets. Periods of higher inflation may also slow the \ngrowth rate of the Indian economy and increase some of our costs and expenses. To the extent that \nthe demand for our products decreases or costs and expenses increase, and we are not able to pass \nthose increases in costs and expenses on to our customers, our operating margins and operating \nincome may be adversely affected, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, \nfinancial condition and results of operations. \n \nOther Risks \n \n67. Changing laws, rules and regulations and legal uncertainties, including adverse application of tax laws, may adversely affect our business and financial performance. \n \nThe regulatory and policy environment in India is evolving and subject to change. Such changes in \napplicable law and policy in India, including the instances described below, may adversely affect our \nbusiness, financial condition, results of operation, performance and prospects in India, to the extent \nthat we are not able to suitably respond to and comply with such changes. \n \nFor instance, in November 2016, the Government of India demonetized certain – high value \ndenominations of currency. Trading and retail businesses in India were impacted for a limited period \nof time on account of such demonetization. Such businesses have subsequently needed to introduce \nadditional point of sale instruments to improve their collection process. \n \nThe Government of India implemented a comprehensive national goods and service tax (“GST”) \nregime that combines taxes and levies by the central and state governments into a unified rate \nstructure from July 01, 2017, which we believe will result in fundamental changes. However, given \nits recent introduction, there is no established practice regarding the implementation of, and \ncompliance with, GST. The implementation of the new GST regime has increased the operational and \ncompliance burden for Indian companies and has also led to various uncertainties. Any future \nincreases and amendments to the GST regime may further affect the overall tax efficiency of \ncompanies operating in India and may result in significant additional taxes becoming payable. Our \nbusiness and financial performance could be adversely affected by any unexpected or onerous \nrequirements or regulations resulting from the introduction of GST or any changes in laws or \ninterpretation of existing laws, or the promulgation of new laws, rules and regulations relating to \nGST, as it is implemented. Further, as GST is implemented, there can be no assurance that we will \nnot be required to comply with additional procedures and/or obtain additional approvals and \nlicenses from the government and other regulatory bodies or that they will not impose onerous \nrequirements and conditions on our operations. Any such changes and the related uncertainties with Page 65 of 402 respect to the implementation of GST may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial \ncondition and results of operations. \n \nFurther, the General Anti Avoidance Rules came into effect on April 1, 2017. The effect of the \napplication of these provisions to our business in India is at present uncertain. Furthermore, the \nFinance Act, 2019 instituted a number of amendments to the existing direct and indirect tax regime \nwhich includes the withdrawal of long-term capital gains exemptions on equity shares, long term \ncapital gains applicability in the hands of Foreign Institutional Investors and applicability of dividend \ndistribution tax for certain transactions with shareholders, among others. \n \n68. Further, there is no assurance that they are stated \nor compiled on the same basis or with the same degree of accuracy, as the case may be, elsewhere. \n \n70. Financial instability in Indian financial markets could adversely affect our Company’s results of operations and financial condition.  \n \nIn this globalized world, the Indian economy and financial markets are significantly influenced by \nworldwide economic, financial and market conditions. Any financial turmoil, say in the United States \nof America, Europe, China or other emerging economies, may have a negative impact on the Indian \neconomy. Although economic conditions differ in each country, investors’ reactions to any significant \ndevelopments in one country can have adverse effects on the financial and market conditions in \nother countries. A loss in investor confidence in the financial systems, particularly in other emerging \nmarkets, may cause increased volatility in Indian financial markets. Indian financial markets have also \nexperienced the contagion effect of the global financial turmoil. Any prolonged financial crisis may \nhave an adverse impact on the Indian economy, thereby resulting in a material and adverse effect on \nour Company's business, operations, financial condition, profitability and price of its Shares. Stock \nexchanges in India have in the past experienced substantial fluctuations in the prices of listed \nsecurities. Page 66 of 402 71. Conditions in the Indian securities market may affect the price or liquidity of our Equity Shares. The Indian securities markets are smaller than securities markets in more developed economies and \nthe regulation and monitoring of Indian securities markets and the activities of investors, brokers and \nother participants differ, in some cases significantly, from those in the more developed economies. \nIndian stock exchanges have in the past experienced substantial fluctuations in the prices of listed \nsecurities. Further, the Indian stock exchanges have experienced volatility in the recent times. The \nIndian stock exchanges have also experienced problems that have affected the market price and \nliquidity of the securities of Indian companies, such as temporary exchange closures, broker defaults, \nsettlement delays and strikes by brokers. In addition, the governing bodies of the Indian stock \nexchanges have from time-to-time restricted securities from trading and limited price movements. A \nclosure of, or trading stoppage on the EMERGE Platform of National Stock Exchange of India Limited \ncould adversely affect the trading price of the Equity Shares. \n \n72. Global economic, political and social conditions may harm our ability to do business, increase our costs and negatively affect our stock price.  \n \nGlobal economic and political factors that are beyond our control, influence forecasts and directly \naffect performance. These factors include interest rates, rates of economic growth, fiscal and \nmonetary policies of governments, inflation, deflation, foreign exchange fluctuations, consumer \ncredit availability, fluctuations in commodities markets, consumer debt levels, unemployment trends \nand other matters that influence consumer confidence, spending and tourism. Increasing volatility in \nfinancial markets may cause these factors to change with a greater degree of frequency and \nmagnitude, which may negatively affect our stock prices.  \n \n73. Foreign investors are subject to foreign investment restrictions under Indian law that limits our ability to attract foreign investors, which may adversely impact the market price of the Equity \nShares. \n \nUnder the foreign exchange regulations currently in force in India, transfers of shares between non-\nresidents and residents are freely permitted (subject to certain exceptions) if they comply with the \npricing guidelines and reporting requirements specified by the RBI. If the transfer of shares, which \nare sought to be transferred, is not in compliance with such pricing guidelines or reporting \nrequirements or fall under any of the exceptions referred to above, then the prior approval of the \nRBI will be required. Additionally, shareholders who seek to convert the Rupee proceeds from a sale \nof shares in India into foreign currency and repatriate that foreign currency from India will require a \nno objection/ tax clearance certificate from the income tax authority. There can be no assurance that \nany approval required from the RBI or any other government agency can be obtained on any \nparticular terms or at all. \n \n74. The extent and reliability of Indian infrastructure could adversely affect our Company’s results of operations and financial condition. \nIndia’s physical infrastructure is in developing phase compared to that of many developed nations. \nAny congestion or disruption in its port, rail and road networks, electricity grid, communication \nsystems or any other public facility could disrupt our Company’s normal business activity. Any \ndeterioration of India’s physical infrastructure would harm the national economy; disrupt the \ntransportation of goods and supplies, and costs to doing business in India. These problems could \ninterrupt our Company’s business operations, which could have an adverse effect on its results of \noperations and financial condition. \n \n75. Any downgrading of India’s sovereign rating by an independent agency may harm our ability to raise financing. \n \nAny adverse revisions to India’s credit ratings for domestic and international debt by international \nrating agencies may adversely impact our ability to raise additional financing, and the interest rates Page 67 of 402 and other commercial terms at which such additional financing may be available. This could have an \nadverse effect on our business and future financial performance, our ability to obtain financing for \ncapital expenditures and the trading price of our Equity Shares. \n \n76. The occurrence of natural or man-made disasters could adversely affect our results of operations, cash flows and financial condition. Hostilities, terrorist attacks, civil unrest and other acts of \nviolence could adversely affect the financial markets and our business.  \n \nThe occurrence of natural disasters, including cyclones, storms, floods, earthquakes, tsunamis, \ntornadoes, fires, explosions, pandemic disease and man-made disasters, including acts of terrorism \nand military actions, could adversely affect our results of operations, cash flows or financial condition. \nTerrorist attacks and other acts of violence or war may adversely affect the Indian securities markets. \nIn addition, any deterioration in international relations, especially between India and its neighboring \ncountries, may result in investor concern regarding regional stability which could adversely affect the \nprice of the Equity Shares. In addition, India has witnessed local civil disturbances in recent years, \nand it is possible that future civil unrest as well as other adverse social, economic or political events \nin India could have an adverse effect on our business. Such incidents could also create a greater \nperception that investment in Indian companies involves a higher degree of risk and could have an \nadverse effect on our business and the market price of the Equity Shares. pertaining to the Market Making arrangement: Shares to be Underwritten 1. The Market Maker(s) (individually or jointly) shall be required to provide a 2 – way quote for 75% of the time in a day. The same shall be monitored by the Stock Exchange. The Spread (difference \nbetween the sell and buy quote) shall not be more than 10% or as specified by the Stock Exchange. Page 81 of 402 Further, the Market Maker(s) shall inform the Exchange in advance for each and every black out \nperiod when the quotes are not being offered by the Market Maker(s). \n \n2. The Prices quoted by Market Maker shall be in compliance with the Market Maker Spread Requirements and other particulars as specified or as per the requirements of EMERGE Platform of \nNSE and SEBI from time to time. \n \n3. The minimum depth of the quote shall be ₹ 1,00,000/-. However, the investors with holdings of value less than ₹ 1,00,000/- shall be allowed to offer their holding to the Market Maker(s) (individually or \njointly) in that scrip provided that he sells his entire holding in that scrip in one lot along with a \ndeclaration to the effect to the selling broker. Based on the IPO price of ₹ [●]/- per share the minimum \nlot size is [●] Equity Shares of face value of ₹ 10 each thus minimum depth of the quote shall be ₹ \n[●]/- until the same, would be revised by EMERGE Platform of National Stock Exchange of India \nLimited. \n \n4. After a period of three (3) months from the market making period, the Market Maker would be exempted to provide quote if the Shares of Market Maker in our Company reaches to 25% of Issue \nSize (including the [●] Equity Shares of face value of ₹ 10 each out to be allotted under this Issue). \nAny Equity Shares allotted to Market Maker under this Issue over and above 25% Equity Shares would \nnot be taken into consideration of computing the threshold of 25% of issue size. As soon as the Shares \nof Market Maker in our Company reduce to 24% of Issue Size, the Market Maker will resume \nproviding 2–way quotes. \n \n5. There shall be no exemption/threshold on downside. However, in the event the Market Maker exhausts his inventory through market making process, EMERGE Platform of National Stock Exchange \nof India Limited may intimate the same to SEBI after due verification. \n \n6. Execution of the order at the quoted price and quantity must be guaranteed by the Market Maker(s), for the quotes given by him. \n \n7. There would not be more than five Market Makers for the Company’s Equity Shares at any point of time and the Market Makers may compete with other Market Makers for better quotes to the \ninvestors. At this stage, Holani Consultants Private Limited is acting as the sole Market Maker. 8. On the first day of the listing, there will be pre – opening session (call auction) and there after the trading will happen as per the equity market hours. The circuits will apply from the first day of the \nlisting on the discovered price during the pre-open call auction. The securities of the company will be \nplaced in SPOS and would remain in Trade for Trade settlement for 10 days from the date of listing \nof Equity share on the Stock Exchange. 9. The shares of the Company will be traded in continuous trading session from the time and day the company gets listed on Emerge Platform of National Stock Exchange of India Limited and market \nmaker will remain present as per the guidelines mentioned under National Stock Exchange of India \nLimited and SEBI circulars. \n \n10. All \ncontrollable reasons require prior approval from the Exchange, while force – majeure will be \napplicable for non – controllable reasons. The decision of the Exchange for deciding controllable and \nnon – controllable reasons would be final. \n \n12. The Market Maker(s) shall have the right to terminate said arrangement by giving one – month notice or on mutually acceptable terms to the Book Running Lead Manager, who shall then be responsible \nto appoint a replacement Market Maker(s). In case of termination of the above – mentioned Market Making agreement prior to the completion \nof the compulsory Market Making period, it shall be the responsibility of the Book Running Lead \nManager to arrange for another Market Maker(s) in replacement during the term of the notice period \nbeing served by the Market Maker but prior to the date of releasing the existing Market Maker from \nits duties in order to ensure compliance with the requirements of regulation 261 of the SEBI (ICDR) \nRegulations. Further the Company and the Book Running Lead Manager reserve the right to appoint \nother Market Maker(s) either as a replacement of the current Market Maker or as an additional \nMarket Maker subject to the total number of Designated Market Makers does not exceed 5 (five) or \nas specified by the relevant laws and regulations applicable at that particular point of time. The \nMarket Making Agreement is available for inspection at our Corporate Office from 11.00 a.m. to 5.00 \np.m. on working days. 13. EMERGE Platform of NSE will have all margins which are applicable on the NSE EMERGE viz., Mark – to – Market, Value – At – Risk (VAR) Margin, Extreme Loss Margin, Special Margins and Base Minimum \nCapital etc. Emerge Platform of National Stock Exchange of India Limited can impose any other \nmargins as deemed necessary from time-to-time. \n \n14. Emerge Platform of National Stock Exchange of India Limited will monitor the obligations on a real time basis and punitive action will be initiated for any exceptions and/or non – compliances. \nPenalties/ fines may be imposed by the Exchange on the Market Maker, in case he is not able to \nprovide the desired liquidity in a particular security as per the specified guidelines. These penalties/ \nfines will be set by the Exchange from time to time. The Exchange will impose a penalty on the Market \nMaker(s) in case he is not present in the market (offering two – way quotes) for at least 75% of the \ntime. The nature of the penalty will be monetary as well as suspension in market making activities/ \ntrading membership. The Department of Surveillance and Supervision of the Exchange would decide and publish the \npenalties/ fines/ suspension for any type of misconduct/ manipulation/ other irregularities by the \nMarket Maker from time to time. \n \n15. Pursuant to SEBI Circular number CIR/MRD/DSA/31/2012 dated November 27, 2012, limits on the upper side for Market Makers during market making process has been made applicable, based on \nthe issue size and as follows: Re‐Entry threshold for buy quote \n(including mandatory initial inventory \nof 5% of the Issue Size) \nUp to Rs. 20 Crore \n25% \n24% \nRs. 20 crores to Rs. 50 crores \n20% \n19% \nRs. 50 to Rs. 80 crores \n15% \n14% \nAbove Rs. 80 crores \n12% \n11% Buy quote exemption threshold \n(including \nmandatory \ninitial \ninventory of 5% of the Issue Size) Issue Size Page 83 of 402 The Market Making arrangement, trading and other related aspects including all those specified \nabove shall be subject to the applicable provisions of law and/or norms issued by SEBI/ EMERGE \nPlatform of National Stock Exchange of India Limited from time to time. \n \n16. All the above – mentioned conditions and systems regarding the Market Making Arrangement are subject to change based on changes or additional regulations and guidelines from SEBI and Stock \nExchange from time to time. \n \n17. Pledge of Locked in Equity Shares: In terms of Regulation 242 of the SEBI (ICDR) Regulations, 2018, the Equity Shares held by our \nPromoters and locked in may be pledged as a collateral security for a loan granted by a scheduled \ncommercial bank or public financial institution or a systemically important non-banking finance \ncompany or housing finance company, subject to following: ➢ In case of Minimum Promoters’ Contribution, the loan has been granted to the issuer company or its subsidiary(ies)for the purpose of financing one or more of the Objects of the \nIssue and pledge of equity shares is one of the terms of sanction of the loan. \n➢ In case of Equity Shares held by Promoters in excess of Minimum Promoters’ contribution, the pledge of equity shares is one of the terms of sanction of the loan. \n \nHowever, lock in shall continue pursuant to the invocation of the pledge and such transferee shall \nnot be eligible to transfer the equity shares till the lock in period stipulated has expired. \n \n26. Transferability of Locked in Equity Shares: In terms of Regulation 243 of the SEBI (ICDR) Regulations, 2018 and subject to provisions of \nSecurities and Exchange Board of India (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) \nRegulations, 2011 as applicable: ➢ The Equity Shares held by our Promoters and locked in as per Regulation 238 of the SEBI (ICDR) Regulations, 2018 may be transferred to another Promoter or any person of the \nPromoters’ Group or to a new promoter(s) or persons in control of our Company, subject to \ncontinuation of lock-in for the remaining period with transferee and such transferee shall \nnot be eligible to transfer them till the lock-in period stipulated has expired. \n➢ The equity shares held by persons other than promoters and locked in as per Regulation 239 of the SEBI (ICDR) Regulations, 2018 may be transferred to any other person (including \nPromoter and Promoters’ Group) holding the equity shares which are locked-in along with \nthe equity shares proposed to be transferred, subject to continuation of lock-in for the \nremaining period with transferee and such transferee shall not be eligible to transfer them \ntill the lock-in period stipulated has expired. The reasons behind increase in working capital requirements \nof the company in previous two FYs and half year ended September 30, 2025 successively, are as \nunder: \n \nOur company is engaged in the manufacturing and processing of 164 types/varieties of spices which \ncan be broadly categorized as Ground Spices, Blend Spices and Whole Spices under the brand name \n“SHYAM”. In addition to our spice offerings, we are also engaged in trading and distribution of \nGrocery Products such as Black Salt, Rock Salt, Rice, Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dried Fenugreek) etc. and \na diverse range of Herbs and seasonings which includes Oregano, Peri Peri, Chilli Flakes, Mixed \nHerbs, Onion Flakes, Tomato Powder etc.  \n \nSummary of the production capacity of our Company and actual production for the last three FYs \nand period ended on September 30, 2025 is as under: Financial Years \n2025 \n2024 \n2023 \nInstalled \nCapacity For the period ended on September 30, 2025 Item Name Actual \nProduction % Increase Installed \nCapacity Actual \nProduction % Increase Installed \nCapacity Actual \nProduction % increase Installed \nCapacity Actual \nProduction in \nproduction in \nproduction in \nproduction (In Mts) \nGround \nSpices \n8760 \n1642.26 \n- \n8760 \n4531.17 \n80.71% \n3675 \n2507.38 \n12.99% \n3360 \n2218.97 (In MTs) (In Mts) (In MTs) (In Mts) (In MTs) (In Mts) (In MTs) Blended Spices \n3120 \n213.61 \n- \n3120 \n478.12 \n00.00 \n480 \n478.28 \n645.10% \n480 \n64.19 \nWhole Spices \n6180 \n472.75 \n- \n6180 \n729.33 \n(13.52%) \n1380 \n843.34 \n327.61% \n1380 \n197.22 \n \nIncrease of working capital gap in FY 2024 \nIn the FY 24, our company has ramped up the production of our offerings significantly due to fresh \nsanction of working capital limits from ₹ 700 lakhs to ₹ 1740 lakhs. With the increase in production, \nthere were more holdings of raw materials for continuous production requirements and storage of \nfinished goods, the levels of investment in raw materials and finished goods in FY 23 amounting to \n₹ 1,121.90 lakhs has increased to ₹ 2,321.09 lakhs in FY 24 leading to increase in investment in \ninventories by ₹ 1,859.90 lakhs.  \n \nFurther with the increase in production, we were able to increase our sales. The sales of our \ncompany in FY 24 were ₹ 10,760.52 lakhs in comparison to sales in FY 23 at ₹ 6,795.29 lakhs. The \nsales of our Company increased by ₹ 3,965.23 lakhs leading to 58.35% increase. The increase in \nsales has led to increase in levels of investment in trade receivables. The trade receivables \nincreased to ₹ 558.69 lakhs from ₹ 374.32 lakhs leading to increase in investment in trade \nreceivables by ₹ 184.37 lakhs. \n \nDue to increase in inventories and trade receivables in FY24, this resulted in negative cash flow \nfrom operations in FY24 which was funded by short term borrowings resulting in increase in level \nof debts of the company in FY24. These were the major reasons for increase in working capital \nrequirements of our company in FY 24 as compared with FY 23. Page 104 of 402 Increase of working capital gap in FY 2025 \nIn the FY 25, Our company anticipated the demand of ground spices and ramped up the production \nof ground spices majorly chili and store bulk qty of finished goods. The production of ground spices \nincreased by 80.71% in FY25 in comparison with FY24 which led to increase in levels of investment \nin raw materials, work-in-progress and finished goods while maintaining the production of blended \nspices and slightly declining the production of whole spices as per demand and supply mechanism \nprevalent in the markets. To meet the enhanced fund requirements, our Company increased \nworking capital limits from banks from ₹ 1,740 lakhs in FY24 to ₹ 3,530 lakhs in FY25. \n \nThe inventories of our company comprising of raw materials, work-in-progress and finished goods \nstood at ₹ 4,071.69 lakhs in FY 25 as compared to ₹ 2,981.80 lakhs.  \n \nFurther the sales of our Company in FY25 increase to ₹ 12,468.04 lakhs from ₹ 10,760.52 lakhs in \nFY24 leading to rise by 13.70%. The increase in sales has led to increase in levels of investment in \ntrade receivables of our company. The trade receivables increased to ₹ 859.02 lakhs from ₹ 558.69 \nlakhs leading to increase in investment in trade receivables by ₹ 300.33 lakhs. \n \nDue to increase in inventories and trade receivables in FY25, this resulted in negative cash flow \nfrom operations in FY25 which was funded by short term borrowings resulting in increase in level \nof debts of the company in FY25. These were the major reasons for increase in working capital \nrequirements of our company in FY 25 as compared with FY 24. \n \nIncrease of working capital gap during the period ended September 30, 2025 \nDuring the period ended September 30, 2025, the contribution of modern trade, comprising sales \nto large retail chains such as D-Mart, Metro Cash & Carry, Reliance Retail and Dealshare, has \nincreased significantly. The share of modern trade in our total revenue has risen from 0.43% in FY23 \nto 31.06% in FY24, 44.31% in FY25 and further to 48.66% during the period ended September 30, \n2025. Under the modern trade model, prompt delivery of goods is required upon receipt of orders \nfrom retail chains, necessitating higher levels of finished goods inventory. To support this \nrequirement and ensure uninterrupted production, our Company is also required to maintain \nadequate raw material inventory. As a result of these operational needs, total inventory comprising \nraw materials, work-in-progress and finished goods increased from ₹ 4,071.69 lakhs as at March \n31, 2025, to ₹ 4,515.09 lakhs as at September 30, 2025. For further details on revenue generated \nunder various business models, please refer to “Our Business – Revenue Model” on page 157-158. \n \nIn addition, our company booked revenue of ₹ 6,377.96 lakhs during the period ended September \n30, 2025, reflecting an annualized growth of 2.31% over FY25. The increase in sales correspondingly \nresulted in higher investment in trade receivables. Trade receivables increased from ₹ 859.02 lakhs \nas of March 31, 2025, to ₹ 1,028.08 lakhs as of September 30, 2025, representing an incremental \ninvestment of ₹ 169.06 lakhs. \n \nThe increase in raw material inventory, finished goods inventory and trade receivables during the \nperiod ended September 30, 2025, resulted in higher working capital being blocked in current \nassets. Although the Company generated positive cash flows from operating activities, the internal \naccruals were not sufficient to fully meet the expanded working capital requirements arising from \nthe growth in scale of operations and higher inventory holding levels. Accordingly, our Company \navailed short-term borrowings to bridge this gap, leading to an increase in the outstanding level of \nshort-term debt as at September 30, 2025. These factors were the primary contributors to the \nincrease in our working capital requirements during the period ending September 30, 2025, as \ncompared to FY25. \n \nBasis of estimation of requirements \nOur company operates under a multi-channel revenue model, which includes General Trade, \nModern Trade, HORECA sales, Private Labelling, Quick Commerce, Exports, and Website sales. \nHistorically our focus has been on general trade which accounted for more than 90% of our total \nrevenue up to FY23. From FY24, our company changed its business strategy and started focusing \nmore on revenue models having high volume trades. The volume in modern trade business \nsegment is much higher in comparison to the one in general trade business segment. Our sales \nunder the modern trade segment increased from ₹ 29.25 Lakhs in FY23 to ₹ 5,524.92 Lakhs in FY25 \nand we have booked sales of ₹ 3,103.58 lakhs in this segment during the period ended September \n30, 2025, registering annualized growth of 12.35% over FY25. Simultaneously, the total volumes of \nthe goods sold of our company also increased from 3,401.81 MT in FY23 to 5,133.99 MT in FY25. \nFurther, volume of total goods sold during the period ended September 30, 2025 is 2,695.59 MT \nindicating annualized growth of 5.03% over FY25.  \n \nOur company intends to focus more over its higher volume modern trade segment and plans to \nexpand and cover all the modern trade players in the industry such as DMart, Reliance Retail, \nDealshare and Metro Cash and Carry etc on pan India basis. This will help us to boost the revenue \nof our company.  \n \nFurther, with the increase in the revenue generated from modern trade segment, the sale of our \nblended spices also increased from ₹ 1,046.61 Lakhs in FY23 to ₹ 2,099.40 Lakhs in FY25 \nsimultaneously as this product category remains to be in high demand in these supermarket \noutlets. \n \nTo fulfill the demand of our product offerings generated from modern trade business segment, our \ncompany needs to maintain optimum level of inventory of raw material and finished goods, \ntherefore working capital gap is increasing in FY26, FY27 and FY28.  \n \nSimilarly, our company is also focusing on expanding its presence on quick commerce platforms \nand have done tie-ups with all the major quick commerce players such as Swiggy Instamart, Zepto, Page 106 of 402 Flipkart minutes and Blinkit. This enables us to reach tech-savvy urban consumers who prioritize \nspeed and convenience, further expanding our brand presence in the fast-growing digital retail \nspace. \n \nAdditionally, our company is further enhancing its production capacity to cater to demand of our \nproducts under private labelling segment. Historically we have been doing private labelling but its \ncontribution to our revenue from operations has been very limited. Going forward with the \nenhanced capacity, our company will be focusing more upon undertaking more private labelling \nassignments.    \n \nFurther, we also want to establish our brand “SHYAM” in the market and will be undertaking \nadvertisement and marketing campaigns including hiring of Mrs. Preity Zinta as a brand \nambassador of our company. Investment in advertisement and marketing expenses will help our \ncompany to increase its visibility and establish our brand image in the market. This in turn will help \nus in increasing demand of our products, ultimately generating more revenue for our company. \n \nAdditionally, our company also intends to tap into new markets and increase our presence in \ninternational markets. In FY25, our export sales increased from ₹ 85.16 Lakhs in FY24 to ₹ 169.53 \nLakhs in FY25. We have booked export sales of ₹ 143.13 lakhs during the period ended September \n30, 2025. In addition to our spice offerings, we are also engaged in trading and \ndistribution of Grocery Products such as Black Salt, Rock Salt, Rice, Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dried \nFenugreek) etc. and a diverse range of Herbs and seasonings which includes Oregano, Peri \nPeri, Chilli Flakes, Mixed Herbs, Onion Flakes, Tomato Powder etc.  \n \nIn the FY23, FY24, FY25 and period ended September 30, 2025, our Company maintained raw \nmaterial inventory levels for 53 days, 96 days, 45 days and 54 days respectively. During the \nstart of Q4 of FY25, our company converted the raw material in hand into finished goods to \nensure an uninterrupted supply of finished goods in Q4 of FY25 and Q1 of FY26. This led to a \ndecrease in closing inventory of raw materials leading to a decline in the holding levels of raw \nmaterial and it fell below the average holding period to 45 days. On the same hand, the closing \ninventory of finished goods increased, leading to an increase in average holding levels of \nfinished goods. \n \nFurther, share of revenue from the modern trade segment in total revenue from operations \nincreased from 44.31% in FY25 to 48.66% during the half year ended September 30, 2025. \nThis segment requires prompt delivery of goods, necessitating the maintenance of higher \nlevels of finished goods inventory, as well as higher raw material inventory to support \nuninterrupted production and timely order fulfilment. It has resulted in an increase in average \nholding levels of raw material inventory to 54 days during H2 of FY26.   \n \nOur company has estimated inventory holdings of raw materials to 90 days in FY26 and 91 \ndays each for FY27, and FY 28 due to the following reasons: \n(i) Our raw material availability is seasonal and our major purchases is done at the time of Raw Material crop harvesting season to procure best quality raw material at competitive prices, \ntherefore, we procure in bulk. \n(ii) We source from various states across India like Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, Rajasthan etc therefore to save the transportation cost we used to maintain minimum inventory of three \nmonths in past. \n(iii) With expansion in our production capacity, we need to maintain larger stocks of raw material to ensure continuous production of finished goods so that optimum utilization of \nproduction capacity can be achieved without hampering operations. \n(iv) Further, we have also expanded our product line and presently manufacturing/ processing 164 types/ varieties of spices. This expanded range of products along with changing \nrecipes requires to hold a larger variety of raw materials for a longer time, waiting for a \nright time to process them.   \n \nTherefore, our company has estimated inventory holdings of raw materials based on past \ntrends and estimated holding levels to 90 days in FY26 and 91 days each for FY27, and FY 28. In the FY23 and FY24, our Company was maintaining Work in Progress in the raw materials \ninventory only. In FY25, our company started maintaining raw materials and work in progress \nstock separately and has estimated work in progress holding of the company for the FY 26, \nFY27 and FY28 at the level of 9 days level per production process of our company. Work in Progress In the FY23, FY24, FY25 and stub period September 30, 2025, our Company maintained \nfinished goods inventory levels for 26 days, 26 days, 90 days and 105 days respectively. During \nthe start of Q4 of FY25, our company converted the raw material in hand into finished goods \nto ensure an uninterrupted supply of finished goods in Q4 of FY25 and Q1 of FY26. This led to \nan increase in closing inventory of finished goods and ultimately leading to an increase in the \nholding levels of finished goods to 92 days. On the same hand, the closing inventory of raw \nmaterials decreased leading to a decrease in average holding levels of raw materials. \n \nFurther, share of revenue from the modern trade segment in total revenue from operations \nincreased from 44.31% in FY25 to 48.66% during the half year ended September 30, 2025. \nThis segment requires prompt delivery of goods, necessitating the maintenance of higher \nlevels of finished goods inventory, resulting in increase in average holding level of finished \ngoods inventory to 105 days during H2 of FY26. \n \nWith the change in the business strategy of our company, we are planning to focus more upon \nthe modern trade and quick commerce business segments. In modern trade, we are supplying Finished Goods Page 108 of 402 Particulars \nJustification for Holding Levels \nto retail chains like DMart, Reliance Retail, Metro Cash and Carry, and DealShare. To ensure \nuninterrupted supply to these retail chains, we need to hold large inventory of finished goods. \nIn addition to this, quick commerce also requires ready availability of finished goods for \nprompt delivery of goods to end customers. These segments provide higher volume trade to \nour company and thus to fulfill the demand of the customers in these business segments, we \nestimate to increase the holding period of our finished goods inventory to 52 days in FY26, \nFY27 and FY28. Our company generally provides products on credit to our customers for a credit period of 20 \ndays, 19 days, 25 days and 29 days in the FY23, FY24, FY25 and period ended September 30, \n2025, respectively, which is as per the acceptable business practice in the similar trade. \nOur company has estimated holding levels of 30 days each for FY26, FY27, and FY28 \nrespectively based on the holding levels for FY25. Our management believes that by providing \nadditional credit period to our customers will help us to increase the volumes of trade and \nsecuring bulk orders for our company. Trade \nReceivables Our company’s trade payables predominantly comprise of payables towards the purchase of \nraw materials. The trade payable days were approximately 22 days, 36 days, 22 days and 32 \ndays of purchases for FY23, FY24, FY25 and half year ended September 30, 2025, respectively.  \nOur Company has proposed to utilize a part of the fresh issue proceeds towards working \ncapital requirements which will lead to payment to creditors and reduction in the outstanding \ndays payable. Hence trade payables days are estimated at 5 days of purchases each for FY26, \nFY27, and FY28 respectively which will enable our Company to get better terms from our \nvendors. This would help us to avail good cash discounts and negotiate with our vendors on \nbetter price to our advantage. \n \n2. Repayment/Pre-payment, in full or in part, of certain outstanding borrowings availed by our Trade Payables company   \nWe have availed a majority of our fund‐based and non‐fund‐based facilities in the ordinary course \nof business from various scheduled commercial banks, financial institutions and other entities. The \nborrowing arrangements entered into by us include, inter alia, term loans and working capital loans. \nFor further information on the financial indebtedness of our Company, see the chapter titled \n“Financial Indebtedness” beginning on page 290. As of November 30, 2025, our Company had an \noutstanding total secured borrowing of ₹ 4,377.16 Lakhs. We propose to utilise a portion of the Net \nProceeds aggregating to ₹ 1,000.00 lakhs for Repayment/Pre-payment, in full or in part, of cash \ncredit borrowing facility availed by our company from scheduled commercial banks.  \n \nPursuant to the terms of the borrowing arrangements, prepayment of certain indebtedness may \nattract prepayment charges as prescribed by the respective lender. Such prepayment charges, as \napplicable, will also be funded out of the Net Proceeds. Given the nature of the borrowings and the \nterms of repayment or prepayment, the aggregate outstanding amounts under the borrowings may \nvary from time to time and we may, in accordance with the relevant repayment schedule, repay or \nrefinance some of the existing borrowings prior to Allotment or avail of additional credit facilities. \n  \nFurther, the outstanding amounts under these borrowings as well as the sanctioned limits are \ndependent on several factors and may vary with our business cycle with multiple intermediate \nrepayments, drawdowns and enhancement of sanctioned limits. Accordingly, our Company may \nutilise the Net Proceeds for repayment/prepayment of any such refinanced facilities (including any \nprepayment fees or penalties thereon) or any additional facilities obtained by our Company. \nHowever, the aggregate amount to be utilised from the Net Proceeds towards prepayment, \nrepayment or redemption of borrowings (including refinanced or additional facilities availed, if any), \nin part or full, will not exceed ₹ 1,000.00 lakhs. In light of the above, at the time of filing of Red \nHerring Prospectus, the table below shall be suitably updated to reflect the revised amounts or \nloans, as the case may be. Such repayment or prepayment will help reduce our outstanding \nindebtedness and debt servicing costs and enable utilization of the internal accruals for further \ninvestment towards business growth and expansion. In addition, repayment/prepayment of the \nloans will add to the profitability of our Company due to reduced finance cost and also the \nimprovement in the debt‐to‐equity ratio of our Company which enable us to raise further resources Page 109 of 402 in the future to fund potential business development opportunities and plans to grow and expand \nour business in the future. \n \nDebt-Equity Ratio of our company and our listed peers for the stub period September 30, 2025 and \nin FY 25, FY 24 and FY 23 is depicted in the table below: Name Of Company \nDebt-Equity Ratio \nSeptember 30, 2025 \n2024-2025 \n2023-2024 \n2022-2023 \nShyam Dhani Industries Limited   \n1.73 \n2.00 \n1.57 \n1.38 \nOur company Listed Peers  \n \n \n \n \nMadhusudan Masala Limited   \n0.69 \n0.71 \n1.13 \n3.98 \nNHC Foods Limited \n0.53 \n0.38 \n1.21 \n1.01 \nM/s G.L. Brand Creation and Marketing Expenses Our Company proposes to utilise ₹ 635.63 Lakhs from the net proceeds of this Initial Public Offering \n(IPO) towards Brand Creation and Marketing Expenses. Recognizing the critical importance of \nbuilding a strong brand identity in the competitive consumer products sector, we aim to significantly \nstrengthen our brand presence and enhance consumer engagement through strategic investments \nin marketing. For details of the advertisement expenses incurred in the past three years by our \nCompany please see “Our Business – Our Business Strategies - Increase in advertisement and \nmarketing activities” on page 162-163. \n \nThere are no Brand Ambassador Expenses and Production Charges have been made by our Company \nin the past. By allocating a portion of the funds raised through this initial public offering towards \nbrand creation and marketing initiatives we expect to strengthen brand awareness and improve \nconsumer engagement as more customers become familiar with our brand. The allocation of the \nNet Proceeds in the brand creation and marketing expenses will be done in the following manner \nto enhance the brand recognition, create a unique brand persona, and foster consumer loyalty. ➢ Brand Ambassador Engagement As a key element of our brand creation strategy, our Company entered into a Brand Endorsement \nAgreement dated August 02, 2025 with the renowned Bollywood actress, Ms. Preity Zinta. This \nagreement designates Ms. Zinta as our brand ambassador for a term of 24 months. This \nassociation is intended to leverage the widespread popularity and appeal of Ms. Zinta to connect \nwith a broader consumer base, especially in urban and semi-urban areas. The Partnership is \nexpected to amplify our company's marketing efforts and significantly increase our visibility \nacross various digital platforms channels, including social and digital media. ➢ Production of Advertising Content In line with our brand-building strategy, our Company has entered into a Line Producer \nAgreement dated August 07, 2025, with PAMV Studios Private Limited (“PAMV Studios”), a \nproduction services company. Under this agreement, PAMV Studios has been engaged to \nmanage the end-to-end production of advertisement films and commercials featuring our brand \nambassador, Ms. Preity Zinta. \n \nPAMV Studios will be responsible for overseeing all aspects of the production process, including \npre-production planning, selection of shooting locations, coordination of technical crews and \nequipment, as well as post-production services such as editing and sound design. The objective \nis to ensure the delivery of quality, impactful content that aligns with our brand vision and \nmarketing goals. \n \nThese advertisement films and commercials will form a key part of our marketing campaign, and \nwill be deployed across various platforms—such as television, digital media, and social media \nchannels—to maximize visibility and audience engagement. revenue profile of \nthe business and in turn helps assess the overall financial performance of our Company \nand size of our business. \nGrowth in Revenue from \nOperations Growth in Revenue from Operations provides information regarding the growth of our \nbusiness for the respective year/period. \nGross Profit (₹ in Lakhs) \nGross Profit provides information regarding the profits from sale of products by our \nCompany. \nGross Profit Margin (%) \nGross Profit Margin is an indicator of the profitability on sale of products by our \nCompany. \nEBITDA (₹ in Lakhs) \nEBITDA provides information regarding the operational efficiency of the business. \nEBITDA Margin (%) \nEBITDA Margin is an indicator of the operational profitability and financial \nperformance of our business. \nProfit After Tax (₹ in Lakhs) \nProfit after tax provides information regarding the overall profitability of the business. \nPAT Margin (%) \nPAT Margin is an indicator of the overall profitability and financial performance of our \nbusiness. \nROE (%) \nRoE provides how efficiently our Company generates profits from shareholders’ funds. \nROCE (%) \nROCE provides how efficiently our Company generates earnings from the capital \nemployed in the business. \nNet Fixed Asset Turnover (In \nTimes) Net Fixed Asset turnover ratio is indicator of the efficiency with which our Company is \nable to leverage its assets to generate revenue from operations. \nNet Working Capital Days \nNet working capital days indicates the working capital requirements of our Company \nin relation to revenue generated from operations. \nOperating Cash Flows (₹ in \nLakhs) Operating cash flows provides how efficiently our company generates cash through its \ncore business activities. \nTotal Quantity Sold (in Kgs) \nThis metric helps us to track the sales growth in volumes of our business according to \nthe various product offerings  \nNumber of product offerings \nThis metric indicates the number of product offerings of our company \nCustomers served during the \nyear This metric indicates how many customers did our company served during the \nyear/period \nWholesalers and distributors \nin the general trade network This metric helps us understand the number of wholesalers and distributors associated \nwith our company. \nPresence in states and union \nterritories This metric indicates the geographical representation of our company’s business and \nmarket \n \nFinancial KPIs of our Company For the Year ended on March 31 \n2025 \n2024 \n2023 \nRevenue from Operations (1) (₹ in Lakhs) I. SPECIAL TAX BENEFITS AVAILABLE TO THE COMPANY UNDER DIRECT TAXATION Outlined below are the special tax benefits available to Shyam Dhani Industries Limited (Formerly \nKnown as Shyam Dhani Industries Private Limited) (the “Company”), its Shareholders under the \nIncome-tax Act, 1961 (the “Act”) as amended by the Finance Act, 2025 applicable for the Financial \nYear 2025-26 relevant to the Assessment Year 2026-27. • Lower corporate tax rate under section 115BAA Section 115BAA has been inserted in the Act w.e.f. FY 2019-20. It gives an option to domestic \ncompany to be governed by this section from a particular assessment year. If a company opts for \nsection 115BAA of the Act, the company can pay corporate tax at a reduced rate of 25.168% (22% \nplus surcharge of 10% and education cess of 4%). However once opted for reduced rate of \ntaxation under the said section, it cannot be subsequently withdrawn. \n \nSection 115BAA further provides that domestic companies availing the option will not be \nrequired to pay Minimum Alternate Tax (MAT) on their ‘book profits’ under section 115JB of the \nAct. However, such a company will no longer be eligible to avail any specified exemptions / \nincentives under the Act and will also need to comply with the other conditions specified in \nsection 115BAA. Also, if a company opts for section 115BAA, the tax credit (under section \n115JAA), if any, which it is entitled to on account of MAT paid in earlier years, will no longer be \navailable. \n \nFurther, it shall not be allowed to claim set-off of any brought forward losses arising to it on \naccount of additional depreciation and other specified incentives. \n \nThe Company has already evaluated and opted for the lower corporate tax rate of 25.168% \n(prescribed under section 115BAA of the Act) with effect from AY 2024-25. Special direct tax benefits available to the Shareholders \n \nThere are no special direct tax benefits available to the shareholders. \n \nII.
