Despite \nelevated financing costs and heightened geopolitical tensions, global activity firmed in early 2024. \nGlobal growth is envisaged to reach a slightly faster pace this year than previously expected, due \nmainly to the continued solid expansion of the U.S. economy. However, the extent of expected \ndeclines in global interest rates has moderated amid lingering inflation pressures in key economies. By \nhistorical standards, the global outlook remains subdued: both advanced economies and emerging \nmarket and developing economies (EMDEs) are set to grow at a slower pace over 2024-26 than in the decade preceding the pandemic.  \n \nDomestic demand is projected to improve in many EMDEs \nthis year, in line with a moderate cyclical recovery from the \neffects of high inflation, tight financial conditions, and anemic \nindustrial activity. Aggregate EMDE growth is nonetheless \npoised to decelerate slightly mainly because of idiosyncratic \nfactors in some large economies. Moreover, significant \nchallenges persist in vulnerable economies—including in low-\nincome countries (LICs) and those facing elevated levels of \nconflict and violence—where growth prospects have \ndeteriorated markedly since January.   \n \nGlobal trade growth is recovering, supported by a pickup in goods trade. Services-trade growth is \nexpected to provide less of a tailwind this year, given that tourism has nearly recovered to pre \npandemic levels. However, the trade outlook remains lackluster compared to recent decades, partly \nreflecting a proliferation of trade-restrictive measures and elevated trade policy uncertainty.   \n \nAggregate commodity prices have increased since late last year. Amid fluctuations, average oil prices \nare expected to be slightly higher in 2024 than in 2023, underpinned by a tight demand-supply balance \nin a context of continued geopolitical tensions. Nonetheless, average energy prices are projected to \nbe marginally lower this year than last—reflecting notable declines in prices for natural gas and coal—\nwhile remaining well above pre-pandemic levels. Metals prices are expected to be little changed over \nthe forecast horizon, as demand related to metals-intensive clean energy investments and a broader \npickup in global industrial activity attenuate the impact on commodity demand of declining real estate \nactivity in China. Well-supplied markets for grains and other agricultural commodities should see \nedible food crop prices decline modestly. Page 133 of 402 Inflation continues to wane globally, making progress toward central bank \ntargets in advanced economies and EMDEs, but at a slower pace than \npreviously expected. Core inflation has remained stubbornly high in many \neconomies, supported by rapid growth of services prices. Over the remainder \nof 2024, continued tight monetary policy stances and slowing wage increases \nshould help reduce inflation further. By the end of 2026, global inflation is \nexpected to settle at an average rate of 2.8 percent, broadly consistent with \ncentral bank targets.  \n \nThe anticipated extent of monetary easing in advanced economies this \nyear has diminished substantially since late 2023—by more than a \npercentage point in the case of the United States. Expected policy rate \npaths diverge across major economies, as the European Central Bank \nproceeds with policy easing while the U.S. Federal Reserve keeps rates on \nhold for longer. Indeed, aside from short-term fluctuations, market \nexpectations for the path of U.S. interest rates have repeatedly moved \nhigher since 2022. Despite this market reassessment, global financial \nconditions have eased this year, reflecting solid risk appetite following last \nyear’s progress on disinflation and diminished concerns about the \npossibility of a sharp slowdown in global growth. In particular, global equity markets have made sizable \ngains.  \n \nEMDE \nfinancial \nconditions \nsimilarly \nbecame \nmore \naccommodative early this year, aided by declining domestic \npolicy rates, improving global sentiment, and expected \neasing of advancedeconomy monetary conditions. EMDE \nconditions turned somewhat less accommodative in the \nsecond quarter, as a strengthening of the U.S. dollar—\nprompted by geopolitical tensions and firm inflation data in \nthe United States— coincided with a bout of capital outflows. \nAlthough market perceptions of sovereign credit risk have \ngenerally eased this year, EMDE borrowing costs continue to \nbe high, and marked divergences persist. Indeed, credit ratings and debt sustainability analyses \nindicate that about 40 percent of EMDEs remain acutely vulnerable to debt-related stress. Across the forecast horizon, global growth remains lackluster by recent historical standards, at about \n0.4 percentage point below the 2010-19 average. In 2024-25, growth is set to underperform its \naverage pace in the 2010s in nearly 60 percent of economies, representing more than 80 percent of \nglobal output and population. The subdued outlook—despite the anticipated moderation of various \ncyclical headwinds— underscores a secular deceleration of potential growth in many large economies. \nRelative to pre pandemic norms, growth has weakened notably in countries that experienced high \nrates of inflation, much of which emanated from shocks to supply chains and commodity prices. Yet \nthis trend is set to continue in the coming years, suggesting potentially enduring supply-side weakness.   \nGDP per capita in EMDEs is forecast to grow at about 3 percent on average over 2024-26, well below Deviation of output from pre-pandemic trends Page 134 of 402 the average in 2010-19. Excluding China, EMDE per capita GDP growth is forecast to be lower still, \naveraging 2.5 percent over 2024-26. Some large EMDEs, such as India, are expected to see continued \nsolid per capita growth. Yet the trend of the 2020s so far is one of uneven and limited progress. Nearly \nhalf of EMDEs are set to lose ground relative to advanced economies when viewed over the 2020-24 \nperiod. Although this trend is expected to improve somewhat over 2025-26 in EMDEs as a whole, per \ncapita growth is set to remain stagnant in many LICs and FCS. \n \n(Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) \n \nGLOBAL RISK AND POLICY CHALLENGES \nRisks to the outlook have become somewhat more balanced since January, with the global economy \nthus far proving resilient to high financing costs. However, the balance of risks remains tilted to the \ndownside amid elevated uncertainty. Heightened geopolitical tensions could sharply depress \nsentiment, disrupt trade and commodity markets, push up inflation, and hurt economic activity; in \nparticular, a conflict-related disruption to global oil supply could push oil prices markedly higher and \nundermine the disinflation process. Elevated trade policy uncertainty—already at an unusually high \nlevel relative to previous years with major elections since 2000—and proliferating trade restrictions \ncould weigh on trade prospects and economic activity. Further trade fragmentation could have \nadverse global repercussions via declining economic confidence, increasing trade distortions, and \nrelated financial market reactions. Advanced-economy interest rates are at levels last seen before the 2008-09 global financial crisis, and, \nin light of persistently above-target inflation and tight labor markets, they are likely to remain high for \nsome time. Over the next couple of years, policy interest rates in advanced economies are expected \nto be more than double their 2000-19 average. Although the global economy has withstood high \ninterest rates better than was anticipated, interest rate-sensitive components of activity will continue \nto be restrained. Moreover, if further delays in the disinflation process emerge, policy rate cuts may \nbe postponed. A higher resulting path for interest rates, relative to the baseline, could give rise to \nmarkedly tighter financial conditions and significantly weaker global growth. Page 135 of 402 Policy makers face a range of daunting challenges. Coordinated \nimprovements in debt relief will be necessary to free up resources for \ngrowthenhancing investments, particularly in some of the most \nvulnerable EMDEs, given elevated financing needs. Enhanced \ninternational cooperation is needed to tackle the threat of climate \nchange, the fragmentation of trade networks, and mounting food \ninsecurity and conflict. Global cooperation is also essential to leverage \nthe benefits of new technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), \nincluding by tapping AI solutions to address global challenges. Fiscal space remains narrow in many EMDEs amid weak revenues \nand elevated debt-servicing costs. Decisive measures will be \nneeded to boost fiscal resources for public investment. These \ncould include reforms to mobilize domestic revenues, the \nharnessing of digital technologies to simplify tax payments and \nrecords management, and reform of costly and inefficient \nsubsidies. Furthermore, even with increased public resources, \nimproved spending efficiency will be needed to meet a wide range \nof development challenges. In particular, it is critical to improve \ninfrastructure investment efficiency, where EMDEs significantly lag \nadvanced economies.  \n \nIn the case of small states, elevated exposure to external shocks poses a formidable fiscal challenge, \nunderscoring the need to balance additional investments in human capital and climate-resilient \ninfrastructure with the maintenance of adequate fiscal buffers.   \n \n(Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) \n \nGLOBAL TRADE \nGlobal trade in goods and services was nearly flat in 2023—the \nweakest performance outside of global recessions in the past 50 years. \nAmid a sharp slowdown in global industrial production, the volume of \ngoods trade contracted for most of 2023 and fell by 1.9 percent for the \nyear as a whole. The evolution of goods trade diverged across regions, \nwith volumes declining in advanced economies, especially in Europe, \nand stagnating in EMDEs as expansions in China and Europe and \nCentral Asia (ECA) offset contractions in Latin America and the \nCaribbean (LAC), Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), and Middle East and North \nAfrica (MNA).   \n \nThe value of global services trade grew about 9 percent in 2023, \ndriven primarily by a recovery in tourism flows—exports of travel \nservices surged by about 38 percent (WTO 2024). However, the pace \nof expansion in tourism was substantially below that in 2022, with \nrecent data indicating tourism activity in line with pre-pandemic \nlevels, suggesting a near-full recovery in most regions. Stabilization \nin services trade is reflected in the steadying of the global services \nPMI for new export orders, which has remained closer to neutral \nthresholds compared to last year. Page 136 of 402 Global trade growth is projected to pick up to 2.5 percent this year, \na significant improvement from last year but well below the average \nrates observed in the two decades preceding the pandemic (figure \n1.3.C). The forecast entails a pickup in goods trade growth after a \nsluggish start to the year, supported by a rebound in global goods \ndemand as inventory restocking resumes in the United States and \nthe euro area, and as demand from China stabilizes. Meanwhile, \nservices trade growth is expected to stabilize near its pre-pandemic \npace. In 2025, trade growth is expected to firm to 3.4 percent, in \ntandem with a pickup in growth in the euro area and EMDEs \nexcluding China, and remain steady in 2026. \n \nDespite the expected growth in trade this year, by the end of 2024 \nglobal trade is set to register the slowest half-decade of growth \nsince the 1990s, mirroring subdued global GDP growth (figure \n1.3.D). In the near term, the responsiveness of global trade to global \noutput is likely to remain lower than before the pandemic, reflecting \nmuted investment growth and the recent proliferation of trade \nrestrictions worldwide.   \n \n(Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) GLOBAL INFLATION \nGlobal inflation has continued to decline, yet it remains above target in \nmost advanced economies and in about one-fourth of inflation-\ntargeting EMDEs. The initial phase of disinflation after the pandemic \nwas underpinned by falling energy prices as well as waning supply chain \npressures. Recently, the pace of consumer price disinflation has \nslowed, reflecting a partial rebound in energy prices, along with a \nnotable slowdown in the rate of decline in core inflation. In advanced economies, disinflation in consumer goods prices \nappears to have bottomed out, while inflation in consumer services \nremains elevated. In the United States, resilient economic activity, \nalongside rapid increases in the cost of shelter, has given rise to \npersistently high services and, more broadly, core inflation over the \npast few months. To some extent, the strength of U.S. productivity \ngrowth has mitigated these trends, likely lessening the inflationary \neffects of rising wages. In contrast, subdued productivity in the euro \narea has driven economy-wide labor costs higher, underpinning \nelevated core and services inflation, despite anemic euro area \ndemand.  \n \nIn EMDEs, headline inflation has generally continued to recede on a \n12-month basis. Across most EMDEs in East Asia and Pacific (EAP) and \nLAC, headline inflation broadly continued to trend near or below pre-\npandemic averages through late 2023 and early 2024, despite \nreaccelerating in some countries. However, progress has been slow \nand uneven in other regions, with elevated core price increases \ncontributing to high headline inflation rates. As in advanced \neconomies, persistently high core inflation in EMDEs has been driven \nby services prices, including for shelter. Page 137 of 402 Greater-than-anticipated inflationary pressures earlier this year \nhave led to an upward revision to the projection for near-term \nglobal inflation. Nevertheless, aside from a small group of countries \nwhere very high inflation reflects idiosyncratic domestic challenges, \nglobal inflation is expected to decline to 3.5 percent in 2024, before \neasing further, to 2.9 percent in 2025 and 2.8 percent in 2026, \nbroadly consistent with average country inflation targets. The \nslowdown is expected to be driven by softening core inflation, as \nservices demand moderates and wage growth slows, in addition to \na modest decline in commodity prices. Surveys of inflation \nexpectations similarly imply gradual global disinflation over the next \ntwo years. (Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) \n \nFINANCIAL DEVELOPMENTS \nGlobal financial conditions have eased, on balance, since last year, primarily reflecting declines in risk \npremia amid still-elevated interest rates. Central banks across major advanced economies are \nexpected to gradually lower policy rates this year, but the level of real interest rates is set to remain a \nheadwind to economic activity— albeit a diminishing one—for some time. Policy rate projections \nderived from financial markets have been volatile since U.S. policy tightening started in 2022, with \nexpectations repeatedly revised higher over time. Meanwhile, most advanced-economy central banks \ncontinue to emphasize that the pace of easing will be cautious, reflecting persistent inflationary \npressures—and, in the case of the United States, robust economic activity. As such, government bond \nyields are well above pre-pandemic levels and are likely to remain so, absent large negative shocks to \ngrowth.   \n \nRisk appetite picked up globally early in the year—particularly in advanced economies— signaling \noptimism that continued steady disinflation might accompany resilient growth. With volatility \nsubdued, advanced economy equity valuations reached elevated levels, especially in the United States, \nwhere confidence regarding potential productivity gains from AI played a key role. Sentiment briefly \nwilted in April, amid firm U.S. inflation data and escalating geopolitical tensions, but rebounded \nthereafter. Although the cost of credit remains high, perceptions of corporate credit risk appear \nmuted—except for asset classes, such as office real estate, that have been adversely affected by \nstructural post-pandemic shifts in activity. Corporate credit spreads remain well below 2010-19 \naverage levels in both the United States and the euro area. Banks in these jurisdictions continue to \nreport tightening of standards for lending to firms, but by markedly narrowing majorities. \n \nEMDE financial conditions also eased in the first quarter of 2024, reflecting expectations of easing \nadvanced-economy monetary conditions, improving global investor sentiment, and ongoing policy \nrate cuts in many large EMDEs. Conditions turned less accommodative early in the second quarter, as \nsafe haven flows and declining expectations of U.S. rate cuts stoked a notable strengthening of the \nU.S. dollar and a bout of debt and equity portfolio outflows. Sovereign spreads have nonetheless \ntrended to below 2010-19 levels in the majority of middle income EMDEs, signalling investor \nconfidence that financial stress risks are broadly contained. In contrast, spreads remain elevated \namong EMDEs with weak credit ratings, even if they have declined substantially this year. \n \nIndeed, despite some easing of global conditions, financial stress concerns remain acute in about 40 \npercent of EMDEs—comprising those with weak credit ratings, and those where debt sustainability \nanalyses indicate a high risk of, or existing, debt distress. Among weakly rated countries that had \nmarket access in the 2010s, a combination of political instability, the pandemic and other external \nshocks, and financial crises in the 2020s has rendered non-concessional debt prohibitively expensive. \nAmong unrated countries—many of them low-income countries—debt burdens have grown \nincreasingly severe owing to a decade of debt build-up in the 2010s, coupled with anemic post-\npandemic recoveries and rising debt-service costs. \n \n(Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) Page 138 of 402 RECENT DEVELOPMENTS AND OUTLOOK \nAfter softening in the second half of 2023, activity in EMDEs generally stabilized in early 2024, with \nindicators of domestic demand, including retail sales and consumer confidence, firming somewhat. In \nearly 2024, headline manufacturing and services sector PMIs broadly moved up, with a still greater \nimprovement in headline manufacturing PMIs for EMDEs excluding China. Economic conditions have \nnonetheless continued to diverge, with ongoing weakness among vulnerable EMDEs. Growth in \ncountries with stronger credit ratings has so far outpaced growth in weaker-rated countries, including \nmany grappling with high debt and financing costs, and in those facing acute challenges, such as \nelevated levels of domestic conflict and violence. \n \nEMDE goods trade growth has shown signs of improvement, with the manufacturing component of \nnew export orders PMIs returning to expansionary territory in early 2024, for the first time since mid-\n2023. In contrast, services exports decelerated in most EMDEs, reflecting an increasingly mature \ntourism recovery following the pandemic. However, countries that lifted pandemic-related restrictions \nlater, mostly in East Asia and Pacific (EAP), continue to see a rebound in tourist flows. \n \nAggregate growth in EMDEs is forecast to edge down from 4.2 percent in 2023 to 4 percent in 2024 \nand remain broadly stable over 2025-26, near estimates of EMDE potential growth for the 2020s. \nHowever, these aggregates mask notable differences in regional trends, with the expected pace of \ngrowth falling short of the 2010-19 average in EAP, ECA, and South Asia (SAR), but returning close to \npre-pandemic averages in other regions over 2025-26, partly owing to still supportive commodity \nprices (box 1.1). Excluding China, EMDE growth is projected to inch up to a still subdued pace of 3.5 \npercent this year, before firming to about 3.9 percent in 2025-26, reflecting a cyclical upswing as \nmonetary policy becomes less restrictive and demand from advanced economies gathers pace.   \n \nIn 2024, the contribution to growth from domestic demand in EMDEs is expected to soften relative to \n2023, before firming over 2025-26. The weaker contribution from domestic demand this year, \nhowever, largely reflects idiosyncratic developments in some of the seven largest EMDEs (EM7), \nfollowing strong performance in 2023. In most of these economies, consumption growth is anticipated \nto decelerate in 2024, as the boost from idiosyncratic factors fades, and then stabilize over 2025-26. \nIn contrast, in other EMDEs, domestic demand is expected to gather pace over the forecast horizon. \nAmong these economies, private consumption is envisaged to rebound in 2024 and further strengthen \nover 2025-26, with declining inflation and interest rates supporting real household incomes and \nconsumer confidence. The rebound in consumption is expected to be broad-based across most \nregions. \n \n(Source: https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-economic-prospects) \n \nINDIAN ECONOMIC OVERVIEW \n \nINTRODUCTION \nStrong economic growth in the first quarter of FY 2022-23 helped India overcome the UK to become \nthe fifth-largest economy after it recovered from repeated waves of COVID-19 pandemic shock. Real \nGDP in the first quarter of 2022–23 is currently about 4% higher than its corresponding 2019-20, \nindicating a strong start for India's recovery from the pandemic. Given the release of pent-up demand \nand the widespread vaccination coverage, the contact-intensive services sector will probably be the \nmain driver of development in 2022–2023. Rising employment and substantially increasing private \nconsumption, supported by rising consumer sentiment, will support GDP growth in the coming \nmonths. \n \nFuture capital spending of the government in the economy is expected to be supported by factors such \nas tax buoyancy, the streamlined tax system with low rates, a thorough assessment and rationalisation \nof the tariff structure, and the digitization of tax filing. In the medium run, increased capital spending \non infrastructure and asset-building projects is set to increase growth multipliers, and with the revival \nin monsoon and the Kharif sowing, agriculture is also picking up momentum. The contact-based \nservices sector has largely demonstrated promise to boost growth by unleashing the pent-up demand Page 139 of 402 over the period of April-September 2022. The sector's success is being captured by a number of HFIs \n(High-Frequency Indicators) that are performing well, indicating the beginnings of a comeback. \n \nIndia has emerged as the fastest-growing major economy in the world and is expected to be one of \nthe top three economic powers in the world over the next 10-15 years, backed by its robust democracy \nand strong partnerships. \n \n(Source: https://www.ibef.org/economy/indian-economy-overview) \n \nMARKET SIZE \nReal GDP or GDP at Constant (2011-12) Prices in the year 2023-24 is estimated at Rs. 173.82 lakh crores \n(US$ 2.08 trillion), against the First Revised Estimates (FRE) of GDP for the year 2022-23 of Rs. 160.71 \nlakh crores (US$ 1.92 trillion). The growth in real GDP during 2023-24 is estimated at 8.2% as compared \nto 7.0% in 2022-23. There are 113 unicorn startups in India, with a combined valuation of over US$ \n350 billion. As many as 14 tech startups are expected to list in 2024 Fintech sector poised to generate \nthe largest number of future unicorns in India. With India presently has the third-largest unicorn base \nin the world. The government is also focusing on renewable sources by achieving 40% of its energy \nfrom non-fossil sources by 2030. India is committed to achieving the country's ambition of Net Zero \nEmissions by 2070 through a five-pronged strategy, ‘Panchamrit’. Moreover, India ranked 3rd in the \nrenewable energy country attractive index. \n \nAccording to the McKinsey Global Institute, India needs to boost its rate of employment growth and \ncreate 90 million non-farm jobs between 2023 to 2030 in order to increase productivity and economic \ngrowth. The net employment rate needs to grow by 1.5% per annum from 2023 to 2030 to achieve 8-\n8.5% GDP growth between same time periods. India’s current account deficit (CAD) narrowed to 0.7% \nof GDP in FY24. The CAD stood at US$ 23.2 billion for the 2023-24 compared to US$ 67.0 billion or \n2.0% of GDP in the preceding year. This was largely due to decrease in merchandise trade deficit. \n \nExports fared remarkably well during the pandemic and aided recovery when all other growth engines \nwere losing steam in terms of their contribution to GDP. Going forward, the contribution of \nmerchandise exports may waver as several of India’s trade partners witness an economic slowdown. \nAccording to Minister of Commerce and Industry, Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution and \nTextiles Mr. Piyush Goyal, Indian exports are expected to reach US$ 1 trillion by 2030. \n \n(Source: https://www.ibef.org/economy/indian-economy-overview) \n \nRECENT DEVELOPMENTS \nIndia is primarily a domestic demand-driven economy, with consumption and investments \ncontributing to 70% of the economic activity. India ranked 5th in foreign direct investment inflows among the developed and \ndeveloping nations listed for the first quarter of 2022. \n \nIndia's economic story during the first half of the current financial year highlighted the unwavering \nsupport the government gave to its capital expenditure, which, in 2023-24, stood 37.4% higher than \nthe same period last year. In the budget of 2023-24, capital expenditure took lead by steeply increasing \nthe capital expenditure outlay by 37.4 % in BE 2023-24 to Rs.10 lakh crore (US$ 120.12 billion) over Rs. \n7.28 lakh crore (US$ 87.45 billion) in RE 2022-23. The ratio of revenue expenditure to capital outlay \nincreased by 1.2% in the current year, signalling a clear change in favour of higher-quality spending. \nStronger revenue generation because of improved tax compliance, increased profitability of the \ncompany, and increasing economic activity also contributed to rising capital spending levels. In Page 144 of 402 February 2024, the Finance Ministry announced the total expenditure in Interim 2024-25 estimated at \nRs. 47,65,768 crore (US$ 571.64 billion) of which total capital expenditure is Rs. 11,11,111 crore (US$ \n133.27 billion). \n \nSince India’s resilient growth despite the global pandemic, India's exports climbed at the second-\nhighest rate with a year-over-year (YoY) growth of 8.39% in merchandise exports and a 29.82% growth \nin service exports till April 2023. With a reduction in port congestion, supply networks are being \nrestored. The CPI-C inflation reduction from June 2022 already reflects the impact. In September 2023 \n(Provisional), CPI-C inflation was 5.02%, down from 7.01% in June 2022. With a proactive set of \nadministrative actions by the government, flexible monetary policy, and a softening of global \ncommodity prices and supply-chain bottlenecks, inflationary pressures in India look to be on the \ndecline overall. \n \nNote: Conversion rate used for January 2024 is Rs.1 = US$ 0.012 (Source: https://www.ibef.org/economy/indian-economy-overview) \n \nINDUSTRY OVERVIEW \n \nIntroduction India is the world’s largest spice producer. It is also the \nlargest consumer and exporter of spices. The production \nof different spices has been growing rapidly over the last \nfew years. Production in 2022-23 stood at 11.14 million \ntonnes compared to 11.12 million tonnes in 2021-22. \nDuring 2022-23, the export of spices from India stood at \nUS$ 3.73 billion from US$ 3.46 billion in 2021-22. During \n2021-22, the single largest spice exported from India \nwas chilli followed by spice oils and oleoresins, mint \nproducts, cumin, and turmeric. India produces about 75 of the 109 varieties which are listed by the International Organization for \nStandardization (ISO). The most produced and exported spices are pepper, cardamom, chilli, ginger, \nturmeric, coriander, cumin, celery, fennel, fenugreek, garlic, nutmeg & mace, curry powder, spice oils \nand oleoresins. Out of these spices, chilli, cumin, turmeric, ginger and coriander makeup about 76% of \nthe total production. \n \nThe largest spices-producing states in India are Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh, \nTelangana, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Assam, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu and \nKerala. \n \nExports Trend India is the largest exporter of spice and spice items. During \n2023-24 (until February 2024), the country exported spices \nworth US$ 3.67 billion. \n \nFor FY23, the country exported spices worth US$ 3.73 \nbillion. In July 2023, the exports of spices from India \nincreased to US$ 298.77 million from US$ 293.84 million in \nJune 2023. From 2016-17 to 2022-23, the total exported \nquantity from India grew at a CAGR of 5.85%. \n \nFor FY23, total volumes of chilli, cumin, turmeric, and ginger \nexports were 0.51, 0.18, 0.17 and 0.05 million tonnes. \n \nDuring 2022-23, the export of turmeric, coriander, garlic, curry powder, other spices such as \nasafoetida, tamarind, etc., expanded both in value and volume as compared to 2021-22. Page 145 of 402 Major Export Destinations \nIndia exported spices and spice products to 159 destinations worldwide as of 2023-24 (until February \n2024). The top destinations among them were China, the USA, Bangladesh, the UAE, Thailand, \nMalaysia, Indonesia, the UK, and Sri Lanka. These nine destinations comprised more than 70% of the \ntotal export earnings in 2023-24 (until February 2024). \n \nChina imported spice valued at US$ 725.76 million from India, while the USA imported spices worth \nUS$ 515.91 million. Bangladesh imported spices amounting to US$ 296.55 million. Additionally, the \nUAE imported spices worth US$ 214.76 million from India during 2023-24 (up to February 2024). \n \nChilli was the most exported spice from India. During 2022-23, China imported US$ 409.44 million in \nchilli. During the same period, the USA imported US$ 96.38 million in chilli. \n \nThe main products imported by the USA are celery, cumin, curry powder, fennel, fenugreek, garlic, \nchilli, and mint products. Source: https://www.ibef.org/exports/spice-industry-india  \n \nFMCG Industry  \n \nThe FMCG sector in India expanded due to consumer-driven growth and higher product prices, \nespecially for essential goods. FMCG sector provides employment to around 3 million people \naccounting for approximately 5% of the total factory employment in India. FMCG sales in the country \ngrew 7-9% by revenues in 2022-23. The key growth drivers for the sector include favourable \nGovernment initiatives & policies, a growing rural market and youth population, new branded \nproducts, and growth of e-commerce platforms. Resilience needs to be the key factor in the \nmanufacturing process, daily operations, retail and logistic channels, consumer insights and \ncommunication that will help FMCG companies to withstand the test of time and create more value \nfor consumers in the long run. India’s fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) sector grew 7.5% by \nvolumes in the April-June 2023 quarter, the highest in the last eight quarters, led by a revival in rural \nIndia and higher growth in modern trade. \n \nCRISIL forecasts 7-9% revenue growth for the FMCG sector in the current FY25, driven by increased \nvolume and rural demand recovery. Fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) sector is India’s fourth-\nlargest sector and has been expanding at a healthy rate over the years because of rising disposable \nincome, a rising youth population, and rising brand awareness among consumers. \n \nWith household and personal care accounting for 50% of FMCG sales in India, the industry is an \nimportant contributor to India’s GDP. \n \nIndia is a country that no FMCG player can afford to ignore due to its middle-class population which is \nlarger than the total population of USA. The Indian FMCG market continues to rise as more people \nstart to move up the economic ladder and the benefits of economic progress become accessible to the \npublic. More crucially, with a median age of just 27, India's population is becoming more consumerist \ndue to rising ambitions. This has been further aided by government initiatives to increase financial \ninclusion and establish social safety nets. \n \nGrowing awareness, easier access and changing lifestyles have been the key growth drivers for the \nsector. The urban segment (accounts for a revenue share of around 65%) is the largest contributor to \nthe overall revenue generated by the FMCG sector in India. However, in the last few years, the FMCG \nmarket has grown at a faster pace in rural India compared to urban India. Semi-urban and rural \nsegments are growing at a rapid pace and FMCG products account for 50% of the total rural spending. Page 146 of 402 Market Size Total revenue of FMCG market is expected to grow at a \nCAGR of 27.9% through 2021-27, reaching nearly US$ \n615.87 billion. In 2022, urban segment contributed 65% \nwhereas rural India contributed more than 35% to the \noverall annual FMCG sales. Good harvest, government \nspending expected to aid rural demand recovery in FY24. \nThe sector had grown 8.5% in revenues and 2.5% in \nvolumes last fiscal year. In the January-June period of \n2022, the sector witnessed value growth of about 8.4% on \naccount of price hikes due to inflationary pressures. In \nthird quarter of FY23, the FMCG sector clocked a value \ngrowth of 9.0% YoY — lower than the 9.2% YoY value \ngrowth seen in third quarter of FY22. \n \nAs per CRISIL, India's dairy industry is projected to experience a healthy revenue growth of 13-14% in \nFY25, driven by strong consumer demand and increased raw milk supply. \n \nAccording to NielsenIQ’s report, in 2024, the FMCG industry in India is expected to grow between 4.5-\n6.5%, owing to strength in the sector and Indian economy. \n \nIndian food processing market size reached US$ 307.2 billion in 2022 and is expected to reach US$ 470 \nbillion by 2028, exhibiting a growth rate (CAGR) of 9.5% during 2023-2028. \n \nThe Union government approved a new PLI scheme for the food processing sector, with a budget \noutlay of Rs. 109 billion (US$ 1.46 billion). Incentives under the scheme will be disbursed for six years \nto 2026-27. \n \nIndia’s FMCG sector has long been the top spender in the country’s advertising market, commanding \nnearly one third share Rs. 31,000 Crore (US$ 3.75 billion) in 2023 of the total advertising expenditure. \nIndia includes 780 million internet users, where an average Indian person spends around 7.3 hours per \nday on their smartphone, one of the highest in the world. Number of active internet users in India will \nincrease to 900 million by 2025 from 759 million in 2022. In 2022, India’s consumer spending was US$ \n2,049.57 billion. Indian villages, which contribute more than 35% to overall annual FMCG sales, are \ncrucial for overall revival of the sector. E-commerce now accounts for 17% of the overall FMCG \nconsumption among evolved buyers, who are affluent and make average spends of about Rs. 5,620 \n(US$ 677.11 million). \n \nThe Indian e-commerce market is anticipated to grow from US$ 83 billion in 2022 to US$ 185 billion in \n2026. By 2030, it is expected to have an annual gross merchandise value of US$ 350 billion. Fuelling e-\ncommerce growth, India is expected to have over 907 million internet users by 2023, which accounts \nfor 64% of the total population of the country. \n \nThe market has grown exponentially over the past five years due to the surge in internet and \nsmartphone users, improved policy reforms, and increase in disposable income. Mobile wallets, \nInternet banking, and debit/credit cards have become popular among customers for making \ntransactions on e-commerce platforms. The total value of digital transactions stood at US$ 300 billion \nin 2021 and is projected to reach US$ 1 trillion by 2026. \n \nThe India online grocery market size has been projected to grow from US$ 4,540 million in 2022 to \nUS$ 76,761.0 million by 2032, at a CAGR of 32.7% through 2032. \n \nFMCG giants such as Johnson & Johnson, Himalaya, Hindustan Unilever, ITC, Lakmé and other \ncompanies (that have dominated the Indian market for decades) are now competing with D2C-focused \nstart-ups such as Mamaearth, The Moms Co., Bey Bee, Azah, Nua and Pee Safe. One Nation One Ration Card: Introduction: The implementation of nation-wide portability of \nration cards through “One Nation One Ration Card \n(ONORC)” scheme, is an endeavour of the \nDepartment of Food & Public Distribution, \nGovernment of India to empower about 81 crore \nbeneficiaries. This plan has been launched under \nthe National Food Security Act (NFSA), 2013, \nwhich aims to ensure that anyone can take their \nshare of food grains from any district of any state \nof the country. Objective: \n• Through this facility, while a migrant beneficiary is able to get ration at the destination he or she is working in, his/her family back home is also allowed to get their part of the entitled ration to \nsupport itself. \n• This system provides flexibility to all NFSA beneficiaries to lift their foodgrains from any FPS (Fair Price Shop) of their choice. \n \nNeed: \n• Owing to the defined coverage of beneficiaries under the National Food Security Act (NFSA), 2013 in each State/UT, it was difficult for migrant beneficiaries to get a new ration card issued. Even if \nthey were able to get one issued, it introduced the ‘duplicity’ of ration cards/beneficiaries in the \ncountry’s Targeted Public Distribution System (TPDS), thereby potentially depriving many other \nleft-out and genuinely deserving beneficiaries from getting included under the fold of NFSA. \n• Now problems of getting a new ration card and duplicity of beneficiaries are solved and the government is enabling the inclusion of all genuine beneficiaries of State/UT through portability \nunder the fold of NFSA. \n• This mechanism can plug the leakage/diversion of un-lifted foodgrains in FPSs, as they can now be lifted by their rightful beneficiaries through portability and gets adjusted between States/UTs, \nthereby minimizing the chances of diversion. \n \nTechnology Driven Scheme: \n• The scheme enables migrant beneficiaries to get their food grains from a FPS of their choice in most parts of the country, by using their same/existing ration card with biometric authentication of \nidentity on an Electronic Point of Sale (e-PoS) device \n• This system of portability is being implemented in all states and Union Territories where the system is being built upon the strong foundations of computerized Targeted Public Distribution System Page 149 of 402 (TPDS) operations. This includes the installed infrastructure of ePoS devices at the FPS and seeding \nof beneficiaries’ Aadhaar numbers with their ration cards. \n• A copy of either the Ration card or Aadhar card is acceptable. Beneficiaries can simply tell either their Ration card number or seeded Aadhar number to the FPS dealer to receive their ration. \n• The Department of Food & Public Distribution, in association with NIC, has launched a Mobile Application “MERA RATION” for the benefit of NFSA beneficiaries, particularly migrant \nbeneficiaries, to take maximum advantage of the One Nation One Ration Card (ONORC) plan. \n• Currently, the ‘Mera Ration’ mobile application is available in 12 languages. \n• On it, other information like registration of migrants, details of available entitlements, location of nearby FPS, information on past transactions, eligibility criteria, list of ONORC states, etc. can be \naccessed. \n \nOutcomes of ONORC: \n• The broad-based reform of portability covering nearly 81 Crore NFSA beneficiaries in all States/UTs is being achieved with minimal outlay of just Rs. 127 Crore, over a period of 4 years. \n• This is a one-of- its-kind Citizen-Centric initiative in the country, swiftly implemented in34 States/UTs in a short-span of time (as of August 2021), after being sanctioned in 2018-19 and \nimplemented from August 2019. \n• ONORC was helpful to NFSA beneficiaries in availing food grains from any location during COVID pandemic/ lockdown period. \n• During the period between 01-April-2020 and 30-September-2021, about 24.32 crore portability transactions under NFSA were carried out across States/UTs, benefiting large number of NFSA \nbeneficiaries, mostly migrants, at the Fair Price Shops (FPS) near to their location of \nwork/temporary stay. \n• Under the NSFA, almost 23.6 crore Ration cards have been digitized to cover 80 crore beneficiaries of all states/UTs. \n• Almost 93.1 % Ration Cards and 90.1 % beneficiaries are Aadhar-seeded at a national level. \n• Online allocation orders for food grains for all FPS has been implemented in all states/UTs, besides Chandigarh and Puducherry. \n• Supply Chain Management of food grains is computerized in 31 States/UTs for online management of stocks in godowns and its in-and-out movement. \n \n(Source: https://pib.gov.in/factsheetdetails.aspx?id=148563) 2. Mid-day meal The National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education (NP-NSPE) which is popularly \nknown as the Mid-day Meal Scheme was launched by the Government of India in 1995. NP-NSPE \nstates that it aims to address “classroom hunger” and encourage poor children, belonging to \ndisadvantaged sections, to attend school regularly and help them concentrate on classroom \nactivities. The mid-day meal programme is a multi-faceted programme of the Government of India \nthat, among other things, also seeks to address issues of food security, lack of nutrition and access \nto education on a nationwide scale. The Scheme is the world’s largest school feeding programme \nreaching out to about 12 crore children in over 12.65 lakh schools/EGS centres across the country. \n \nThe level of malnutrition is of great concern in India with over 40% of children being classified as \nundernourished. Anaemia affects over 3/4th of the school children due to low intake of iron and \nfolic acid. The reasons for such high levels of malnutrition and anaemia are complex. They include \npoverty, gender inequity, specific dietary patterns and recurrent illness, all these acting in \nconjunction. \n \nSchool feeding programmes are popular in the developing world and beyond, not only because of \ntheir educational but also for their nutritional benefits. Mid-day meal acts as a regular source of \n“supplementary nutrition” for children, which facilitates their healthy growth. To achieve the \nobjectives of the Scheme, the guidelines prescribe specific nutritional content in the mid-day meal Page 150 of 402 Sl.No. Item \nPrimary \nUpper Primary 1 \nCalories 450 calories 700 calories 2 \nProtein 12gms. \n20gms. Recently (September \n2021), the Government renamed this scheme to Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman or ‘PM \nPOSHAN’. However, under the new scheme ‘PM POSHAN’, 24 lakhs of children studying in pre-primary \nschools who are already covered under the Integrated Child Development Services will get food \nunder the MDM scheme. \n \nThe PM Poshan will be operational initially for 5 years (2021-22 to 2025-26). Here, the Central \nGovernment will take responsibility for Rs. 54,061 crores of the total approximate expenditure \nof Rs. 1.3 lakh crore. SPICED Scheme Spices Board, under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, has launched a transformative scheme \naimed at significantly enhancing the export of spices and value- added spice products as well as \nimproving the productivity of cardamoms and upgrading the post-harvest quality of spices across \nIndia for export. \n \nVarious programmes rolled out under the scheme 'Sustainability in Spice Sector through \nProgressive, Innovative and Collaborative Interventions for Export Development (SPICED)' will be \nimplemented during the remaining period of the 15th Finance Commission cycle, till FY 2025-26, \nwith a total approved outlay of Rs. 422.30 crore. \n \nThe SPICED scheme is expected to facilitate value addition and to drive innovation and \nsustainability in the spice sector by introducing new sub-components/programs like the Mission \nValue Addition, Mission Clean and Safe Spices, promotion of GI spices, support for \nentrepreneurship through Spice Incubation Centres, etc. The scheme gives thrust on farmers \ngroups / FPOS / Farmers Clusters identified under ODOP and DEH, SC/ST community, Exporters \nfrom NE region, and SMEs. \n \nThe programs under the components such as Improving the productivity of cardamom and post-\nharvest quality upgradation of spices are specifically designed to empower farmer groups, including \nFarmer Producer Organizations (FPOs), Farmer Producer Companies (FPCs), and Self-Help Groups \n(SHGs) in key spice-growing regions. These groups will be prioritized for post-harvest improvement Page 151 of 402 of spices, with targeted assistance provided to enhance creation of an exportable surplus of spices, \nin compliance with the applicable food safety and quality standards. \n \nThe programs for cardamom focuses on increasing the productivity of both small and large \ncardamom through replanting efforts, production of quality planting material, developing water \nsources, adopting micro-irrigation systems, etc. Additionally, there are programs to promote \nweather-based insurance to protect farmers' interests. Similarly, post-harvest quality improvement \nof spices is addressed through programs such as Mission Clean and Safe Spices through post-\nharvest improvement by groups in identified clusters, promotion of sustainable production and \ncertification systems and extension advisory services. \n \nIn a move to further strengthen value addition in the spice sector, the Board is introducing \ncomponents such as Enhancing capacities for market expansion, Trade promotion, and \nTechnological interventions. These components offer support for technological and infrastructural \ninterventions for processing and value addition of spices, setting up or upgradation of in-house \nlaboratories, product development, market development & branding, and implementation of food \nsafety & quality assurance mechanisms, all aimed at improving India's global competitiveness in \nthe spice sector. To strengthen trade promotion efforts, programs have been designed to support \nparticipation in international fairs, buyer-seller meets, and for promotion of GI-tagged spices in \ndomestic and global markets. Moreover, the Board provides financial assistance for Spice \nIncubation Centres to foster innovation and entrepreneurship, providing a platform for startups, \nSMEs, and entrepreneurs to develop new products and processes within the spices sector. While \nexporters with a valid Certificate of Registration as Exporter of Spices (CRES) are eligible for \nassistance under these programs, preference will be given to first-time applicants, Small and \nMedium Enterprises (SMEs), etc. \n \nReceipt and processing of applications under the scheme SPICED are online. Spices Board's officials \nshall support the growers in submitting the application through the online portal, if required. \nScheme activities will be geo-tagged and fund availability, status of applications under different \ncomponents, list of beneficiaries, etc. will be published in the Board's website for better \ntransparency. \n \nThis multifaceted scheme underscores the Board's commitment to bolstering India's spice industry, \nimproving farmer livelihoods, and solidifying India's position as a global leader in spice production, \nprocessing, and export. \n \nThe online submission of application for availing assistance under various programs of the SPICED \nscheme will commence from 20th September 2024. For more information and assistance, \ninterested stakeholders may visit the Board's website www.indianspices.com or contact the \nnearest Spices Board office. \n \n(Source: https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2051699) Export Development and Promotion of Spices \nThis initiative by the Spices Board of India aims to support the exporter to adopt high-tech \nprocessing technologies and upgrade the existing level of technology for the development of \nindustry and to meet the changing food safety standards of the importing countries. The initiative \nprovides benefits of infrastructure development, promoting Indian spice brands abroad, setting up \ninfrastructure in the major spice growing centres, promoting organic spices and special \nprogrammes for north-eastern entrepreneurs. \n \nSetting up and maintenance of infrastructure for common processing (Spices Parks) \nSpices Board has launched eight crop-specific Spices Parks in key production/market centres \nintending to facilitate the farmers to get an improved price realization and wider reach for their \nproduce. The purpose of the park is to have an integrated operation for cultivation, post-harvesting, \nprocessing, value-addition, packaging and storage of spices and spice products. The common \nprocessing facilities for cleaning, grading, packing, and steam sterilization will help the farmers to \nenhance the quality of the produce, resulting in better price realization. Page 152 of 402 Spice Complex Sikkim \nSpices Board submitted a project proposal to the state’s cell for setting up a Spice Complex in Sikkim \nseeking financial assistance for facilitating and demonstrating common processing and value \naddition in spices to help farmers and other stakeholders in the state. \n \n(Source: https://www.ibef.org/exports/spice-industry-india) Page 153 of 402 OUR BUSINESS \n \nSome of the information in the following discussion, including information with respect to our plans \nand strategies, contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. In addition to our \nspices offerings, we are also engaged in trading and distribution of Grocery Products such as Black Salt, \nRock Salt, Rice, Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dried Fenugreek) etc. and a diverse range of Herbs and seasonings \nwhich includes Organo, Peri Peri, Chilli Flakes, Mixed Herbs, Onion Flakes, Tomato Powder etc. \n \nOur company sources the raw material of spices directly from mandis and suppliers situated across \nIndia and process and manufacture them at our manufacturing facility situated at Khasra No. 06/1067 \nManpura Road, Jatawali, near Delhi bypass, Tehsil – Chomu, Jaipur, Rajasthan. Our manufacturing \nfacility is equipped with plant and machinery to facilitate efficient production process of cleaning, \ndrying, grading, grinding and packaging. \n \nOur Company operates across multiple sales channels, catering to both Business to Business (“B2B”) \nand Direct to Consumer (“D2C”) markets. In the B2B space, we serve customers through General Trade \n(wholesalers and distributors across India), Modern Trade (supermarkets and big retail chains), and \nQuick Commerce Platforms (through quick commerce apps), ensuring our products are easily \naccessible to consumers. We are also involved in Private Labelling, HoReCa (Hotel, Restaurant, and \nCatering) sales, and Export Sales. By using our products these businesses can create custom spice \nblends for their own branded lines, allowing them to provide good quality ingredients and tailored \nsolutions to meet the unique needs of professional kitchens \n \nAdditionally, we have a Direct-to-Consumer (“D2C”) presence via our website, offering seamless online \nshopping experience for customers to directly purchase our products. For further details regarding \nrevenue generated through these multiple sales channels, please refer to “Our Business – Revenue \nModel” on page 157-158. L. Dangayach and Company, \nChartered Accountants \n \nREVENUE MODEL \n \nWe operate on a multiple sales channel model the details of which are as under: \n \n1. Business to Business (B2B): B2B sales involve selling our products to other businesses, which may use them or sell them to their own customers. The different type of revenue model in B2B sales is \nas under: \n \n• \nGeneral Trade: General or traditional trade can be defined as the trade conducted by local stores \nor shops that cater to the needs of local consumers. These typically include wholesalers and \ndistributors. They work to satisfy the typical requirements of the end consumer and deal with \nsmall amounts of products. Our company works with a network of approximately 389 wholesalers \ndistributors across India as on September 30, 2025. These distributors play a key role in marketing \nour products through their own sales teams, while our company provides additional support via \nour marketing personnel. Our company sell our products to these distributors, who then resells \nour products to local markets and small retailers. This model generates revenue through \nwholesale bulk sales, with distributors marking up the products for retail. \n \n• \nModern Trade: Modern trade is a more structured and sophisticated system of chain retailers like \nmini-markets, supermarkets, and hypermarkets. They are found only in cities and are typically \ncorporate-owned. Our company focuses on establishing relationships with large retail chains and \nsupermarket giants like D-Mart, Metro Cash & Carry, Reliance Retail and Dealshare. Our company \ndirectly sells to these retail chains, where it places products for consumer purchase. A dedicated \nteam of 121 sales and marketing professionals is employed to work specifically within these \nstores, driving visibility, sales, and ensuring the products are well-presented to consumers. In this \nmodel, revenue is earned by selling products at wholesale prices to these large retailers, while \nthe retailers mark up prices for consumer sales. Additionally, in-store promotions and bulk \ndiscounts may be utilized to increase sales volumes. • \nQuick Commerce: Quick Commerce enables us to tap into the growing trend of on-demand \ndelivery through platforms such as Flipkart Minutes, Swiggy Instamart, Blinkit and Zepto. In this \nmodel, we supply products to the Distribution Centres (DCs) of these platforms, from where \ncustomer orders are efficiently fulfilled and delivered. We enter into contracts with these \nplatforms for product listings and agrees on pricing terms. Sales are driven through commission-\nbased models, where platforms charge a fee per transaction. This model enables us to reach tech-\nsavvy urban consumers looking who prioritize speed and convenience, further expanding our \nbrand presence in the fast-growing digital retail space. • \nPrivate Labelling: This refers to a business arrangement where we manufacture and process \nproducts but package them under our customers brand names. This allows our customers to offer \ngood-quality spices without investing in production. We provide flexible packaging options like \npouches, jars, and bulk packs, with customizable minimum order quantities to accommodate \nbusinesses of all sizes. This model helps us to reach new markets, increase sales volume through Page 157 of 402 larger orders, and build long-term client partnerships. It also allows us to focus on our strength \nof producing and processing good quality spices, while our clients manage marketing and \ndistribution, ensuring steady growth and market adaptability. \n \n• \nHORECA Sales: The HoReCa sector includes Hotels, Restaurants, and Catering, where we provide \nbulk spice solutions tailored to chefs and foodservice providers. We begin by understanding our \nclients' specific needs, whether custom spice blends or bulk packaging, and ensure good quality, \nfresh products with consistent flavour. Our packaging is designed for bulk use, and we focus on \ntimely deliveries. Engaging in the HoReCa business allows for larger sales volumes, stable \nrevenue, increased brand exposure, and product innovation, helping us meet emerging culinary \ntrends and build long-term client relationships. \n \n• \nExports sales: Under this revenue model our company exports its products to various \ninternational distributors and importers situated in multiple countries across the globe such as \nMongolia, Nepal, Oman, Saudi Arabia, UAE. Private labelling also helps us to strengthen our \nexport presence by tailoring products to suit international markets, opening up new global \nopportunities Our company generates revenue by selling bulk orders to these international \ncustomers. 2. Direct to Consumer (D2C): This means a business model where a company sells products or services directly to end-users (consumers) without intermediaries. Our company is involved in D2C sales \nthrough the following: \n \n• \nWebsite Sales: Our company have a dedicated website which allows the customers to directly \nmake a purchase, pay for them and can get them delivered at their preferred locations. This allows \nus to increase our profit margins as customers can directly buy from us thus eliminating the \nmiddlemen. L. Dangayach and Company, \nChartered Accountants \n \nOUR COMPETITIVE STRENGTHS \n \n1. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) Our company is dedicated to providing good quality natural spices while supporting sustainable \nand ethical practices in the sourcing and production of our products. One of the major challenges \nto achieving these quality standards is the widespread overuse of chemical pesticides by farmers, \ndue to lack of awareness and knowledge. While pesticides are intended to boost crop production, \ntheir excessive use can result in harmful residues in food, soil degradation, and adverse effects on \nhuman health, wildlife, and the broader environment. Page 158 of 402 To mitigate these risks, we have adopted Integrated Pest \nManagement (IPM). Integrated Pest Management (IPM) is \na sustainable and environmentally conscious approach to \ncontrol pests that minimizes the need for chemical \npesticides, benefiting both human health and the \nenvironment. The core principle of IPM is prevention, \nemploying natural methods to reduce pest damage while \nmaintaining crop health.  \n \nThrough IPM, our company aims to minimize the use of \nchemical pesticides and promote the use of natural \nmethods in conventional farming. This approach provides \na balanced and safe solution that not only preserves the \nenvironment but also ensures the well-being of farmers \nand supports the production of healthy crops. \n \n2. Experienced management team and promoters with qualified workforce. We are led by an experienced management team that has the expertise and vision to manage and \noutgrow our business. Our management team’s collective experience and forecasting capabilities \nenables us to understand and anticipate future market trends, manage our business operations \nand growth, leverage customer relationships, and respond to changes in customer preferences. \nOur management team continues to focus on production, marketing and new growth areas in their \nrespective product segments.  \n \nWe leverage the understanding and the experience of our senior management in successfully \nmanaging our operations and growth. We continuously strengthen our expertise by providing in-\nhouse training to our workforce, in order to diversify and update their skill sets and keep them \nupdated with the latest changes in technologies and processes. The faith of the management in the \nworkforce and their dedicated performance has enabled us to build a niche player in the market. \nThe experience of our senior management team has resulted in streamlined processing, improved \nproduct quality and increased profitability, which give us a competitive edge over our competitors.  \n \nOur Company is managed by our Promoters and Directors, Mr. Ramawtar Agarwal, Mrs. Mamta \nDevi Agarwal and Mr. Vithal Agarwal. \n \nRAMAWTAR AGARWAL: He has been associated with our Company since incorporation. He has \nover 30 years of experience in the spices industry. He has worked closely with the purchase team \nto continuously innovate and improve the quality of our spice products. He is responsible for \nmonitoring financial performance and ensuring the efficient use of resources to support business \ngrowth. MAMTA DEVI AGARWAL: She has the experience of over 17 years in the spice industry. She is \nresponsible for overseeing the production of blended spices and making sure the quality is \nmaintained at every step. She also helps build the brand by creating new product recipes that \nimprove the customer experience and make it easier for them to use our products. \n \nVITHAL AGARWAL: He joined our Company in December 2017 and has over 7 years of experience \nof the Spice Industry in our Company. He is involved in creating and executing business plans, \nmanaging key client relationships, leading the team to achieve company goals and handling \nmarketing to promote the brand and attract customers.  \n \nFor further information regarding the Directors, Key Managerial Personnel and Senior Management \nof our company, please refer to “Our Management – Brief Profile of our Directors” and “Brief \nProfile of our Key Managerial Personnel and Senior Management Personnel” on pages 195-196 \nand 207-209 respectively. Page 159 of 402 The knowledge and experience of our promoters, along with senior management, team of skilled \npersonnel, provides us with a significant competitive advantage as we seek to expand our \nproduction capacities and product portfolio, in our existing markets as well as new markets. Their \nleadership and vision have helped our Company grow and reach a position where we are today.   \n \n3. Established manufacturing facility and integrated production with cost efficiencies. We have our Manufacturing Unit located at Khasra No. 06/1067 Manpura Road, Jatawali, near Delhi \nbypass, Tehsil – Chomu, Jaipur, Rajasthan. Our manufacturing unit is equipped and capable of \ncarrying out end-to-end manufacturing and processing activities. Our years of experience in precision engineering, strategically located production facilities, and \nfocus on design, coupled with technologically advanced and cost-competitive manufacturing \ntechnology processes have enabled us to meet our customers’ and stringent regulatory \nrequirements.  \n \nWe have full-service capabilities across the product cycle including product development, raw \nmaterial sourcing, mixing of ingredients according to different recipes, testing and measurement \ninfrastructure, all under one roof to meet the requirement of our global customers. The entire \nprocess is carried out under one roof. Our dynamic setup not only gives us better control over \nquality but also benefits us with cost advantages compared to our competitors who resort to job \nwork for various activities in the complete manufacturing process. Our engineering expertise and \ntechnology-driven manufacturing processes have enabled us to deliver our products and provide \ntimely solution to our customers in accordance with their designs and specifications, in a cost-\neffective manner without compromising on quality. For further information regarding the \nmanufacturing units of our Company, please refer to “Our Business - Capacity Utilization” on page \n171.   \n \n4. Diversified product portfolio Our understanding of the consumer’s culinary taste complements our product development \ncapabilities, which has allowed us to develop a comprehensive portfolio of a variety of spices and \nother products. Our product portfolio comprises various types products which includes Ground \nSpices like Chilli Powder, Turmeric Powder, and Coriander Powder, as well as Blended Spices such \nas Sambar Masala, Garam Masala, Pav Bhaji Masala, and Chole Masala. We also offer Whole Spices \nincluding Cumin Seeds, Cloves, and Black Pepper etc. and the grocery products such as Black Salt, \nRock Salt, Rice Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dry fenugreek), Sabudana Soyavadi Moong Mangodi and Mishri \nDana. For further details regarding our product offerings, please refer to “Our Business – Our Page 160 of 402 Products” on page 164. \n \nThese products are manufactured in our owned manufacturing unit and comply with stringent \nquality standards and the products are being available in different packaging sizes. Our diversified \nproduct portfolio enables us to cater to a wide range of taste preferences and consumer segments.  \n \n5. Strong and consistent financial performance We have demonstrated consistent growth in terms of revenues and profitability. The recognition \nof our product quality has enabled us to penetrate the Indian spices and masala market and cater \nto new customers in addition to our existing customer network. The introduction of new revenue \nstreams and new products has also helped our company to increase its market and revenue. \nIncreased acceptance of newer product categories due to improved designs and efficient pricing \nhas further established our reputation. Long and strong relationship with customers and dealers and efficient supply chain management. Particulars \nFor the period ended September 30, 2025 We have been in the business of manufacturing and processing of the spices since the last decade \nand have successfully developed and supplied quality products to our customers. Our \nunderstanding of the Indian taste palate complements our product development capabilities and \nhas allowed us to develop a long-standing relationship with our customers. Our past experience in \nthe supply of our products, ability to meet specific taste requirements of our customers, reputation \nfor quality of our products and the competitiveness of our offerings has enabled us to establish and \nmaintain relationships with our customers. Our sales & distribution network is aided by our in-\nhouse sales and marketing team, which liaise with our customers on a regular basis for customer \ninputs, market demands as well as the positioning of our products vis-à-vis products of our \ncompetitors. Owing to our strong customer relationships we have developed a network of 432 \nwholesalers and distributors as on March 31, 2025. Our existing relationship with our customers \nrepresents a competitive advantage in gaining new customers and increasing our business. \n \nOUR BUSINESS STRATEGIES  \n \nOur focus is on expanding our operations in existing as well as new markets. Our Company \nmeticulously engineered with a cutting-edge technology and aptly supported by an efficient team of \ntrained personnel who marketed the product in unexplored markets, had soon positioned itself as one \nof the popular brands in Indian market and paved the way for acquiring bigger share of this competitive \nmarket. We intend to provide good quality products to our customers and grow our business by \nleveraging our strengths and implementing the following strategies: ➢ Continued focus on diversified business model: Our company operates under a diverse revenue model that includes General Trade, Modern Trade, \nHORECA sales, Private Labelling, Quick Commerce, Exports, and Website sales. Until FY23, our \nprimary focus was on general trade, which contributed over 90% of our total revenue. However, in \nFY24, we shifted our strategy to place more emphasis on modern trade, resulting in a notable Page 161 of 402 increase in sales within this segment from ₹ 29.25 Lakhs in FY23 to ₹ 3,342 Lakhs in FY24. Further \nin FY 25 the sale from Morden Trade is increased to ₹ 5,524.92 Lakhs. \n \nAs part of this change in diversified business model, our company will continue to focus on \nexpanding its reach within the modern trade sector. We are working towards broadening our \npresence across key modern trade players, including DMart, Reliance Retail, Dealshare, and Metro \nCash and Carry, with plans for a pan-India reach. This move is aimed at further increasing our \nmarket footprint and driving revenue growth. \n \nAdditionally, we have made strategic efforts to strengthen our presence on quick commerce \nplatforms, with partnerships established with leading players such as Swiggy Instamart, Zepto, \nFlipkart Minutes, and BlinkIT. This will help us to increase our market presence and tap into the \ngrowing quick commerce industry in India. \n \nIn line with our expansion across these segments, we are also increasing our production capacity \nto meet the growing demand in the private labelling segment. This capacity enhancement will \nenable us to better serve our clients and ensure a steady supply of products as demand continues \nto rise. \n \n➢ Increase in advertisement and marketing activities Our company is committed to expanding its market presence and enhancing brand recognition for \nour products, particularly our brand \"SHYAM\".
