Manufacturing Process of Blended Spices Details of the Manufacturing process is as under: \n \n❖ Raw Material Procurement and Quality Control: The process begins with the sourcing of good quality of raw spices from reliable suppliers. These raw spices can include whole spices like pepper, \ncumin, coriander, turmeric, and cardamom, as well as ground spices. Upon receiving the raw spices \nat the manufacturing unit, they undergo an inspection process. This includes checking for quality, \nfreshness, foreign matter, and any signs of contamination or damage. Spices that meet the quality \nstandards are then accepted for further processing. It’s essential to ensure the raw materials are \nfresh, free from contamination, and meet industry standards. If the materials pass Quality Control \n(QC), they are transferred to Raw Material Storage. If they fail QC, they are returned to the supplier. \n \n❖ Cleaning and Sorting: Before processing, raw spices must be cleaned and sorted. This is done to remove dirt, stones, and other foreign impurities. Various cleaning methods may be used, such as \nsieving or air blowing. Sorting is performed manually or using automated systems to ensure \nuniformity in size and quality. After cleaning, the raw materials are mixed in precise proportions. \nThis ensures consistency in the product, as the components need to be uniformly blended to \nachieve the desired quality and characteristics. \n \n❖ Grinding and Cooling: The mixed raw materials are ground using specific equipment to achieve the desired particle size or consistency. Page 165 of 402 After grinding, the material is cooled to prevent it from overheating and to stabilize its texture. \nCooling is essential to ensure that the material doesn’t degrade or change properties, which could \naffect the final product quality. ❖ Metal Detection and Inspection: The processed material is passed through a metal detector to ensure that there are no metal contaminants. This step is essential for ensuring the safety and \nquality of the product. \n \nAfter that a thorough inspection is carried out to check the material for any defects, inconsistencies, \nor issues that could compromise the final product’s quality. \n \n❖ Storage of Grounded and Cooled Materials: Once the materials have passed inspection, they are stored in a designated area under controlled conditions to preserve their quality. \n \nFor materials that are sensitive to temperature or require refrigeration, they are transferred to \noutsourced cold storage. \n \n❖ Packaging: The final product (either whole or ground spices) is then packaged into appropriate containers, such as sachets, jars, bottles, or bulk packaging. Packaging is done in a hygienic \nenvironment to prevent contamination and preserve the spices’ aroma and flavor. Some packaging \nunits also use vacuum sealing or nitrogen flushing to extend shelf life. \n \n❖ Labeling and Quality Control: Before the packaged spices are released to the market, they undergo rigorous quality control checks. This includes testing for: \n• Purity \n• Expiration Date \n• Date of Manufacturing \n• Color \n• Aroma \n• Taste \n• Pesticide residues etc. Proper labeling is done on each product with details such as the name, ingredients, manufacturer’s \ninformation, expiry date, and other legal information. \n \n❖ Storage and Distribution: The final packaged spices are stored in a cool, dry, and dark environment to preserve their flavor and aroma. After storage, they are ready to be distributed to distributors,  \nwholesalers, or directly to customers. \n \nB. Manufacturing Process of Whole Spices: Page 166 of 402 ❖ Raw Material Receiving and Inspection: The process begins with the receipt of raw materials, followed by a thorough quality inspection. If the materials meet quality standards, they are \ntransferred to raw material storage. Any materials that fail quality control (QC) are returned to the \nsupplier.  \n \n❖ Two-Step Cleaning Process for Raw Materials: To ensure quality and purity the raw materials undergo a Two - Step cleaning process to remove dust and impurities. The process are as follows: \n \nCleaning I: - Initial cleaning of the raw material to remove dust and impurities. \nCleaning II: - Secondary cleaning process to refine the material and meet stringent quality \nstandards. \n \n❖ Packaging, Date/Batch Inspection, and Dispatch: Once processed, the final product is carefully packaged in appropriate containers, ensuring proper sealing, labelling, and compliance with safety \nand quality standards. Before dispatch, a final inspection is conducted to verify batch numbers, \nmanufacturing dates, and other essential details for traceability and compliance. The packaged \ngoods are then moved to Finished Goods (FG) storage for inventory management. \n \n❖ Dispatch of Finished Goods: After passing the final inspection and packaging stage, the products are prepared for dispatch to customers, distributors or wholesalers ensuring timely delivery and \nproduct integrity. \n \nC. Manufacturing Process of Grocery Items: ❖ Receiving and Inspection of Grocery Items: The process begins with receiving grocery items from suppliers. Each shipment undergoes a thorough inspection to verify quality, quantity, and overall \ncondition. This check ensures that products are free from damage, spoilage, or contamination and \nmeet safety standards. Approved items are moved to storage, while non-compliant products are \neither returned to the supplier or handled according to company policies. \n \n \n❖ Cleaning and Sorting of Grocery Items: Certain grocery items require cleaning before they are made available for sale. This step involves removing the dirt and other impurities from the \nproducts. Following cleaning, products are sorted based on type, size, and quality, ensuring proper \norganization and presentation. \n \n❖ Packaging of Grocery Item: Grocery items are then packaged according to product-specific requirements. The packaging is designed to maintain freshness, protect against contamination, and \nprovide essential details such as expiration dates, nutritional information, and ingredient lists. \nProper labelling ensures compliance with food safety regulations, and all packages are securely Page 167 of 402 sealed to preserve product integrity. \n \n❖ Finished Goods Storage and Dispatch: After packaging, products are stored in the finished goods storage area. Upon receiving orders, items are carefully picked, packed, and dispatched to their \nfinal destination, ensuring timely and efficient delivery. \n \nD. MANUFACTURING PROCESS OF GROUND SPICES: ➢ Chilli Powder: Details of the processing process is as under: \n \n❖ Raw Material Procurement and Quality Control: The process begins with the sourcing of good quality dried chillies from reliable suppliers. Upon arriving at the manufacturing unit, the dried \nchillies undergo an quality inspection to check for freshness, color, pungency, moisture content, \nand any signs of contamination or damage. Only chillies that meet industry standards are accepted \nfor further processing, while non-compliant batches are rejected. Approved dried chillies are then \ntransferred to raw material storage. \n \n❖ Cleaning and Sorting:  Before processing, the stemps of all the dried chillies are removed in order to preserve the colour as well as maintain the spiceness. Post this stemp removal process, the dried \nchillies are thoroughly cleaned and sorted to remove dirt, cut stems, stones, and other foreign \nimpurities. Various cleaning methods, such as sieving or air blowing are used to ensure purity. After \ncleaning, the dried chillies are sorted manually or using automated systems to separate them based \non size, color, and quality. This ensures consistency in the final chilli powder. \n \n❖ Grinding and Refining of Raw Material: After cleaning, the chillies undergo a three-step grinding process to achieve the desired fine powder consistency: Grinder 1: Initial size reduction of dried chilies. \nGrinder 2: Further refinement to break down coarse particles.  \nGrinding 3: Final grinding to achieve uniform fine chili power. \n \n❖ Oil Addition and Mixing: After the grinding process, the edible oil is received from the suppliers and undergoes a quality inspection to ensure it meets the required standards. Once approved, the \noil is mixed thoroughly with the ground chili powder to achieve the desired consistency and quality. Page 168 of 402 ❖ Final Processing of Raw Material: After the oil mixing stage, the chilli powder undergoes a vibration process to eliminate air pockets and ensure uniform distribution of the material. This step enhances \nproduct consistency and quality. Next, the powder is further refined using a super mill, which \nimproves texture, smoothness, and overall finish. To ensure safety and purity, the powder then \nundergoes magnetic separation, effectively removing any potential metallic contaminants. This \nfinal step ensures that the chilli powder meets the quality and safety standards before packaging. \n \n❖ Storage of Grounded and Cooled Materials: Once processed, the chilli powder is stored in a designated area under controlled conditions to maintain its color, aroma, and pungency. For \ntemperature-sensitive batches, the powder is transferred to outsourced cold storage facilities. \n \n❖ Packaging: The chilli powder is then packaged in various formats, such as sachets, jars, bottles, or bulk packs, depending on market requirements. Packaging is done in a hygienic environment to \nprevent contamination and preserve the product’s freshness. Advanced techniques like vacuum \nsealing or nitrogen flushing may be used to extend shelf life. \n \n❖ Labeling and Quality Control: Before market release, the packaged chili powder undergos rigorous quality control checks. This includes testing for: • \nPurity \n• \nManufacturing and Expiration Dates \n• \nColor and texture \n• \nAroma and taste \n• \nPesticide residues etc. \n \nEach package is then labeled with essential details such as the name, ingredients, manufacturer’s \ninformation, expiry date, and other legal information. \n \n❖ Storage and Distribution: The final packaged chilli powder is stored in a cool, dry, and dark environment to maintain its vibrant color and spicy flavor. Once ready, it is distributed to \nwholesalers, distributors and customers, ensuring timely delivery and optimal product quality. \n \n➢ Coriander Powder: Page 169 of 402 Details of the processing Process is as under: \n \n❖ Raw Material Procurement and Quality Control: The process begins with the receipt of Raw Materials (RM) i.e. coriander seeds, followed by Inspection to assess their quality. If they meet the \nQuality Control (QC) standards, they are transferred to Raw Material Storage. If they fail QC, they \nare returned to the supplier. \n \n❖ Cleaning Process for Raw Materials: To ensure the good quality, the coriander seeds undergo a three-step cleaning process: • \nInitial Cleaning: Removal of loose dust and debris. • \nInspection & Contaminant Removal: Larger impurities and foreign materials are eliminated. • \nFinal Cleaning: Specialized techniques are used to achieve the desired purity and cleanliness. \n \n❖ Grinding and Refinement of Raw Materials: Once cleaned, the coriander seeds are transferred to Grinder 1, where they are ground using Hammer Mill 1. The semi-processed material is then further \nrefined in Grinder 2 with Hammer Mill 2 for finer grinding. After this stage, the powdered coriander \npasses through a Vibro Sifter, ensuring uniform texture and quality. \n \n❖ Metal Detection, Storage, and Transfer to Semi-Finished Goods: To maintain product safety, the coriander powder undergoes metal detection to identify and remove any contaminants. The \nrefined powder is then stored in Ground Storage and Cold Storage to preserve freshness. From \nground storage, it is transferred to the Semi-Finished Goods section for further processing. \n \n❖ Packaging, Storage, and Final Dispatch of Finished Goods: In the final stage, the coriander powder is packed in appropriate packaging materials to maintain its quality and shelf life. The packaged \ngoods are then moved to Storage and eventually Dispatch to their final destination. ➢ Turmeric Powder: Details of the processing Process is as under: ❖ Raw Material Handling and Quality Control: The process begins with the receipt of Raw Materials (RM) i.e. dried turmeric rhizomes, followed by Inspection to assess their quality. If they Page 170 of 402 meet the Quality Control (QC) standards, they are transferred to Raw Material Storage. If they \nfail QC, they are returned to the supplier or inn cases of quality issues Pillage and Destruction \nprocesses are implemented for the non-compliant materials. \n \n❖ Two-Step Cleaning Process for Raw Materials: To ensure purity and quality, the dried turmeric rhizomes undergo a two-step cleaning process: • \nCleaning 1: Removal of dust, sand, and other loose particles. \n• \nCleaning 2: Manual inspection to eliminate any remaining impurities or foreign materials. \n \n❖ Grinding and Refinement Process for Raw Materials: After thorough cleaning, the dried turmeric rhizomes are transferred for grinding, where they are processed to achieve the desired texture. \nThe ground material is then passed through a Vibro Sifter to ensure uniform consistency. Following \nthis, a metal detector is used to eliminate any potential metal contaminants, ensuring product \nsafety. ❖ Final Inspection and Storage of Processed Materials: A final quality inspection is performed before storage. The processed turmeric powder is then stored in Ground Storage and Cold Storage to \nmaintain freshness. From Ground Storage, the materials are transferred to the Semi-Finished \nGoods section for further processing. \n \n❖ Packaging, Storage, and Dispatch of Finished Goods: Once the turmeric powder meets the required standards, it is moved to the Packaging section. The packaged product is then stored in \nFinished Goods Storage before being dispatched to its final destination. \n \nCAPACITY UTILIZATION \n \nThe details of Installed capacity and capacity Page 172 of 402 POWER \nOur Company requires power for the efficient working and timely production of our manufacturing \nunit. The power requirement of the office is for lighting, systems, equipments and machines for \nrunning etc. Adequate power is available which is met through the electric supply by respective area \nelectricity Board. Our Company has also installed DG set 250 KVA for power backup. We have also \ninstalled solar panels of 200 KW at our unit which assists in the supply of electricity. \n \nINFORMATION TECHNOLOGY \nOur company installed SAP Business One software on 10.06.2024 at our premises. This software helps \nus with inventory management, raw material tracking, order status update as well as provide \naccounting features.  \n \nENVIRONMENT SOCIAL AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE INITIATIVES \n \nOur safety, health and environmental practices are robust and are continuously updated to adapt to \nthe safety, health and environmental practices, rules, and regulations of the geography we operate in. \nWe conduct external tests of our safety mechanisms every year to comply with the requirements of \nthe Health and Safety Management System and Environmental Management System. \n \nOur Company was exempted from the provision of section 135 of the Companies Act, 2013, till March \n31, 2024, in respect of Corporate Social Responsibility. However, with effect from the fiscal year ending \non March 31, 2025, Our Company has set up the CSR Committee and adopted the CSR Policy in \ncompliance with the provision of Section 135 of the Companies Act, 2013 and the rules made \nthereunder. The total expenditure required to be spent for the Fiscal Year ended on March 31, 2025, \nwas ₹ 9.38 Lakhs. LOGISTICS \n \nTransportation is key element in our business operations. Raw material is bought to our manufacturing \nunit from third party transport suppliers. Similarly, our finished products are transported to various \ndestinations in India either via rail network for bulk orders and other orders are transported via third \nparty logistics providers. Our facility is equipped with a stockyard, enabling smooth functioning of our \noperations. We do not have any contractual arrangements or agreements with third-party \ntransportation and logistics providers and engage their services, as and when required. \n \nQUALITY ASSURANCE \n \nOur entire process is monitored by our in-house Quality Control team. Good quality raw materials are \nprocured from other agents of the market, thus leaving no space for quality degradation. Our offerings \nsuch as Red Chilli Powder, Cumin Seed, Pav Bhaji Masala, Coriander Powder, etc. are used by \nprofessional chefs throughout the world because of their inherent natural flavor and aroma. For the \ndetails regarding the quality certification obtained by our company, please refer to “Government \nApproval – Approvals Obtained by Our Company in Relation to Our Business and Operations - \nCertifications” beginning on page 302. \n \nSALES AND MARKETING SETUP \n \nOur company is committed to strengthening our brand presence and building trust within the Spices \nIndustry through target branding and promotional activities. As a result, to remain \ncompetitive in our markets, we must continuously strive to reduce our costs of production, \ntransportation and distribution and improve our operating efficiencies. We compete primarily on the \nbasis of product quality, technology, cost, delivery and service, as well as quality and depth of senior \nlevel relationships. \n \nThe principal elements of competition in our industry are quality, technical ability, performance \nrecord, sustainable relationship with existing clients and vendors, use of technically upgraded plant \nand machinery, timely delivery and reliability. We compete against our competitors by establishing \nourselves as knowledge-based production unit with industry expertise in the segment which enables \nus to provide our clients with quality products. However, price is the deciding factor in most cases.  \n \nCOLLABORATION \n \nThere is no collaboration as on the date of filing of the Red Herring Prospectus. \n \nMAJOR CUSTOMERS AND SUPPLIERS \n \nWe majorly procure our raw materials and sell our products to various dealers / wholesalers. Page 179 of 402 KEY INDUSTRY REGULATIONS AND POLICIES \n \nThe following description is a summary of the relevant regulations and policies as prescribed by the \nGovernment of India and other regulatory bodies that are applicable to our business. The information \ndetailed in this chapter has been obtained from various legislations, including rules and regulations \npromulgated by the regulatory bodies that are available in the public domain. The regulations and \npolicies set out below may not be exhaustive and are only intended to provide general information to \nthe investors and are neither designed nor intended to be a substitute for professional legal advice. Our \nCompany may be required to obtain licenses and approvals depending upon the prevailing laws and \nregulations as applicable. For details of such approvals, please see the section titled “Government and \nStatutory Approvals” beginning on page 302.  \n \nINDUSTRY/BUSINESS/TRADE RELATED LAWS \n \nThe Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 (“FSSA”) \nThe Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 (“FSSA”) was enacted to establish a comprehensive \nregulatory framework for food safety in India, replacing the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954. \nThe Act led to the formation of the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI), which sets \nscientific standards for food products and regulates their manufacture, storage, distribution, sale, and \nimport to ensure consumer safety. The regulatory framework mandates that all food business \noperators obtain necessary licenses and comply with prescribed safety and quality standards. \nAdditionally, the Food Safety and Standards Rules, 2011 (“FSSR”) provide detailed guidelines on the \nregistration and licensing of food businesses, enforcement mechanisms, and roles of food safety \nofficers and analysts. The law also places liability on manufacturers, distributors, and retailers to \nensure that food products meet quality and safety benchmarks and prohibits the sale of misbranded \nor unsafe products. \n \nIn addition to these regulations, the FSSAI has issued several guidelines to address emerging challenges \nin food safety, including the Guidance Note on Food Hygiene and Safety during the COVID-19 \nPandemic. This Guidance Note outlines preventive measures for food businesses, including health \nscreenings, disinfection protocols, and hygiene standards, to mitigate contamination risks. The FSSA \nframework plays a critical role in ensuring food safety, strengthening regulatory compliance, and \nfostering consumer trust in the food industry. \n \nLegal Metrology Act, 2009 (“LM Act”) \nThe Legal Metrology Act, 2009 replaced the Standards of Weights & Measures Act, 1976 and the \nStandards of Weights & Measures (Enforcement) Act, 1985 to establish a uniform system of weights \nand measures in line with international standards. India, as a member of the International \nOrganization of Legal Metrology (“OIML”), adopted the SI units to ensure accuracy and consistency in \ntrade and commerce. The Act regulates inter-state trade, mandates the approval of weighing and \nmeasuring instruments, and establishes standards for numeration to prevent malpractices in \ntransactions. It also provides for the Indian Institute of Legal Metrology to train enforcement officers \nand prescribes penalties for non-compliance. \n \nThe Legal Metrology Act is essential to ensure that all pre-packaged goods meet prescribed labelling \nand measurement standards. This includes accurate declaration of weight, quantity, MRP, \nmanufacturing details, and consumer grievance information on packaging. The Act mandates \nregistration of weighing and measuring instruments used in manufacturing and retail, ensuring \ntransparency and fair trade practices. Non-compliance can result in penalty, making adherence to legal \nmetrology regulations a critical aspect of business operations for consumer protection and regulatory \ncompliance. \n \nLegal Metrology (Packaged Commodities) Rules, 2011 (“Packaged Commodities Rules”) \nhe Packaged Commodities Rules was framed under Section 52(2) (j) and (q) of the Metrology Act and \nlay down specific provisions applicable to packages intended for retail sale, whole sale and for export Page 180 of 402 and import. A “pre packaged commodity” means a commodity which without the purchaser being \npresent is placed in a package of a pre-determined quantity. The key provisions of the Packaged \nCommodities Rules are: \n• It is illegal to manufacture, pack, sell, import, distribute, deliver, offer, expose or possess for sale any pre‐packaged commodity unless the package is in such standard quantities or number and \nbears thereon such declarations and particulars as prescribed.  \n• All pre‐packaged commodities must conform to the declarations provided thereon as per the requirement of Section 18(1) of the Metrology Act; and  \n• No pre‐packaged commodity shall be packed with error in net quantity beyond the limit prescribed in the first schedule of the Packaged Commodity Rules. \n \nThe Spices Board Act, 1986 \nThe Spices Board Act, 1986 was enacted to establish the Spices Board of India, a regulatory body under \nthe ministry of Commerce and Industry, Government of India. The Act consolidated the functions of \nthe erstwhile Cardamom Board and Spices Export Promotion Council, with the objective of promoting, \ndeveloping, and regulating the spice industry in India. The Board is responsible for overseeing the \nproduction, processing, and export of spices, ensuring quality control, certification, and adherence to \ninternational standards. It also provides financial and technical assistance to farmers, exporters, and \nother stakeholders in the spice industry. \n \nThe Board's regulatory framework ensures compliance with both domestic and international food \nsafety standards, making it essential for companies involved in the manufacturing, processing, and \nexport of spices.   \n \nAgricultural Produce (Grading and Marketing) Act, 1937 (Agmark)  \nThe agricultural produce marketing legislations enacted by state governments regulate marketing of \nagricultural, horticultural, livestock products and certain other produce in market areas and \nestablishes market committees for every market area in the state to regulate transactions in \nagricultural produce. It provides for the organization and composition of committees and their powers \nand functions which include, granting licenses to operate in the market, provide for necessary facilities \nin the market area, regulate and control transactions in the market and admissions to the market.  \n \nThe Directorate of Marketing and Inspection enforces the Agricultural Produce (Grading and \nMarketing) Act, 1937. Under this Act Grade standards are prescribed for agricultural and allied \ncommodities. These are known as Agmark' standards. Grading under the provisions of this Act is \nvoluntary. The DMI enforces the Agricultural Products (Grading and Marketing) Act, 1937. Under this \nAct, Grade Standards are prescribed for agricultural and allied commodities. These are known as \n\"Agmark\" Standards. Grading under the provisions of this Act is voluntary. Manufacturers who comply \nwith standard laid down by DMI are allowed to use \"Agmark\" labels on their products. \n \nThe Essential Commodities Act, 1955  \nThe Essential Commodities Act, 1955 (“ECA”) gives powers to the Government of India to control the \nproduction, supply and distribution of certain essential commodities for inter alia securing their \nequitable distribution and availability at fair prices. Using the powers under it, various ministries/ \ndepartments of the Indian government have issued control orders for regulating production, \ndistribution, trading, quality aspects, movement and prices pertaining to commodities which are \nessential and administered by them, including for essential commodities such as food grains, edible \noils, sugar and drugs. Penalties in terms of fine and imprisonment are prescribed under the ECA for \nnon-compliance of its provisions. \n \nThe Essential Commodities (Amendment) Act, 2020 (“Amendment Act”), which is yet to be \nimplemented, provides the Government of India to regulate the supply of certain food items including \nedible oils only under extraordinary circumstances which may include war, famine, extraordinary price \nrise and natural calamity of grave nature. The Amendment Act requires that imposition of any stock \nlimit on agricultural produce must be based on price rise. Further, a stock limit may be imposed only Page 181 of 402 if there is: (i) a 100% increase in retail price of horticultural produce; and (ii) a 50% increase in the \nretail price of non-perishable agricultural food items. The increase will be calculated over the price \nprevailing immediately preceding twelve months, or the average retail price of the last five years, \nwhichever is lower. \n \nSTATUTORY AND COMMERCIAL LAWS \n \nThe Companies Act, 2013 and Companies Act, 1956 \nThe Companies Act, 2013, has replaced the Companies Act, 1956, in a phased manner. The Companies \nAct, 2013 received the assent of the President of India on August 29, 2013. At present, almost all the \nprovisions of this law have been made effective except a few to which extent the Companies Act, 1956, \nis still applicable. The Ministry of Corporate Affairs has also issued rules complementary to the \nCompanies Act, 2013 establishing the procedure to be followed by companies in order to comply with \nthe substantive provisions of the Companies Act, 2013. The Companies Act primarily regulates the \nformation, financing, functioning, and winding up of companies. The Companies Act, 2013 prescribes \nregulatory mechanisms regarding all relevant aspects including organizational, financial and \nmanagerial aspects of companies. Indian Contract Act, 1872 \nThe Indian Contract Act, 1872 (“Contract Act”) codifies the way in which a contract is entered, \nexecuted, and implemented and the implications of a breach of a contract. The Contract Act consists \nof limiting factors subject to which contract may be entered into, executed and breach enforced, as \namended from time to time. It determines the circumstances in which a promise made by the parties \nto a contract shall be legally binding on them. Each contract creates some rights and duties upon the \ncontracting parties. The Contract Act deals with the enforcement of these rights and duties upon the \nparties. The Contract Act also lays down provisions of indemnity, guarantee, bailment, and agency. \nProvisions relating to the sale of goods and partnerships which were originally in the Act are now the \nsubject matter of separate enactments viz., the Sale of Goods Act, 1930 and the Indian Partnership Act \n1932. The objective of the Contract Act is to ensure that the rights and obligations arising out of a \ncontract are honoured and that legal remedies are made available to those who are affected. \n \nThe Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 \nThe Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 cover Insolvency of companies, Limited Liability \npartnerships (LLPs), unlimited liability partnerships, and individuals. The IBC 2016 has laid down a \ncollective mechanism for resolution of insolvencies in the country by maintaining a delicate balance \nfor all stakeholders to preserve the economic value of the process in a time bound manner. The code \nempowers any creditor of a Corporate Debtor (CD), irrespective of it being a Financial Creditor (FC) or \nOperational Creditor (OC) or secured or unsecured creditor, or the Corporate Debtor itself, to make \nan application before the Adjudicating Authority (AA) to initiate Corporate Insolvency Resolution \nProcess (CIRP) against a Corporate Debtor, at their discretion, in the event of there being a default by \nthe Corporate Debtor in payment of their dues for an amount as specified from time to time. On \ninitiation of the said CIRP, a resolution to be sought for the company withing a time bound time period \nof 180 days. \n \nMicro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 \nThe Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 was enacted in order to promote \nand enhance the competitiveness of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise (“MSME”). As per the \nnotification no. F. No. 2/1(5)/2019-P&G/Policy (Pt.-IV) dated June 01, 2020, the Central Government \nnotified the following criteria for the classification of MSME with effect from July 01, 2020: as a micro-\nenterprise, where the investment in plant and machinery or equipment does not exceed One Crore \nRupees and turnover does not exceed Five Crore Rupees; a small enterprise, where the investment in \nplant and machinery or equipment does not exceed ten crore rupees and turnover does not exceed \nFifty Crore Rupees; and a medium enterprise, where the investment in plant and machinery or \nequipment does not exceed Fifty Crore Rupees and turnover does not exceed Two Hundred and Fifty \nCrore Rupees. Page 182 of 402 The classification limits for MSME have been revised pursuant to MSME Notification No. SO-1364(E) \ndated 21.03.2025. The new classification thresholds are as follows: (a) For Micro Enterprises, the \ninvestment limit will be raised to ₹ 2.5 crores and the turnover limit to ₹ 10 crores; (b) For Small \nEnterprises, the investment limit will be increased to ₹ 25 crores and the turnover limit to ₹ 100 crores; \nand (c) For Medium Enterprises, the investment limit will be enhanced to ₹ 125 crores and the turnover \nlimit to ₹ 500 crores. These revised limits have come into effect from 1 April 2025. \n \nThe Arbitration & Conciliation Act, 1996 \nThe Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (“A&C Act”) provides a framework for the resolution of \ndisputes through arbitration and conciliation. The main aim of A&C Act is to promote alternative \ndispute resolution mechanisms and offer cost-effective, and private alternative to court litigation. \nArbitration or conciliation is initiated based on an agreement between the parties or by a court order. \nIn arbitration proceedings the tribunal conducts hearings, gathers evidence, and issues an award based \non the proceedings. In conciliation proceedings, the conciliator engages with the parties to help them \nreach a mutually acceptable resolution. The arbitral award is the final decision of the arbitrator(s), \nwhich is binding on the parties. The arbitral award has the same force of decree as that the court \ndecree.  \n \nConsumer Protection Act, 2019 \nThe Consumer Protection Act, 2019 (“Consumer Act”), has repealed Consumer Protection Act, 1986 \nand provides for the protection of the interest of the consumers and the settlement of disputes raised \nby the consumers. The provisions of the Consumer Protection Act, 2019 have been made effective \nvide notification no. F. No. J-9/1/2020-CPU dated July 23, 2020, and notification no. F. No. J-9/1/2020-\nCPU dated July 15, 2020, as issued by the Central Government. The Consumer Act sets out a \nmechanism for consumers to file complaints against, inter alia, service providers in cases of \ndeficiencies in services, unfair or restrictive trade practices, and excessive pricing. A three-tier \nconsumer grievance redressal mechanism has been implemented pursuant to the Consumer Act, at \nthe national, state, and district levels. Further, the Consumer Act established a Central Consumer \nProtection Authority to promote, enforce, and protect the rights of consumers. If the allegations \nspecified in a complaint about the services provided are proved, the service provider can be directed \nto inter alia remove the deficiencies in the services in question, return to the complainant the charges \npaid by the complainant, and pay compensation, including punitive damages, for any loss or injury \nsuffered by the consumer. Non-compliance with the orders of the authorities may attract criminal \npenalties in the form of fines and/or imprisonment. \n \nCompetition Act, 2002  \nThe Competition Act, 2002 aims to anti-competitive practices that cause or are likely to cause an \nappreciable adverse effect on competition in the relevant market in India. The act deals with the \nprohibition of agreements and anti-competitive agreements. No enterprise or group shall abuse its \ndominant position in various circumstances as mentioned under the act. The prima facie duty of the \nCompetition Commission established under the act is to eliminate practices having adverse effects on \ncompetition, promote and sustain competition, protect the interests of the consumer, and ensure \nfreedom of trade. \n \nIndian Stamp Act, 1899  \nUnder the Indian Stamp Act, 1899 and other State specific stamp legislations (“Stamp Act”) stamp \nduty is payable on instruments evidencing a transfer or creation or extinguishment of any right, title \nor interest in immovable property and other instruments specified therein. Stamp duty must be paid \non all instruments specified under the Stamp Act at the rates specified in the schedules to the Stamp \nAct. The applicable rates for stamp duty on instruments chargeable with duty vary from state to state. \nInstruments chargeable to duty under the Stamp Act, which are not duly stamped are incapable of \nbeing admitted in court as evidence of the transaction contained therein and it also provides for \nimpounding of instruments that are not sufficiently stamped or not stamped at all. Page 183 of 402 The Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881  \nIn India, the laws governing monetary instruments such as cheques are contained in the Negotiable \nInstruments Act, 1881 (“NI Act”). The NI Act provides effective legal provision to restrain persons from \nissuing cheques without having sufficient funds in their account and any stringent provision to punish \nthem in the event of such cheque not being honoured by their bankers and returned unpaid. Section \n138 of the NI Act creates statutory offence in the matter of dishonour of cheques on the ground of \ninsufficiency of funds in the account maintained by a person with the banker. \n \nLEGISLATIONS RELATING TO LABOUR AND EMPLOYMENT \n \nEmployees State Insurance Act, 1948  \nEmployees State Insurance Act, 1948 (“ESI Act”) as amended, provides for certain benefits to \nemployees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury. All employees in establishments \ncovered by the ESI Act are required to be insured, with an obligation imposed on the employer to make \ncertain contributions in relation thereto. In addition, the employer is also required to register itself \nunder the ESI Act and maintain prescribed records and registers.  \n \nEmployees Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952, and the schemes formulated \nthere under \nThis Employees Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952 (“EPF Act”) provides for the \ninstitution of provident funds, family pension funds, and deposit-linked insurance funds for the \nemployees in factories and other establishments. Accordingly, the following schemes are formulated \nfor the benefit of such employees: \n \n(i) \nThe Employees Provident Fund Scheme, 1952: As per this scheme, a provident fund is constituted \nand both the employees and employer contribute to the fund at the rate of 12% (or 10% in certain \ncases) of the basic wages, dearness allowance and retaining allowance, if any, payable to \nemployees per month. \n \n(ii) The Employees’ Pension Scheme, 1995: The employees’ pension scheme is a pension scheme for survivors, old aged and disabled persons. This scheme derives its financial resources by partial \ndiversion from the provident fund contribution, the rate is 8.33%. Thus, a part of the contribution \nrepresenting 8.33% of the employee’s pay shall be remitted by the employer to the employee’s \npension fund within fifteen (15) days of the close of every month by a separate bank draft or \ncheque on account of the employees’ pension fund contribution in such manner as may be \nspecified in this behalf by the appropriate authority constituted under the EPF Act. \n \n(iii) The Employees Deposit Linked Insurance Scheme, 1976: As per this scheme, the contribution by the employer shall be remitted by him together with administrative charges at such rate as the \nCentral Government may fix from time to time under Section 6C (4) of the EPF Act, to the \ninsurance fund within fifteen (15) days of the close of every month by a separate bank draft or \ncheque or by remittance in cash in such manner as may be specified in this behalf by the \nappropriate authority constituted under the EPF Act. \n \nThe Factories Act, 1948 \nThe Factories Act, 1948 (“Factories Act”) consolidates the law relating to labour in factories. The main \nobjective of the Factories Act is to regulate the working conditions in factories, to regulate health, \nsafety welfare, and annual leave, and to enact special provisions with respect of young persons, \nwomen, and children who work in factories. Any factory that fulfils the criteria given in the Factories \nAct is required to obtain registration under the Factories Act.  \n \nThe Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013  \nThe Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 \n(“SHWW Act”) provides for the protection of women at the workplace and the prevention of sexual \nharassment at the workplace. The SHWW Act also provides for a redressal mechanism to manage \ncomplaints in this regard. Sexual harassment includes one or more of the following acts or behaviours Page 184 of 402 namely, physical contact and advances a demand or request for sexual favours or making sexually \ncoloured remarks, showing pornography or any other unwelcome physical, verbal or non-verbal \nconduct of a sexual nature. The SHWW Act makes it mandatory for every employer of a workplace to \nconstitute an internal complaints committee which shall always be presided upon by a woman. It also \nprovides for the manner and time period within which a complaint shall be made to the internal \ncomplaints committee i.e., a written complaint is to be made within a period of three (3) months from \nthe date of the last incident. If the establishment has less than ten (10) employees, then the complaints \nfrom employees of such establishments as also complaints made against the employer himself shall \nbe received by the local complaints committee. The penalty for non-compliance with any provision of \nthe SHWW Act shall be punishable with a fine extending to ₹ 50,000/- (Rupees Fifty Thousand Only). \n \nThe Payment of Wages Act, 1936 \nThe Payment of Wages Act applies to the persons employed in the factories and to persons employed \nin industrial or other establishments, either directly or indirectly through a sub-contractor, where the \nmonthly wages payable to such persons is less than ₹ 24,000/-. The Act confers on the person(s) \nresponsible for payment of wages certain obligations with respect to the maintenance of registers and \nthe display in such factory/establishment, of the abstracts of this Act and Rules made there under. \n \nIn order to rationalize and reform all labour laws in India, the Government of India has notified four \nlabour codes that are yet to come into force as of the date of this Red Herring Prospectus, which are \nas follows: \n(i) \nThe Code on Social Security, 2020* \n(ii) The Code on Wages, 2019*  \n(iii) Industrial Relations Code, 2020* \n(iv) Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code, 2020*  \n \n* These codes have become partly applicable and shall become fully effective on the day that the Government \nshall notify for this purpose. \n \nThe Payment of Bonus Act, 1965  \nThe Payment of Bonus Act, 1965, as amended (“PoB Act”) provides for payment of minimum bonuses \nto factories, and every other establishment in which 20 or more persons are employed and requires \nmaintenance of certain books and registers and filing of monthly returns showing computation of \nallocable surplus, set on and set off of allocable surplus and bonus due. The minimum bonus to be paid \nto each employee is 8.33% of the annual salary or wage or ₹100, whichever is higher. \n \nThe Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 \nThe Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 (“Maternity Act”) provides for leave and the right to payment of \nmaternity benefits to women employees in case of confinement or miscarriage, etc. The Maternity Act \nis applicable to every establishment being a factory, mine, or plantation inter alia to every shop or \nestablishment within the meaning of any law for the time being in force in relation to shops and \nestablishments in a State, in which ten or more persons are employed, or were employed, on any day \nof the preceding twelve months; provided that the State Government may, with the approval of the \nCentral Government, after giving at least two months’ notice shall apply any of the provisions of the \nMaternity Act to any specific establishments or class of establishments, industrial, commercial, \nagricultural or otherwise. The Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017 amended the Maternity Act \nto provide for the increase of paid maternity leave from 12 to 26 weeks unless the mother has two or \nmore surviving children and introduced a mandatory provision for creche facilities for employers with \nmore than 50 employees. \n \nThe Minimum Wages Act, 1948 \nThe Minimum Wages Act, 1948, as amended (“Minimum Wages Act”) provides a framework for State \nGovernments to stipulate the minimum wage applicable to a particular industry. The minimum wage \nmay consist of a basic rate of wages and a special allowance, or a basic rate of wages and the cash \nvalue of concessions in respect of supplies of essential commodities, or an all-inclusive rate allowing \nfor the basic rate, the cost of living allowance and the cash value of the concessions, if any. Workmen \nare to be paid for overtime at overtime rates stipulated by the appropriate government. Page 185 of 402 Shops and Establishment Laws \nThe shops and establishment laws govern a company in the states where it has \noffices/godowns/shops. It regulates the conditions of work and employment in shops and commercial \nestablishments and generally prescribes obligations in respect of registration, opening and closing \nhours, daily and weekly working hours, health and safety measures, and wages for overtime work. \n \nOther Labour law legislations: \nIn addition to the aforementioned material legislations that are applicable to our Company, some of \nthe other labour legislations that may be applicable to our Company include the following: \n(i) \nPayment of Gratuity Act, 1972; \n(ii) \nState-wise Labour welfare fund legislations and rules made thereunder; \n(iii) \nIndustrial Disputes Act, 1947;  \n(iv) \nThe Employees’ Compensation Act, 1923;  \n(v) \nThe Apprentices Act, 1961 \n \nENVIRONMENTAL LAWS \n \nEnvironment Protection Act, 1986, and Environment Protection Rules, 1986 \nThe purpose of the Environment Protection Act, 1986 (“EPA”) is to act as an umbrella legislation \nproviding a framework for Central Government to co-ordinate of environment protection activities of \nvarious central and state authorities. The said Act prohibits a person carrying on business, operations, \nprocess from discharging or emitting any environmental pollutant in excess of such standards as may \nbe prescribed by the Government in this regard. Further, the Environment Protection Rules, 1986 (“EP \nRules”) specify, inter alia, the standards for the emission or discharge of environmental pollutants, \nrestrictions on the location of industries, and restrictions on the handling of hazardous substances in \ndifferent areas. For contravention of any of the provisions of the EPA or the EP Rules framed \nthereunder, the punishment includes either imprisonment or fine, or both. \n \nTAX LAWS \n \nThe Income Tax Act, 1961 \nThe Income Tax Act, 1961 (“Tax Act”) deals with the taxation of individuals, corporate, partnership \nfirms, etc. As per the provisions of the Tax Act, the rates at which they are required to pay tax are \ncalculated on the income declared by them or assessed by the authorities, after availing the deductions \nand concessions accorded under the Act. The maintenance of books of accounts and relevant \nsupporting documents and registers are mandatory under the Tax Act. Filing of returns of income is \ncompulsory for all assesses. The maintenance of books of accounts and relevant supporting \ndocuments and registers are mandatory under the Tax Act. \n \nGoods and Services Tax \nGoods and Services Tax (“GST”) is levied on supply of goods or services or both jointly by the Central \nand State Governments. It was introduced as The Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) \nAct 2017 and is governed by the GST Council. GST provides for imposition of tax on the supply of goods \nor services and will be levied by central on intra-state supply of goods or services and by the States \nincluding Union territories with legislature/ Union Territories without legislature respectively. A \ndestination based consumption tax GST would be a dual GST with the central and states \nsimultaneously levying tax with a common base. The GST law is enforced by various acts viz. Central \nGoods and Services Act, 2017 (CGST), State Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017 (SGST), Union Territory \nGoods and Services Tax Act, 2017 (UTGST), Integrated Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017 (IGST) and \nGoods and Services Tax (Compensation to States) Act, 2017 and various rules made thereunder. \n \nEvery person liable to take registration under these Acts shall do so within a period of 30 days from \nthe date on which he becomes liable to registration. The Central/State authority shall issue the \nregistration certificate upon receipt of application. The Certificate shall contain fifteen-digit \nregistration numbers known as Goods and Service Tax Identification Number (GSTIN). In case a person Page 186 of 402 has multiple business verticals in multiple locations in a state, a separate application will be made for \nregistration of each and every location. The registered assessee is then required to pay GST as per the \nrules applicable thereon and file the appropriate returns as applicable thereon. GST has replaced \nfollowing indirect taxes and duties at the central and state levels. \n \nThe Customs Act, 1962, and Customs Tariff Act, 1975 \nThe stipulations prescribed by the Customs Act of 1962 and its corresponding regulations are \nenforceable during the importation of goods into India from foreign territories, as well as during the \nexportation of goods from India to foreign destinations. Additionally, the Customs Tariff Act of 1975 \nestablishes the applicable rates for the imposition of customs duties as per the provisions outlined in \nthe Customs Act of 1962. \n \nINTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS \n \nThe Trademarks Act, 1999 \nThe Trademarks Act, 1999 (“TM Act”) provides for the process for making an application and obtaining \nregistration of trademarks in India. The purpose of the TM Act is to grant exclusive rights to marks such \nas a brand, label, and to obtain relief in case of infringement for commercial purposes as a trade \ndescription. The TM Act prohibits the registration of deceptively similar trademarks and provides for \npenalties for infringement, falsifying, and falsely applying trademarks. \n \nThe Copyright Act, 1957  \nCopyright is a right given by the law to creators of literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works and \nproducers of cinematograph films and sound recordings. In fact, it is a bundle of rights including, \ninteralia, and rights of reproduction, communication to the public, adaptation and translation of the \nwork. There could be slight variations in the composition of the rights depending on the work. The Act \nplays a vital role in promoting respect for intellectual property while encouraging the dissemination of \nknowledge and culture. By protecting the interests of both authors and the public, it creates an \nenvironment conducive to creativity, technological advancement, and cultural development. \n \nFOREIGN INVESTMENT REGULATIONS \n \nForeign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992, and the Foreign Trade Policy of India, 2023 \nThe Foreign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992 (“FTA”) seeks to increase foreign trade by \nregulating imports and exports to and from India. It authorizes the Government to formulate as well \nas announce the export and import policy and to keep amending the same on a timely basis. The \nForeign Trade Policy of India, 2023 is notified by Central Government, in the exercise of powers \nconferred under Section 5 of the FTA, as amended. In accordance with Policy 2023, an entity is required \nto mandatorily apply for the Importer-Exporter Code (“IEC”) for undertaking import/export activities.  \n \nForeign Exchange Management Act, 1999, and rules and regulations framed thereunder  \nForeign investment in India is governed primarily by the provisions of the Foreign Exchange \nManagement Act, 1999 (“FEMA”) which relates to regulation primarily by the RBI and the rules, \nregulations, and notifications there under, and the policy prescribed by the Department of Industrial \nPolicy and Promotion, Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Government of India. As laid down by the \nFEMA Regulations (as defined hereunder), no prior consents and approvals are required from the RBI, \nfor foreign direct investment (“FDI”) under the ‘automatic route’ within the specified sectoral caps. In \nrespect of all industries not specified as FDI under the automatic route, and in respect of investment \nin excess of the specified sectoral limits under the automatic route, approval may be required from \nthe FIPB and/or the RBI. The RBI, in the exercise of its power under the FEMA, has notified the Foreign \nExchange Management (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, 2019 vide notification F.No. 1/14/EM/2015 \ndated October 17, 2019 (“FEMA Regulations”) which governs transfer by or issue security to a person \nresident outside India. FEMA Regulations repealed the Foreign Exchange Management (Transfer or \nIssue of Security by a Person Resident outside India) Regulations, 2017, and Foreign Exchange \nManagement (Acquisition and Transfer of Immovable Property in India) Regulations, 2018. Page 187 of 402 Foreign Direct Investment Policy, 2020 \nWith the intent and objective of the Government of India to attract and promote foreign direct \ninvestment in order to supplement domestic capital, technology, and skills, for accelerated economic \ngrowth. The Government of India has put in place a policy framework on Foreign Direct Investment, \nwhich is transparent, predictable, and easily comprehensible. This framework is embodied in the \nCircular on Consolidated FDI Policy, which may be updated every year, to capture and keep pace with \nthe regulatory changes, effected in the interregnum. The Department of Industrial Policy and \nPromotion (“DIPP”), Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Government of India makes policy \npronouncements on FDI through press notes/press releases which are notified by the RBI as \namendments to the Foreign Exchange Management (Transfer or Issue of Security by Persons Resident \nOutside India) Regulations, 2000. These notifications take effect from the date of issue of press notes/ \npress releases unless specified otherwise therein. In case of any conflict, the relevant FEMA \nNotification will prevail. The procedural instructions are issued by the RBI vide A.P. (DIR Series) \nCirculars. The regulatory framework, over a period, thus, consists of Acts, Regulations, Press Notes, \nPress Releases, Clarifications, etc. Page 188 of 402 OUR HISTORY AND CERTAIN OTHER CORPORATE MATTERS \n \nBRIEF HISTORY OF OUR COMPANY \n \nOur Company was originally incorporated as “Shyam Dhani Industries Private Limited” at Jaipur as a \nprivate limited company under the Companies Act, 1956, pursuant to a certificate of incorporation \ndated October 19, 2010, issued by the RoC, Rajasthan. Page 218 of 402 DIVIDEND POLICY \n \nUnder the Companies Act, a Company can pay dividends upon a recommendation by our Board of \nDirectors and approval by the shareholders at the general meeting of our Company. The Articles of \nAssociation of our Company give our shareholders, the right to decrease, and not to increase, the \namount of dividend recommended by the Board of Directors.  \n \nThe Articles of Association of our Company also gives the discretion to our Board of Directors to \ndeclare and pay interim dividends. No dividend shall be payable for any financial except out of profits \nof our Company for that year or that of any previous fiscal year or years, which shall be arrived at after \nproviding for depreciation in accordance with the provisions of Companies Act, 2013. \n \nOur Company does not have any formal dividend policy for declaration of dividend in respect of the \nEquity Shares. The declaration and payment of dividend will be recommended by our Board of \nDirectors and approved by the shareholders of our Company at their discretion and may depend on a \nnumber of factors, including the results of operations, earnings, Company’s future expansion plans, \ncapital requirements and surplus, general financial condition, contractual restrictions, applicable \nIndian legal restrictions and other factors considered relevant by our Board of Directors. \n \nDividend paid on Equity Shares \n \nOur Company has not declared any dividend on the Equity Shares for the period ended on September \n30, 2025 and the past three fiscal years. Our Company’s corporate actions pertaining to payment of \ndividends in the past are not to be taken as being indicative of the payment of dividends by our \nCompany in the future. Accordingly, all references to a particular Fiscal Year \nare to the 12 months ended March 31 of that year. \n \nOVERVIEW \n \nOur company is engaged in the manufacturing and processing of 164 type/varieties of spices such as \nGround Spices, Blend Spices and Whole Spices under the brand name “SHYAM”. In addition to our \nspice offerings, we are also engaged in trading and distribution of Grocery Products such as Black Salt, \nRock Salt, Rice, Poha, Kasuri Methi (Dried Fenugreek) etc. and a diverse range of Herbs and seasonings \nwhich includes Organo, Peri Peri, Chilli Flakes, Mixed Herbs, Onion Flakes, Tomato Powder etc. \n \nOur Company operates across multiple sales channels, catering to both Business to Business (“B2B”) \nand Direct to Consumer (“D2C”) markets. In the B2B space, we serve customers through General \nTrade (wholesalers and distributors across India), Modern Trade (supermarkets and big retail chains), \nand Quick Commerce Platforms (through quick commerce apps), ensuring our products are easily \naccessible to consumer We are also involved in Private Labelling, HoReCa (Hotel, Restaurant, and \nCatering) sales, and Export Sales. By using our products these businesses can create custom spice \nblends for their own branded lines, allowing them to provide good quality ingredients and tailored \nsolutions to meet the unique needs of professional kitchens \n \nAdditionally, we have a Direct-to-Consumer (“D2C”) presence via our website, offering seamless \nonline shopping experience for customers to directly purchase our products. \n \nFor further details, please refer “Our Business – Overview” beginning on page 154. \n \nSIGNIFICANT MATERIAL DEVELOPMENTS SUBSEQUENT TO THE STUB PERIOD \n \nIn the opinion of the Board of Directors of our Company, since the date of the last financial statements \ndisclosed in this Red Herring Prospectus, there have not arisen any circumstance that materially and \nadversely affect or are likely to affect the business activities or profitability of our Company or the \nvalue of its assets or its ability to pay its material liabilities within the next twelve months except as \nmentioned below: \n1. Our Company has received the In Principle Approval from National Stock Exchange of India Limited on November 24, 2025, to use their names in the Offer Documents in respect of the proposed \npublic issue of Equity Shares. Page 265 of 402 2. Our company, in consultation with the BRLM, has undertaken a Pre-IPO Placement aggregating of 2,86,000 Equity Shares of face value of ₹ 10/- each for an aggregate amount of ₹ 200.20 Lakhs. The \nIssue size as disclosed in the Draft Red Herring Prospectus, aggregating up to 57,84,000 Equity \nShares, has been reduced by 2,86,000 Equity Shares pursuant to the Pre-IPO Placement subject to \nthe Issue complying with Rule 19(2)(b) of the SCRR, and accordingly, the Issue size is of up to \n54,98,000 Equity Shares of face value of ₹ 10/- each. The proceeds of the Pre-IPO Placement shall \nbe utilized towards General Corporate purposes. Our results of operations and financial conditions are affected by numerous factors \nincluding the following: \n \nAbility to expand the customer base and develop new products capabilities to meet evolving \npreferences and generate new sales. \nCustomer relationships are the core of our business. Our ability to grow our operations and increase \nsales depends upon the brand awareness of our products among the end consumers. We expect that \nour revenue growth will be primarily driven by the pace of adoption of our products by the end \nconsumers. This will drive demand for our products by the end consumers from switching from their \nregular brand to our brand.   \n \nWe have substantial opportunity to grow our customer base. We have invested, and intend to \ncontinue to invest, in order to drive sales to new customer. In particular, we have made, and plan to \ncontinue to make, investments to enhance the expertise of our sales and marketing segment. Our \nbusiness from existing customers has steadily grown and contributed a significant portion of our \nrevenue. Our ability to establish and strengthen customer relationships and expand the scope of our \nproducts and services will be an important factor in our future growth and our ability to continue \nincreasing our profitability. \n \nLeveraging on our present portfolio of customers and expertise in the verticals of our existing \ncustomers we aim to develop new customer relationships by identifying potential customers that \noperate within the same verticals as our existing customer. In addition, if we can generate healthy \ndemand for our products, we may be able to increase our price, which would consequently lead to an \nincrease in our revenues and profit margins. Conversely, if we are unable to provide products to our \ncustomers, either at all or at an acceptable price, or if our customers are dissatisfied with our product \nfor any other reason, it would have an adverse effect on our revenues and our profits. \n \nRegulatory Framework \nWe have obtained all regulatory permissions which are necessary to run our business, Further, some \nof the approvals are granted for fixed periods of time and need renewals, which are obtained in the \ncourse of business, however, there may be change in statutory regulations at any time which cannot \nbe predicted by us. There can be no assurance that the change in regulations will not impact our \noperations in the future. \n \nAbility of Management \nOur success depends on the continued services and performance of the members of our management \nteam and other key employees. Competition for senior management in the industry is intense, and \nwe may not be able to retain our existing senior management or attract and retain new senior \nmanagement in the future. The loss of the services of our Promoters could seriously impair our ability \nto continue to manage and expand our business. Further, the loss of any other member of our senior \nmanagement or other key personnel may adversely affect our business, results of operations and \nfinancial condition. Page 266 of 402 Ability to manage logistics and transportation needs \nWe rely on third party transportation and other logistic facilities at every stage of our business activity \nincluding for procurement of products from our suppliers and for transportation from our factory to \nour customers and other markets. Since the cost of our goods also carried by third party transporters \nis much higher than the consideration paid for transportation, it may be difficult for us to recover \ndamages for damaged, delayed or lost goods. Our operations and profitability are dependent upon \nthe availability of transportation and other logistic facilities in a time and cost-efficient manner. \nAccordingly, our business is vulnerable to increased transportation costs, transportation strikes and \nlock-outs, shortage of labour, delays and disruption of transportation services for events such as \nweather-related problems and accidents. Further, movement of goods encounters additional risks \nsuch as accidents, pilferage, spoilage or shrinkage may adversely affect our operations, results of \noperations and financial condition. Although we have not experienced any material logistics and \ntransport related disruptions in the past, any prolonged disruption or unavailability of such facilities \nin a timely manner could result in delays or non-supply or may require us to look for alternative \nsources which may not be cost-effective, thereby adversely affecting our operations, results of \noperations, cash flows and financial condition. \n \nMarket & Economic conditions \nIndia is one of the largest economies and is growing at a rapid pace. But in this globalised economy, \nall the businesses face an uncertain level of volatility from unexpected global events which ranges \nfrom global pandemics to wars, to weather changes to supply chain disruption, which may change the \neconomic dynamics and the purchasing capability of the end customer. At the time of market \nslowdown, the demand falls which has adverse impact on our business.  \n \nCompetition  \nWe operate in a competitive atmosphere. Our competition varies by market, geographic areas and \ntype of products. Our Company may face stiff competition from organized and unorganized players as \nthe dynamic changes. Some of our competitors may have greater resources than those available to \nus. While service quality, technical ability, performance records, etc. are key factors in client decisions \namong competitors, however, price and quality are the deciding factor in most cases. Further, this \nindustry is fragmented with many small and medium sized companies and entities, which \nmanufactures some of these products at various levels, which may adversely affect our business \noperation and financial condition. Further, there are no entry barriers in this industry and any \nexpansion in capacity of existing manufacturers would further intensify competition. Moreover, as we \nseek to diversify into new geographical areas, new territories, new emerging markets, we face \ncompetition from competitors that have a pan-India presence and also from competitors that have a \nstrong presence in regional markets. The markets in which we compete and intend to compete are \nundergoing, and are expected to continue to undergo, rapid and significant change. We expect \ncompetition to intensify as technological advances and consolidations continue. These competitive \nfactors may force us to reduce rates, and to pursue new market opportunities. Increased competition \ncould result in reduced demand for our products, increased expenses, reduced margins and loss of \nmarket share. Failure to compete successfully against current or future competitors could harm our \nbusiness, operating cash flows and financial condition. \n \nChanges in fiscal, economic or political conditions in India \nWe are incorporated in India and we conduct our corporate affairs and our business from India. \nConsequently, our business operations, financial performance and the market price of our Equity \nShares are affected by interest rates, government policies, taxation, social and other political and \neconomic developments affecting India.  \n \nAny slowdown or perceived slowdown in the Indian economy, or in specific sectors of the Indian \neconomy or certain regions in India, could adversely affect our business, results of operations and \nfinancial condition along with the price of the Equity Shares. Expenses \nOur expenses comprise of cost of materials consumed, purchase of Stock-in-trade, Change in \ninventories of Work in Progress and Finished Goods, employee benefit expenses, finance costs, \ndepreciation & amortization expenses and other expenses. ➢ Cost of material consumed - Cost of material consumed primarily consists of cost of procuring raw materials i.e., primarily dried chillies, dried coriander seeds and dried turmeric rhizomes and \nother products. \n➢ Change in inventories of Finished Goods and WIP – Changes in inventories of finished goods is calculated based on the opening stock and closing stock of dried chillies, dried coriander seeds \nand dried turmeric rhizomes and other products. \n➢ Employee benefit expenses - Our employee benefit expenses principally include salaries and allowances, sales incentive, directors’ remuneration, contribution to provident fund and other \nfunds, gratuity, recruitment expenses, staff welfare expenses, etc. \n➢ Finance costs - Our finance costs include interest on secured and unsecured borrowings and bank charges. \n➢ Depreciation and amortization expenses - Depreciation and amortization expenses majorly comprises of depreciation of property, plant and equipment. \n➢ \nOther expenses - Other expenses comprise of manufacturing and service cost, administration, \nselling and other expenses. \n \nOur Results of Our approach to \nmanaging liquidity is to ensure to the extent possible, that we will have sufficient liquidity to meet our \nliabilities when they are due under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring \nunacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation. We manage liquidity risk by maintaining \nadequate reserves, banking facilities and reserve borrowing facilities by continuously monitoring \nforecast and actual cash flows, and by matching the maturity profiles of financial assets and liabilities. \n \nEffect of Inflation \nWe are affected by inflation as it has an impact on the raw material cost, wages, etc. In line with \nchanging inflation rates, we rework our margins to absorb the inflationary impact. \n \nCredit Risk \nWe are exposed to credit risk on monies owed to us by our customers If our customers do not pay us \npromptly, or at all, we may have to make provisions for or write off such amounts. \n \nReservations, qualifications and adverse remarks \nExcept as disclosed in chapter titled “Financial Statements In terms of the \nborrowings availed by us, the interest rate is typically dependent on the guidelines of RBI and \nlenders and ranges from 6.85% per annum to 9.99% per annum either on a floating rate or linked \nto base rate, as specified by respective lenders. \n \n2. Validity/Tenor: The working capital and Channel Finance facilities are typically repayable on demand of the lender as well as based on a mutually agreed repayment schedule. The validity of \nour credit facilities and term loans typically ranges between 12 months to 96 months. \n \n3. Penal Interest: The terms of certain financing facilities availed by us prescribe penalties for non- compliance of certain obligations by us. These include, inter alia, breach of non-payment of \ninstalments, breaching any provisions as set forth in the loan documentation entered into with \nthe lenders. Further, the penal interest payable on the facilities availed by us typically ranges \nbetween 1% to 2% per annum over the documented rate. \n \n4. or  \n \n(ii) Litigations where the value or expected impact in terms of value, exceeds the lower of the following: (a) Two (2) percent of turnover, as per the latest annual restated financial statements of the Company, which amounts to ₹ 249.36 Lakhs; or \n(b) Two (2) percent of net worth, as per the latest annual restated financial statements of the Company, which amounts to ₹ 47.21 Lakhs; or \n(c) Five (5) percent of the average of absolute value of profit or loss after tax, as per the last three annual restated financial statements of the Company, which amounts to ₹ 28.78 Lakhs. \n \nFor the purposes of the above, pre-litigation notices received by the Relevant Parties from third parties \n(excluding those notices issued by statutory or regulatory or taxation authorities or notices threatening \ncriminal action) have not and shall not, unless otherwise decided by our Board, be considered material \nuntil such time that any of the Relevant Parties or the Group Company, as the case may be, is \nimpleaded as a defendant in litigation before any judicial or arbitral forum. \n \nFurther, in accordance with the Materiality Policy, our Company has considered such creditors \n‘material’ to whom the amount due is equal to or in excess of ₹ 5,00,000/-. \n \nOur Company has no subsidiary as of the date of this Red Herring Prospectus. \n \nUnless stated to the contrary, the information provided below is as of the date of this Red Herring \nProspectus. (“Everest”) \nfiled a suit against our Company under the Trademarks Act, 1999 before the Hon’ble \nBombay High Court on April 20, 2021, seeking a permanent injunction to restrain the \nCompany from using the registered trademark ‘TIKHALAL’. Everest alleged trademark \ninfringement through the sale of the Company’s product “SHYAM TIKHA LAL” and claimed \n₹ 5 crore in damages or profits earned from the infringing sales, along with the delivery and \ndestruction of all products containing ‘TIKHALAL’. In response, our Company contended \nthat ‘SHYAM TIKHA LAL’ has been in continuous use since 1995 and was registered in 2015, \narguing that ‘TIKHA’ and ‘LAL’ are common descriptive Hindi words that cannot be \nmonopolized. The Company denied any infringement or passing off, asserting that the \nmarks are distinct and unlikely to cause consumer confusion. Anwar Khan and Shyam Dhani Industries [Case No. - 1/2024 – 40123] \nShyam Dhani Industries, Sole Propertiroship firm of our Promoter Mr. Ramawtar Agarwal \nreceived two show cause notices dated May 21, 2024, and September 21, 2024, from the Court \nof Adjudication Officer under Section 68 read with Section 52 of the Food Safety and Standards \nAct, 2006, alleging that their product “Shyam Garam Masala” was found to be “misbranded” \nbased on the Analysis Report from the Food Safety Office, Himachal Pradesh, regarding samples \ncollected from Mr. Anwar Khan, who had purchased the product from D-MART, Zirakpur. \n \nIn response, Shyam Dhani Industries denied any connection with Anwar Khan and asserted that \nthe misbranded product in his possession was actually some other company’s salted peanuts \nand not their product. The matter is currently pending adjudication. \n \n(ii) Government through Narendra Sharma, Food Safety Officer, Office of the Chief Medical and Health Officer, Jaipur Vs. Shri Chand Prakash Sharma, M/s Shyam Dhani Industries [313/2025] \nOffice of the Chief Medical and Health Officer, Jaipur has filed a case on May 08, 2025 against \nM/s Shyam Dhani Industries (sole proprietorship firm of our Promoter, Mr. Ramawtar Agarwal, \nrepresented by Mr. Chandra Prakash Sharma, seller and nominee) under section 26 and 59(i) of \nthe Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006. The matter pertains to a search conducted on 25 April \n2024 at premises of M/s. Shyam Dhani Industries by the Food Safety Officer, Department of \nMedical & Health Services, Rajasthan. \n \nDuring the search, 20 packets of 100 grams each of Garam Masala were collected for testing. As \nper Test Report No. LS/1533/Act/2024/2113 dated 5 June 2024 issued by the State Central \nPublic Health Laboratory, Jaipur, Rajasthan, the product samples were classified as “Unsafe \nFood”. Based on this report, it was alleged that Mr. Chandra Prakash Sharma, nominee of M/s \nShyam Dhani Industries had violated Section 26 of the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006, by \nselling unsafe Garam Masala packets, making them liable for penalties under Section 59(i) of the \nsaid Act. The court granted bail to Mr. Chandra Prakash Sharma on June 17, 2025. The matter is \ncurrently pending for adjudication. MECHANISM FOR INVESTOR GRIEVANCES AND REDRESSAL SYSTEM Our Company has appointed Bigshare Services Private Limited as the Registrar to the Issue, to handle \nthe investor grievances in co-ordination with the Compliance Officer of the Company. All grievances \nrelating to the present Issue may be addressed to the Registrar with a copy to the Compliance Officer, \ngiving full details such as name, address of the applicant, UPI ID (if applicable), number of Equity Shares \napplied for, amount paid on application and name of bank and branch. The Company would monitor \nthe work of the Registrar to ensure that the investor grievances are settled expeditiously and \nsatisfactorily. \n \nThe Registrar to the Issue, namely, Bigshare Services Private Limited, will handle investor’s grievances \npertaining to the Issue. A fortnightly status report of the complaints received and redressed by them \nwould be forwarded to the Company. The Company would also be co-coordinating with the Registrar \nto the Issue in attending to the grievances to the investor. \n \nAll grievances relating to the ASBA process may be addressed to the SCSBs, giving full details such as \nname, address of the applicant, number of Equity Shares applied for, amount paid on application and \nthe Designated Branch of the SCSB where the Application Form was submitted by the Applicant. We \nestimate that the average time required by us or the Registrar to the Issue or the SCSBs for the \nredressal of routine investor grievances will be seven (7) business days from the date of receipt of the \ncomplaint. In case of non-routine complaints and complaints where external agencies are involved, \nwe will seek to redress these complaints as expeditiously as possible. \n \nOur Company will constitute Stakeholders Relationship Committee in the meeting of our Board of \nDirector(s) before listing of Equity Shares on Stock Exchange. For further details on the Committees, \nplease refer to the section titled “Our Management-Corporate Governance” beginning on page 202. Our Company has appointed Ms. Ambika Sharma as the Company Secretary and Compliance Officer \nto redress the complaints, if any, of the investors participating in the Issue. Contact details for our \nCompliance Officer are as follows: \n \nName: Ms. Ambika Sharma \nAddress: A-28, Shyam Mitra, Mandal Road No. 5, Sikar Road, Jaipur, Rajasthan -302013 \nTel: +91 - 9257061811 \nEmail: cs@shyamspices.co.in  \nWebsite: www.shyamspices.co.in  \n \nInvestors can contact the Compliance Officer or the Registrar to the Issue in case of any pre- Issue or \npost-Issue related problems such as non-receipt of letters of Allotment, credit of allotted Equity Shares \nin the respective beneficiary account or refund orders, etc. Pursuant to the press release no. PR. No. \n85/2011 dated 8th June 2011, SEBI has launched a centralized web-based complaints redress system \n“SCORES”. This would enable investors to lodge and follow up their complaints and track the status of \nredressal of such complaints from anywhere. For more details, investors are requested to visit the \nwebsite www.scores.gov.in. \n \nSTATUS OF INVESTOR COMPLAINTS We confirm that we have not received any investor complaint during the three (3) years preceding the \ndate of this Red Herring Prospectus and hence there are no pending investor complaints as on the \ndate of this Red Herring Prospectus.
