DISPOSAL OF INVESTOR GRIEVANCES BY OUR COMPANY Our Company estimates that the average time required by our Company or the Registrar to the Issue \nor the relevant Designated Intermediary, for the redressal of routine investor grievances shall be seven \n(7) Working Days from the date of receipt of the complaint. In case of non-routine complaints and \ncomplaints where external agencies are involved, our Company will seek to redress these complaints \nas expeditiously as possible.  \n \nIMPERSONATION \n \nAttention of the Applicants is specifically drawn to the provisions of sub-section (1) of Section 38 of \nthe Companies Act, 2013 which is reproduced below: \n \n“Any person who – a) makes or abets making of an application in a fictitious name to a company for acquiring, or subscribing for, its securities, or \nb) makes or abets making of multiple applications to a company in different names or in different combinations of his name or surname for acquiring or subscribing for its securities; or \nc) otherwise induces directly or indirectly a company to allot, or register any transfer of, securities to him, or to any other person in a fictitious name, shall be liable for action under section 447.” \n \nThe liability prescribed under Section 447 of the Companies Act, 2013, includes frauds involving an \namount of at least ₹ 10,00,000/- or one per cent. of the turnover of our Company, whichever is lower, \nimprisonment for a term of not less than six (6) months extending up to ten (10) years (provided that \nwhere the fraud involves public interest, such term shall not be less than three (3) years) and fine of \nan amount not less than the amount involved in the fraud, extending up to three times of such \namount. Where the fraud involves an amount less than ₹ 10,00,000/- (Rupees Ten Lakh only) or one \npercent (1%) of the turnover of our Company, whichever is lower, and does not involve public interest, \nany person guilty of such fraud shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend \nto five (5) years or with fine which may extend to ₹ 50,00,000/- or with both. \n \nEXEMPTION FROM COMPLYING WITH ANY PROVISIONS OF SECURITIES LAWS, IF ANY, GRANTED BY \nSEBI \n \nThe Company has not sought for any exemptions from complying with any provisions of securities \nlaws granted by SEBI. Page 320 of 402 SECTION VIII – ISSUE INFORMATION TERMS OF THE ISSUE \n \nThe Equity Shares being issued pursuant to this Issue shall be subject to the provisions of the Companies \nAct, 2013, SEBI ICDR Regulations, SCRA, SCRR, the Memorandum and Articles of Association, the SEBI \nListing Regulations, the terms of the Red Herring Prospectus, the Abridged Prospectus, Bid cum \nApplication Form, the Revision Form, the CAN/ the Allotment Advice and other terms and conditions \nas may be incorporated in the Allotment Advices and other documents/certificates that may be \nexecuted in respect of the Issue. The Equity Shares shall also be subject to laws, as applicable, \nguidelines, rules, notifications and regulations relating to the Issue of capital and listing and trading of \nsecurities issued from time to time by SEBI, the Government of India, the FIPB, the Stock Exchange, the \nRBI, RoC and/or other authorities, as in force on the date of the Issue and to the extent applicable or \nsuch other conditions as may be prescribed by SEBI, the RBI, the Government of India, the FIPB, the \nStock Exchange, the RoC and any other authorities while granting their approval for the Issue. \n \nIn terms of SEBI Circular No. CIR/CFD/POLICYCELL/11/2015 dated November 10, 2015 and the SEBI \n(Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2018, all the investors (except Anchor \nInvestors) applying in a public Issue shall use only Application Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) \nprocess for application providing details of the bank account which will be blocked by the Self Certified \nSyndicate \nBanks \n(SCSBs) \nfor \nthe \nsame. \nFurther, \npursuant \nto \nSEBI \nCircular \nNo. \nSEBI/HO/CFD/DIL2/CIR/P/2018/138 dated November 01, 2018, Individual Investors applying in public \nIssue may use either Application Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) facility for making application \nor also can use UPI as a payment mechanism with Application Supported by Blocked Amount for \nmaking application. \n \nFurther vide the said circular Registrar to the Issue and Depository Participants have been also \nauthorized to collect the Application forms. Investors may visit the official website of the concerned \nstock exchange for any information on operation of this facility of form collection by Registrar to the \nIssue and DPs as and when the same is made available. \n \nAUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUE \n \n \nThe Issue of Equity Shares has been authorized by the Board of the Directors of our Company at their \nmeeting held on February 01, 2025, and was approved by the Shareholders of the Company by passing \na Special Resolution at the Extra Ordinary General Meeting held on February 25, 2025, in accordance \nwith provisions of the Companies Act, 2013. \n \nRANKING OF EQUITY SHARES \n \nThe Equity Shares being issued and transferred in the Issue shall be subject to the provisions of the \nCompanies Act, 2013, our Memorandum and Articles of Association, SEBI Listing Regulations, SEBI \nICDR Regulations, SCRA and shall rank pari-passu with the existing Equity Shares of our Company \nincluding rights in respect of dividend. The Allottees upon receipt of Allotment of Equity Shares under \nthis Issue will be entitled to dividends and other corporate benefits, if any, declared by our Company \nafter the date of Allotment in accordance with Companies Act, 2013 and the Articles. For further \ndetails, please refer to the section titled “Main Provisions of Articles of Association” beginning on \npage 362. \n \nMODE OF PAYMENT OF DIVIDEND \n \nThe declaration and payment of dividend will be as per the provisions of Companies Act, 2013, SEBI \n(Listing Obligation & Disclosure Requirements) Regulation, 2015, the Memorandum and Articles of \nAssociation and recommended by the Board of Directors at their discretion and approved by the \nshareholders and will depend on a number of factors, including but not limited to earnings, capital Page 321 of 402 requirements and overall financial condition of our Company. All dividends, declared by our Company \nafter the date of Allotment (pursuant to the Allotment of Issued Shares), will be payable to the bidders \nwho have been allotted Issued Shares, for the entire year, in accordance with applicable law.  \n \nFor further details, please refer to the chapter titled “Dividend Policy” beginning on page 219. \n \nFACE VALUE AND ISSUE PRICE PER SHARE \n \nThe face value of the Equity Shares is ₹ 10/- each and the Issue Price at the lower end of Price Band is \n₹ [●] per Equity Share and at the higher end of the Price Band is ₹ [●] per Equity Share. The Anchor \nInvestor Issue Price is ₹ [●] per Equity Share. \n \nThe Price Band and the minimum Bid Lot size for the Issue will be decided by our Company in \nconsultation with the Book Running Lead Manager and advertised in all editions of Financial Express, \nEnglish national daily newspaper and all editions of Jansatta, Hindi daily newspaper and all editions of \nNafa Nuksaan, regional  daily newspaper in Jaipur, Rajasthan (Hindi also being the regional language \nof Jaipur, Rajasthan where our Registered and Corporate Office is located), each with wide circulation, \nat least two Working Days prior to the Bid/Issue Opening Date and shall be made available to the Stock \nExchange for the purpose of uploading the same on its websites.  \n \nThe Price Band, along with the relevant financial ratios calculated at the Floor Price and at the Cap \nPrice, shall be prefilled in the Bid cum Application Forms available on the website of the Stock \nExchange. \n \nAt any given point of time there shall be only one denomination of Equity Shares. \n \nCompliance with SEBI ICDR Regulations, 2018  \nOur Company shall comply with all requirements of the SEBI (ICDR) Regulations. In this context, two agreements have been signed amongst our \nCompany, the respective Depositories and the Registrar to the Issue: \n \n▪ \nTripartite Agreement dated November 29, 2024 amongst NSDL, our Company and the Registrar \nto the Issue; and \n \n▪ \nTripartite Agreement dated December 12, 2024 amongst CDSL, our Company and the Registrar to \nthe Issue. \n \nSince trading of the Equity Shares is in dematerialized form, the tradable lot is [●] Equity Shares of \nface value of ₹ 10 each. A person, being a nominee, entitled to the Equity Shares by \nreason of the death of the original holder(s), shall be entitled to the same advantages to which he or \nshe would be entitled if he or she were the registered holder of the Equity Share(s). Where the \nnominee is a minor, the holder(s) may make a nomination to appoint, in the prescribed manner, any Page 323 of 402 person to become entitled to equity share(s) in the event of his or her death during the minority. A \nnomination shall stand rescinded upon a sale / transfer / alienation of equity share(s) by the person \nnominating. A buyer will be entitled to make a fresh nomination in the manner prescribed. Fresh \nnomination can be made only on the prescribed form available on request at our Registered Office or \nwith the registrar and transfer agents of our Company. \n \nAny person who becomes a nominee by virtue of the provisions of Section 72 of the Companies Act, \n2013, shall upon the production of such evidence as may be required by the Board, elect either: \n \na) To register himself or herself as the holder of the Equity Shares; or  \nb) To make such transfer of the Equity Shares, as the deceased holder could have made. Further, the Board may at any time give notice requiring any nominee to choose either to be registered \nhimself or herself or to transfer the Equity Shares, and if the notice is not complied with within a period \nof ninety days, the Board may thereafter withhold payment of all dividends, bonuses or other moneys \npayable in respect of the Equity Shares, until the requirements of the notice have been complied with. \n \nSince the Allotment of Equity Shares in the Issue will be made only in dematerialized mode there is no \nneed to make a separate nomination with our Company. Nominations registered with respective \ndepository participant of the bidder would prevail. If the investor wants to change the nomination, \nthey are requested to inform their respective depository participant. \n \nWITHDRAWAL OF THE ISSUE \n \nOur Company, in consultation with the Book Running Lead Manager, reserves the right to not proceed \nwith the Issue after the Issue Opening Date but before the allotment. In such an event, our Company \nwould issue a public notice in the newspapers in which the pre–Issue and price band advertisements \nwere published, within two days of the Issue Closing Date or such other time as may be prescribed by \nSEBI, providing reasons for not proceeding with the Issue. The Book Running Lead Manager through, \nthe Registrar to the Issue, shall notify the SCSBs and the Sponsor Bank to unblock the bank accounts \nof the ASBA Bidders within one Working Day from the date of receipt of such notification. Our \nCompany shall also inform the same to the Stock Exchanges on which Equity Shares are proposed to \nbe listed.  \n \nNotwithstanding the foregoing, this Issue is also subject to obtaining (i) the final listing and trading \napprovals of the Stock Exchange, which our Company shall apply for after Allotment, and (ii) the final \nRoC approval of the Prospectus after it is registered with the RoC. If our Company withdraws the Issue \nafter the Issue Closing Date and thereafter determines that it will proceed with an Issue of the Equity \nShares, our Company shall file a fresh Draft Red Herring Prospectus with Stock Exchange. \n \nISSUE PROGRAMME \n \nAn indicative timetable in respect of the Issue is set out below: Event \nIndicative Date \nIssue Opening Date \nMonday, December 22, 2025 \nBid / Issue Closing Date \nWednesday, December 24, 2025 \nFinalization of Basis of Allotment with the Designated Stock Exchange \nOn or before Friday, December 26, 2025 \nInitiation of Allotment / Refunds / Unblocking of Funds from ASBA \nAccount or UPI ID linked bank account* \nOn or before Monday, December 29, 2025 Credit of Equity Shares to Demat Accounts of Allottees \nOn or before Monday, December 29, 2025 \nCommencement of trading of Equity Shares on the Stock Exchange \nTuesday, December 30, 2025 \nNote:  \n1. Page 324 of 402 *In accordance with SEBI circular dated March 16, 2021 and thereafter on June 02, 2021, for IPOs opening \nsubsequent to May 1, 2021 (or any other date as prescribed by SEBI) In case of (i) any delay in unblocking of \namounts in the ASBA Accounts (including amounts blocked through the UPI Mechanism) for cancelled/ \nwithdrawn/deleted ASBA Forms, the Bidder shall be compensated by the SCSB at a uniform rate of ₹ 100/- per \nday or 15% per annum of the Bid Amount, whichever is higher from the date on which the request for \ncancellation/ withdrawal/ deletion is placed in the Stock Exchanges bidding platform until the date on which the \namounts are unblocked; (ii) any blocking of multiple amounts for the same ASBA Form (for amounts blocked \nthrough the UPI Mechanism), the Bidder shall be compensated by the SCSB at a uniform rate ₹ 100/-per day or \n15% per annum of the total cumulative blocked amount except the original application amount, whichever is \nhigher from the date on which such multiple amounts were blocked till the date of actual unblock; (iii) any \nblocking of amounts more than the Bid Amount, the Bidder shall be compensated by the SCSB at a uniform rate \nof ₹ 100/- per day or 15% per annum of the difference in amount, whichever is higher from the date on which \nsuch excess amounts were blocked till the date of actual unblock; (iv) any delay in unblocking of non-allotted/ \npartially allotted Bids, exceeding two Working Days from the Bid/Issue Closing Date, the Bidder shall be \ncompensated by the SCSB at a uniform rate of ₹ 100/-per day or 15% per annum of the Bid Amount, whichever \nis higher for the entire duration of delay exceeding two Working Days from the Bid/ Issue Closing Date till the \ndate of the actual unblock. The SCSBs shall compensate the Bidder, immediately on the date of receipt of \ncomplaint from the Bidder. From the date of receipt of complaint from the Bidder, in addition to the \ncompensation to be paid by the SCSBs as above, the post-Issue BRLM shall be liable for compensating the Bidder \nat a uniform rate of ₹ 100/- per day or 15% per annum of the Bid Amount, whichever is higher from the date of \non which grievance is received by the BRLM or Registrar until the date on which the blocked amounts are \nunblocked. \n \nThe above timetable is indicative and does not constitute any obligation or liability on our Company, \nand the BRLM. Whilst our Company shall ensure that all steps for the completion of the necessary \nformalities for the listing and the commencement of trading of the Equity Shares on the Stock \nExchange are taken within 6 Working Days of the Bid / Issue Closing Date, the timetable may change \ndue to various factors, such as extension of the Bid / Issue Period by our Company, revision of the \nPrice Band or any delays in receiving the final listing and trading approval from the Stock Exchange. \nThe Commencement of trading of the Equity Shares will be entirely at the discretion of the Stock \nExchange and in accordance with the applicable laws. \n \nIn case of any delay in unblocking of amounts in the ASBA Accounts (including amounts blocked \nthrough the UPI Mechanism) exceeding four Working Days from the Bid/Issue Closing Date, the \nBidder shall be compensated at a uniform rate of ₹ 100 per day for the entire duration of delay \nexceeding two Working Days from the Bid/Issue Closing Date by the intermediary responsible for \ncausing such delay in unblocking. The Issue is being made under \nRegulation 229(2) of Chapter IX of SEBI (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, \n2018 via book building process. \n \nThe allocation to the public will be made as per Regulation 253 of SEBI ICDR Regulations, wherein not \nmore than 50% of the Net Issue shall be allocated on a proportionate basis to QIBs. Further, 5% of the \nQIB Portion shall be available for allocation on a proportionate basis only to Mutual Funds, and the \nremainder of the QIB Portion shall be available for allocation on a proportionate basis to all QIBs, \nincluding Mutual Funds, subject to valid Bids being received at or above the Issue Price. Further, not \nless than 15% of the Net Issue shall be available for allocation on a proportionate basis to Non-\nInstitutional Investors and not less than 35% of the Net Issue shall be available for allocation to \nIndividual Investors in accordance with the SEBI ICDR Regulations, subject to valid Bids being received \nat or above the Issue Price.  \n \nAccordingly, we have allocated the Net Issue i.e., not less than 35% of the Net Issue shall be available \nfor allocation to Individual Bidders and not less than 15% of the Net Issue shall be available for \nallocation to Non institutional bidders and not more than 50% of the Net Issue shall be allocated on a \nproportionate basis to QIBs subject to valid Bids being received at or above the Issue Price, if any. Page 334 of 402 Under subscription, if any, in any category, except the QIB Portion, would be allowed to be met with \nspill-over from any other category or a combination of categories at the discretion of our Company \nand in consultation with the BRLMs and the Stock Exchange. However, under-subscription, if any, in \nthe QIB Portion will not be allowed to be met with spill-over from other categories or a combination \nof categories. \n \nThe Equity Shares, on Allotment, shall be traded only in the dematerialized segment of the Stock \nExchanges. \n \nBidders should note that the Equity Shares will be allotted to all successful Bidders only in \ndematerialized form. Pursuant to the SEBI UPI Circulars, the UPI mechanism has been introduced in \na phased manner as a payment mechanism (in addition to mechanism of blocking funds in the account \nmaintained with SCSBs under the ASBA) for Bids by UPI Bidders through designated intermediaries \nwith the objective to reduce the time duration from public issue closure to listing from six Working \nDays to up to three Working Days. Considering the time required for making necessary changes to the \nsystems and to ensure complete and smooth transition to the UPI payment Mechanism, the SEBI UPI \nCircular have introduced the UPI Mechanism in three phases in the following manner: \n \n• \nPhase I: This phase was applicable from January 1, 2019 until March 31, 2019 or floating of five \nmain board public issues, whichever was later. Subsequently, the timeline for implementation of \nPhase I was extended till June 30, 2019. Under this phase, a Individual Bidder had the option to \nsubmit the ASBA Form with any of the designated intermediaries and use his / her UPI ID for the \npurpose of blocking of funds. The time duration from public issue closure to listing continue to be \nsix Working Days. \n \n• \nPhase II: This phase has become applicable from July 1, 2019 and was to initially continue for a \nperiod of three months or floating of five main board public issues, whichever is later. SEBI, vide \nits circular no. SEBI/HO/CFD/DCR2/CIR/P/2019/133 dated November 8, 2019 has decided to \nextend the timeline for implementation of UPI Phase II until March 31, 2020. Subsequently, SEBI, \nvide its circular no. SEBI/HO/CFD/DIL2/CIR/P/2020/50 dated March 30, 2020 extended the \ntimeline for implementation of UPI Phase II till further notice. Under this phase, submission of the \nASBA Form by UPI Bidders through Designated Intermediaries (other than SCSBs) to SCSBs for \nblocking of funds has been discontinued and replaced by the UPI Mechanism. However, the time \nduration from public issue closure to listing continues to be six Working Days during this phase. • \nPhase III:  This phase has become applicable on a voluntary basis for all issues opening on or after \nSeptember 1, 2023, and on a mandatory basis for all issues opening on or after December 1, 2023, \nvide SEBI circular bearing number SEBI/HO/CFD/TPD1/CIR/P/2023/140 dated August 9, 2023 \n(\"T+3 Notification”). In this phase, the time duration from public issue closure to listing has been \nreduced to three Working Days. The Issue shall be undertaken pursuant to the processes and \nprocedures as notified in the T+3 Notification as applicable, subject to any circulars, clarification \nor notification issued by the SEBI from time to time, including any circular, clarification or \nnotification which may be issued by SEBI. Page 335 of 402 Pursuant to the SEBI UPI Circular, SEBI has set out specific requirements for redressal of investor \ngrievances for applications that have been made through the UPI Mechanism. The requirements of \nthe SEBI UPI Circular include, appointment of a nodal officer by the SCSB and submission of their \ndetails to SEBI, the requirement for SCSBs to send SMS alerts for the blocking and unblocking of UPI \nmandates, the requirement for the Registrar to submit details of cancelled, withdrawn or deleted \napplications, and the requirement for the bank accounts of unsuccessful Bidders to be unblocked not \nlater than one day from the date on which the Basis of Allotment is finalised. Failure to unblock the \naccounts within the timeline would result in the SCSBs being penalised under the relevant securities \nlaw. Additionally, if there is any delay in the redressal of investors’ complaints in this regard, the \nrelevant SCSB as well as the post – Issue BRLM will be required to compensate the concerned investor. \n \nThe Issue will be made under UPI Phase III of the SEBI UPI Circulars and the same will be advertised in \nall editions of Financial Express, English national daily newspaper and all editions of Jansatta, Hindi \nnational daily newspaper and all editions of Nafa Nuksaan, regional daily newspaper in Jaipur, \nRajasthan (Hindi also being the regional language of Jaipur, where our Registered and Corporate Office \nis located), each with wide circulation, on or prior to the Bid/ Issue Opening Date and such \nadvertisement shall also be made available to the Stock Exchanges for the purpose of uploading on \ntheir websites. \n \nAll SCSBs offering the facility of making applications in public issues shall also provide the facility to \nmake application using UPI. Provided that the aggregate ceiling of 10% \nmay be raised to 24% if a special resolution to that effect is passed by the general body of the Indian \ncompany. \n \nEligible NRIs will be permitted to apply in the Issue through Channel I or Channel II (as specified in the \nSEBI UPI Circulars). Further, subject to applicable law, Eligible NRIs may use Channel IV (as specified in \nthe SEBI UPI Circulars) to apply in the Issue, provided the UPI facility is enabled for their NRE/NRO \naccounts. \n \nFor details of restrictions on investment by NRIs, see “Restrictions on Foreign Ownership of Indian \nSecurities” beginning on page 359. \n \nParticipation of Eligible NRIs in the Issue shall be subject to the FEMA Rules. With effect from April 1, 2020, \nthe aggregate limit by FPIs shall be the sectoral caps applicable to the Indian company as prescribed \nin the FEMA Rules with respect to its paid-up equity capital on a fully diluted basis. While the aggregate \nlimit as provided above could have been decreased by the concerned Indian companies to a lower \nthreshold limit of 24% or 49% or 74% as deemed fit, with the approval of its board of directors and its \nshareholders through a resolution and a special resolution, respectively before March 31, 2020, our \nCompany has not decreased such limit and accordingly the applicable limit with respect to our \nCompany is 100%. In terms of the FEMA Rules, for calculating the aggregate holding of FPIs in a \ncompany, holding of all registered FPIs shall be included. \n \nIn case of Bids made by FPIs, a certified copy of the certificate of registration issued under the SEBI FPI \nRegulations is required to be attached to the Bid cum Application Form, failing which our Company, in \nconsultation with the Book Running Lead Manager, reserves the right to reject any Bid without \nassigning any reason. Page 341 of 402 An FPI issuing offshore derivate instruments is also required to ensure that any transfer of offshore \nderivative instrument is made by, or on behalf of it subject to, among others, the following conditions: a) each offshore derivative instruments are transferred to persons subject to fulfilment of SEBI FPI Regulations; and \nb) prior consent of the FPI is obtained for such transfer, except when the persons to whom the offshore derivative instruments are to be transferred to are pre-approved by the FPI. \n \nFurther, Bids by following FPIs, submitted with the same PAN but with different beneficiary account \nnumbers, Client IDs and DP IDs may not be regarded as multiple Bids: \n \n• FPIs which utilise the multi-investment manager (“MIM”) structure. \n• Offshore derivative instruments (“ODI”) which have obtained separate FPI registration for ODI and proprietary derivative investments. \n• Sub funds or separate class of investors with segregated portfolio who obtain separate FPI registration. \n• FPI registrations granted at investment strategy level/sub fund level where a collective investment scheme or fund has multiple investment strategies/sub-funds with identifiable differences and \nmanaged by a single investment manager. \n• Multiple branches in different jurisdictions of foreign bank registered as FPIs. \n• Government and Government related investors registered as Category I FPIs. \n• Entities registered as collective investment scheme having multiple share classes. The Bids belonging to the aforesaid seven structures and having same PAN may be collated and \nidentified as a single Bid in the Bidding process. Post the repeal \nof the SEBI VCF Regulations, the VCFs which have not re-registered as an AIF under the SEBI AIF \nRegulations shall continue to be regulated by the SEBI VCF Regulations until the existing fund or \nscheme managed by the fund is wound up and such fund shall not launch any new scheme after the \nnotification of the SEBI AIF Regulations. The SEBI FVCI Regulations prescribe the investment \nrestrictions on FVCIs. Category I AIFs and Category II AIFs cannot invest more than 25% of the investible \nfunds in one investee company directly or through investment in the units of other AIFs. A category III \nAIF cannot invest more than 10% of the investible funds in one investee company directly or through \ninvestment in the units of other AIFs. A VCF registered as a Category I AIF, as defined in the SEBI AIF \nRegulations, cannot invest more than one-third of its investible funds by way of subscription to an \ninitial public offering of a venture capital undertaking. \n \nThe holding in any company by any individual VCF or FVCI registered with SEBI should not exceed 25% \nof the corpus of the VCF or FVCI. Further, VCFs and FVCIs can invest only up to 33.33% of the investible \nfunds in various prescribed instruments, including in initial public offerings. \n \nFurther, the shareholding of VCFs, Category I AIFs or Category II AIFs and FVCIs in a company prior to \nan initial public offering being undertaken by such company, shall be exempt from lock-in \nrequirements, provided that such equity shares shall be locked in for a period of at least six months \nfrom the date of purchase by the VCF or AIF or FVCI. However, if such VCFs, Category I AIFs or Category Page 342 of 402 II AIFs and FVCIs hold individually or with persons acting in concert, more than 20% of the pre-issue \nshareholding of such company, this exemption from lock-in requirements will not be applicable. \n \nThere is no reservation for Eligible NRIs, AIFs, FPIs and FVCIs. All such Bidders will be treated on the \nsame basis with other categories for the purpose of allocation. However, this cap does not apply to the cases \nmentioned in (i) and (ii) above. \n \nFurther, the aggregate investment by a banking company in all its subsidiaries and other entities \nengaged in financial services and non-financial services, including overseas investments, cannot \nexceed 20% of the banking company’s paid-up share capital and reserves. \n \nThe banking company is required to submit a time-bound action plan for disposal of such shares within \na specified period to RBI. A banking company would require a prior approval of RBI to make (i) \ninvestment in a subsidiary or a financial services company that is not a subsidiary (with certain \nexceptions prescribed), and (ii) investment in a non-financial services company in excess of 10% of \nsuch investee company’s paid-up share capital as stated in para 5(a)(v)(c)(i) of the Reserve Bank of \nIndia (Financial Services provided by Banks) Directions, 2016, as amended. Failing this, our \nCompany, in consultation with the Book Running Lead Manager, reserves the right to reject any Bid \nwithout assigning any reason thereof. The exposure norms for insurers are prescribed under \nRegulation 9 of the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (Investment) \nRegulations, 2016 (“IRDAI Investment Regulations”), and are based on investments in the equity \nshares of a company, the entire group of the investee company and the industry sector in which the \ninvestee company operates. Bidders are advised to refer to the IRDAI Investment Regulations 2016, \nas amended, which are broadly set forth below: (a) equity shares of a company: the lower of 10%* of the outstanding equity shares (face value) or 10% of the respective fund in case of life insurer or 10% of investment assets in case of general \ninsurer or reinsurer; \n(b) the entire group of the investee company: not more than 15% of the respective fund in case of a life insurer or 15% of investment assets in case of a general insurer or reinsurer or 15% of the \ninvestment assets in all companies belonging to the group, whichever is lower; and \n(c) the industry sector in which the investee company operates: not more than 15% of the fund of a life insurer or a general insurer or a reinsurer or 15% of the investment asset, whichever is lower. \n \nThe maximum exposure limit, in the case of an investment in equity shares, cannot exceed the lower \nof an amount of 10% of the investment assets of a life insurer or general insurer and the amount \ncalculated under (a), (b) and (c) above, as the case may be. \n \n*The above limit of 10% shall stand substituted as 15% of outstanding equity shares (face value) for \ninsurance companies with investment assets of ₹ 2,50,00,000 Lakhs or more and 12% of outstanding \nequity shares (face value) for insurers with investment assets of ₹ 5,00,00,000 Lakhs or more but less \nthan ₹ 2,50,00,000 Lakhs. \n \nInsurance companies participating in this Issue shall comply with all applicable regulations, guidelines \nand circulars issued by IRDAI, from time to time, including the IRDAI Investment Regulations for \nspecific investment limits applicable to them. \n \nBIDS BY NBFC-SI \n \nIn case of Bids made by NBFC-SI, a certified copy of the certificate of registration issued by RBI, a \ncertified copy of its last audited financial statements on a standalone basis and a net worth certificate \nfrom its statutory auditor(s), must be attached to the Bid cum Application Form. No Individual Investors who applies for minimum \napplication size will be allotted less than the minimum Bid Lot subject to availability of shares in \nIndividual Investors who applies for minimum application size Category and the remaining available \nshares, if any will be allotted on a proportionate basis. The Issue was 100% underwritten. \n \nFlow of Events from the closure of Bidding period (T DAY) Till Allotment: \n• On T Day, RTA to validate the electronic bid details with the depository records and also reconcile the final certificates received from the Sponsor Bank for UPI process and the SCSBs for ASBA and \nSyndicate ASBA process with the electronic bid details. \n• RTA identifies cases with mismatch of account number as per bid file / FC and as per applicant’s bank account linked to depository demat account and seek clarification from SCSB to identify the \napplications with third party account for rejection. \n• Third party confirmation of applications to be completed by SCSBs on T+1 day. \n• RTA prepares the list of final rejections and circulate the rejections list with BRLM/ Company for their review/ comments. \n• Post rejection, the RTA submits the basis of allotment with the Designated Stock Exchange (DSE). \n• The DSE, post verification approves the basis and generates drawal of lots wherever applicable, through a random number generation software. \n• The RTA uploads the drawal numbers in their system and generates the final list of allotees as per process mentioned below: Process for generating list of Allottees \n• Instruction is given by RTA in their Software System to reverse category wise all the application numbers in the ascending order and generate the bucket /batch as per the allotment ratio. For \n• example, if the application number is 78654321 then system reverses it to 12345687 and if the ratio of allottees to applicants in a category is 2:7 then the system will create lots of 7. If the drawal \nof lots provided by Designated Stock Exchange (DSE) is 3 and 5 then the system will pick every 3rd \nand 5th application in each of the lot of the category and these applications will be allotted the \nshares in that category. \n• In categories where there is proportionate allotment, the Registrar will prepare the proportionate working based on the oversubscription times. \n• In categories where there is undersubscription, the Registrar will do full allotment for all valid applications. On the basis of the above, the RTA will work out the allotees, partial allotees and non- \nallottees, prepare the fund transfer letters and advice the SCSBs to debit or unblock the respective \naccounts. Further, upon oversubscription, an Allotment of not more than \n10% of the Net Issue may be made for the purpose of making Allotment in minimum Bid Lots. \nThe Allotment of Equity Shares to applicants other than to the Individual Investors, Non-Institutional \nInvestors and Anchor Investors shall be on a proportionate basis within the respective investor \ncategories and the number of securities allotted shall be rounded off to the nearest integer, subject \nto minimum Allotment being equal to the minimum application size as, determined and disclosed. \n \nThe Allotment of Equity Shares to each Individual Investor and Non-Institutional Investor shall not be \nless than the minimum Bid Lot, subject to the availability of Equity Shares in the Individual Investor \ncategory and the Non-Institutional Category, respectively, and the remaining available Equity Shares, \nif any, shall be Allotted on a proportionate basis. \n \nPAYMENT INTO ESCROW ACCOUNT FOR ANCHOR INVESTORS  \n \nOur Company, in consultation with the Book Running Lead Managers in their absolute discretion, will \ndecide the list of Anchor Investors to whom the CAN will be sent, pursuant to which the details of the \nEquity Shares allocated to them in their respective names will be notified to such Anchor Investors. \nAnchor Investors are not permitted to Bid in the Issue through the ASBA process. PRICE DISCOVERY AND ALLOCATION \n \na) Based on the demand generated at various price levels, our Company in consultation with the BRLM shall finalize the Issue Price. \n \nb) The SEBI ICDR Regulations, 2018 specify the allocation or Allotment that may be made to various categories of Bidders in an Issue depending on compliance with the eligibility conditions. Certain \ndetails pertaining to the percentage of Issue size available for allocation to each category is \ndisclosed overleaf of the Bid cum Application Form and in the RHP. For details in relation to \nallocation, the Bidder may refer to the Red Herring Prospectus. c) Under-subscription in any category (except QIB Category) is allowed to be met with spill over from any other category or combination of categories at the discretion of the Issuer in consultation with \nthe BRLM and the Designated Stock Exchange and in accordance with the SEBI ICDR Regulations. \nUnsubscribed portion in QIB Category is not available for subscription to other categories. \n \nd) In case of under subscription in the Issue, spill-over to the extent of such under-subscription may be permitted from the Reserved Portion to the Issue. For allocation in the event of an under-\nsubscription applicable to the Issuer, Bidders may refer to the Red Herring Prospectus. e) Allocation to Anchor Investors, if applicable shall be at the discretion of our Company and in consultation with the BRLM, subject to compliance with the SEBI Regulations. \n \nIllustration of the Book Building and Price Discovery Process \nBidders should note that this example is solely for illustrative purposes and is not specific to the Issue. \n \nBidders can bid at any price within the Price Band. For instance, assume a Price Band of ₹ 20/- to ₹ \n24/- per share, Issue size of 3,000 Equity Shares and receipt of five Bid from Bidders, details of which \nare shown in the table below. The illustrative book given below shows the demand for the Equity \nShares of the Issuer at various prices and is collated from Bids received from various investors. Page 354 of 402 Applied Quantity \nBid Amount (₹) \nCumulative Quantity \nSubscription \n500 \n24 \n500 \n16.67% \n1,000 \n23 \n1,500 \n50.00% \n1,500 \n22 \n3,000 \n100.00% \n2,000 \n21 \n5,000 \n166.67% \n2,500 \n20 \n7,500 \n250.00% \n \nPrice discovery is a function of demand at various prices. The highest price at which the Issuer is able \nto Issue the desired number of Equity Shares is the price at which the book cuts off, i.e., ₹ 22.00 in the \nabove example. The Issuer in consultation with the BRLM, may finalize the Issue Price at or below such \nCut-Off Price, i.e., at or below ₹ 22.00. All Bids at or above this Issue Price and cut-off Bids are valid \nBids and are considered for allocation in the respective categories. \n \nFILING OF OFFER DOCUMENTS \n \nThe Draft Red Herring Prospectus was filed along with due diligence certificate as per Form A of \nschedule V to which the site visit report of the issuer prepare by the BRLMs is annexed including \nadditional confirmation as provided in form G of schedule V with NSE Emerge, the SME Platform of \nNational Stock Exchange of India Limited. \n \nThe Draft Red Herring Prospectus filed with SME Exchange was available for public comments, if any, \nfor a period of atleast 21 days from the date of filing by hosting it on the websites of our company at \nwww.shyamspices.co.in, \nSME \nExchange \nat \nwww.nseindia.com, \nand \nat \nBRLM \nwebsite \nwww.holaniconsultants.co.in  \n \nThe Draft Red Herring Prospectus will not be filed with SEBI, nor has SEBI issued any observation on \nthe Draft Red Herring Prospectus in terms of Regulation 246 (2) of SEBI (ICDR) Regulations. or \n(b) makes or abets making of multiple applications to a company in different names or in different combinations of his name or surname for acquiring or subscribing for its securities; or \n(c) otherwise induces directly or indirectly a company to allot, or register any transfer of, securities to him, or to any other person in a fictitious name, shall be liable for action under Section 447.” \n \nThe liability prescribed under Section 447 of the Companies Act, 2013, includes, for frauds involving \nan amount of at least ₹ 10,00,000/- or one per cent. of the turnover of the Company, whichever is \nlower, imprisonment for a term of not less than six (6) months extending up to ten (10) years (provided \nthat where the fraud involves public interest, such term shall not be less than three (3) years) and fine \nof an amount not less than the amount involved in the fraud, extending up to three times of such \namount. Where the fraud involves an amount less than ₹ 10,00,000/- (Rupees Ten lakhs only) or one \nper cent (1%) of the turnover of the Company, whichever is lower, and does not involve public interest, \nany person guilty of such fraud shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend \nto five (5) years or with fine which may extend to ₹ 50,00,000/- (Rupees Fifty lakhs only) or with both. \n \nUTILISATION OF ISSUE PROCEEDS \n \nThe Board certifies that: (i) all monies received out of the Fresh Issue shall be credited/transferred to a separate bank account other than the bank account referred to in sub-Section (3) of Section 40 of the Companies \nAct, 2013; \n(ii) details of all monies utilised out of the Fresh Issue shall be disclosed, and continue to be disclosed till the time any part of the Fresh Issue proceeds remains unutilised, under an appropriate head \nin the balance sheet of our Company indicating the purpose for which such monies have been \nutilised; and \n(iii) details of all unutilised monies out of the Fresh Issue, if any shall be disclosed under an appropriate separate head in the balance sheet indicating the form in which such unutilised \nmonies have been invested. \n \nBASIS OF ALLOCATION \n \n1. Page 358 of 402 RESTRICTIONS ON FOREIGN OWNERSHIP OF INDIAN SECURITIES \n \nForeign investment in Indian securities is regulated through the Industrial Policy, 1991, the FDI Policy, \nFEMA and the rules and regulations made thereunder. While the Industrial Policy, 1991 prescribes the \nlimits and the conditions subject to which foreign investment can be made in different sectors of the \nIndian economy, FEMA regulates the precise manner in which such investment may be made. Under \nthe Industrial Policy, 1991, unless specifically restricted, foreign investment is freely permitted in all \nsectors of Indian economy up to any extent and without any prior approvals, but the foreign investor \nis required to follow certain prescribed procedures for making such investment. The government \nbodies responsible for granting foreign investment approvals are the RBI and the Department for \nPromotion of Industry and Internal Trade, Ministry of Commerce and Industry, Government of India \n(“DPIIT”). \n \nThe Government has from time to time made policy pronouncements on FDI through press notes and \npress releases. DPIIT has issued a consolidated FDI Policy, which with effect from October 15, 2020, \nconsolidates and supersedes all previous press notes, press releases and clarifications on FDI issued \nby the DPIIT that were in force and effect as on October 15, 2020. The Government has also enacted \nForeign Exchange Management (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, 2019 and Foreign Exchange \nManagement (Debt Instruments) Regulations, 2019 in supersession of Foreign Exchange Management \n(Transfer or Issue of Security by a Person Resident Outside India) Regulations, 2017 and the Foreign \nExchange Management (Acquisition and Transfer of Immovable Property in India) Regulations, 2018. \nConsequent to the Foreign Exchange Management (Non-Debt Instrument) Rules, 2019, the Reserve \nBank has issued Foreign Exchange Management (Mode of Payment and Reporting of Non-Debt \nInstrument) Regulation, 2019 which governs the mode of payment and reporting requirements for \ninvestment in India by a person resident outside India. \n \nAs per the FDI Policy, FDI in such sector in which our Company operates, is permitted up to 100% of \nthe paid-up share capital of such company under the automatic route. In case of investment in sectors \nthrough Government Route, approval from competent authority as mentioned in Chapter 4 of the FDI \nPolicy 2020 has to be obtained by the Company. \n \nAs per the existing policy of the Government of India, OCBs cannot participate in this Issue and in \naccordance with the extant FDI guidelines on sectoral caps, pricing guidelines etc. as amended by \nReserve bank of India, from time to time. For further details, see the chapter titled “Issue Procedure” \nbeginning on page 333. \n \nInvestment by Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) \nForeign Portfolio Investors (“FPIs”) are permitted to subscribe to the Equity Shares of an Indian \nCompany in a public issue without the prior approval of the RBI, so long as the price of the Equity \nShares to be issued is not less than the price at which the Equity Shares are issued to residents. SEBI \nregistered FPIs have been permitted to purchase shares of an Indian company through issue, subject \nto total FPI investment being within the individual FPI investment limit of below 10% of the total paid-\nup equity capital of the Indian Company on a fully diluted basis, or less than 10% of the paid-up value \nof each series of debentures or preference shares or share warrants issued by an Indian company and \nthe total holdings of all FPIs put together, including any other direct and indirect foreign investments \nin the Indian company by the FPIs permitted under Foreign Exchange Management (Non-debt \nInstruments) Rules, 2019, shall not exceed 24% of the paid-up equity capital of the Indian company \non a fully diluted basis. However, this aggregate limit of 24% may be increased up to sectoral \ncap/statutory ceiling, as applicable, by the Indian company concerned by passing a resolution by its \nBoard of Directors followed by passing of a special resolution to that effect by its general body. \n \nWith effect from April 01, 2020, the aggregate limit shall be the sectoral caps applicable to the Indian \ncompany as laid out in sub-paragraph (b) of paragraph 3 of Schedule I of the Foreign Exchange \nManagement (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, 2019, with respect to its paid-up equity capital on a fully \ndiluted basis or such same sectoral cap percentage of paid-up value of each series of debentures or Page 359 of 402 preference shares or share warrants. The aggregate limit as provided above may be decreased by the \nIndian company concerned to a lower threshold limit of 24% or 49% or 74% as deemed fit, with the \napproval of its Board of Directors and its General Body through a resolution and a special resolution, \nrespectively before March 31, 2020. The Indian company which has decreased its aggregate limit to \n24% or 49% or 74%, may increase such aggregate limit to 49% or 74% or the sectoral cap or statutory \nceiling respectively as deemed fit, with the approval of its Board of Directors and its General Body \nthrough a resolution and a special resolution, respectively; however, once the aggregate limit has been \nincreased to a higher threshold, the Indian company cannot reduce the same to a lower threshold. \n \nSubscription by Non-Resident Indians (NRI) or Overseas Citizen of India (OCI) on Repatriation Basis \nAs per Schedule III of the Foreign Exchange Management (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, 2019, a NRI \nor OCI may purchase or sell shares of a listed Indian company on repatriation basis, on a recognised \nstock exchange in India, subject to the conditions that Non-Resident Indians (“NRIs”) or Overseas \nCitizen of India (“OCIs”) may purchase and sell shares through a branch designated by an authorised \ndealer for the purpose; and the total holding by any individual NRI or OCI shall not exceed 5% of the \ntotal paid-up equity capital on a fully diluted basis or should not exceed 5% of the paid-up value of \neach series of debentures or preference shares or share warrants issued by an Indian company and \nthe total holdings of all NRIs and OCIs put together shall not exceed 10% of the total paid-up equity \ncapital on a fully diluted basis or shall not exceed 10% of the paid-up value of each series of debentures \nor preference shares or share warrants. The aggregate ceiling of 10% may be raised to 24% if a special \nresolution to that effect is passed by the general body of the Indian company. \n \nInvestment by NRI or OCI on Non-Repatriation Basis \nAs per Schedule IV of the Foreign Exchange Management (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, \n2019,purchase by an NRI/ OCI, including a company, a trust and a partnership firm incorporated \noutside India and owned and controlled by NRIs/OCIs, on non-repatriation basis of shares and \nconvertible debentures or warrants issued by a company without any limit either on the stock \nexchange or outside, it will be deemed to be domestic investment at par with the investment made \nby residents. This is further subject to remittance channel restrictions. However, NRI/ OCI, including a \ncompany, a trust and a partnership firm incorporated outside India and owned and controlled by \nNRIs/OCIs, is prohibited from making any investment, under Schedule IV, in capital instruments or \nunits of a Nidhi company or a company engaged in agricultural/ plantation activities or real estate \nbusiness or construction of farmhouses or dealing in transfer of development rights. \n \nInvestment by other Non-Resident Investors  \nAs per Schedule I of the Foreign Exchange Management (Non-debt Instruments) Rules, 2019, a person \nresident outside India may purchase capital instruments of a listed Indian company on a stock \nexchange in India provided the person resident outside India making the investment has already \nacquired control of such company in accordance with SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and \nTakeover) Regulations, 2011 and continues to hold such control and the amount of consideration may \nbe paid as per the mode of payment as prescribed by RBI i.e. Regulation 3 of Foreign Exchange \nManagement (Mode of Payment and Reporting of Non-Debt Instrument) Regulation 2019 under or \nout of the dividend payable by Indian investee company in which the person resident outside India \nhas acquired and continues to hold the control in accordance with SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of \nShares and Takeover) Regulations, 2011 provided the right to receive dividend is established and the \ndividend amount has been credited to a specially designated non-interest bearing rupee account for \nacquisition of shares on the recognized stock exchange. \n \nInvestors are advised to refer to the exact text of the relevant statutory provisions of law before \ninvesting and / or subsequent purchase or sale transaction in the Equity Shares of Our Company. \n \nNo person shall make an application in the Issue, unless such person is eligible to acquire Equity Shares \nof our Company in accordance with applicable laws, rules, regulations, guidelines, and approvals. \n \nThe Equity Shares to be issued in the Issue have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. \nSecurities Act and may not be issued within U.S., LIEN The Company shall have a first and paramount lien upon all the \nshares/debentures (other than fully paid-up shares/debentures) registered in \nthe name of each member (whether solely or jointly with others) and upon the \nproceeds of sale thereof for all moneys (whether presently payable or not) \ncalled or payable at a fixed time in respect of such shares/debentures and no \nequitable interest in any share shall be created except upon the footing and \ncondition that this Article will have full effect. And such lien shall extend to all \ndividends and bonuses from time to time declared in respect of such \nshares/debentures. Unless otherwise agreed the registration of a transfer of \nshares/debentures shall operate as a waiver of the Company’s lien if any, on \nsuch shares/debentures. The Directors may at any time declare any \nshares/debentures wholly or in part to be exempt from the provisions of this \nclause. \nEvery fully paid share shall be free from all lien and that in the case of partly \npaid shares the Issuer’s lien shall be restricted to moneys called or payable at \na fixed time in respect of such shares. Company to have Lien on \nshares 48. CONVERSION OF SHARES INTO STOCK The Company may, by ordinary resolution in General Meeting, \na) convert any fully paid-up shares into stock; and \nb) re-convert any stock into fully paid-up shares of any denomination. Conversion of shares into \nstock or reconversion 101. The holders of stock may transfer the same or any part thereof in the same \nmanner as and subject to the same regulation under which the shares from \nwhich the stock arose might before the conversion have been transferred, or \nas near thereto as circumstances admit, provided that, the Board may, from \ntime to time, fix the minimum amount of stock transferable so however that \nsuch minimum shall not exceed the nominal amount of the shares from which \nthe stock arose. Transfer of stock 102. The holders of stock shall, according to the amount of stock held by them, have \nthe same rights, privileges and advantages as regards dividends, participation \nin profits, voting at meetings of the Company, and other matters, as if they \nhold the shares for which the stock arose but no such privilege or advantage \nshall be conferred by an amount of stock which would not, if existing in shares, \nhave conferred that privilege or advantage. Rights of stock Holders 103. Such of the regulations of the Company (other than those relating to share \nwarrants), as are applicable to paid up share shall apply to stock and the words \n“share” and “shareholders” in those regulations shall include “stock” and \n“stockholders” respectively. BORROWING POWERS Subject to the provisions of the Act and these Articles, the Board may, from \ntime to time at its discretion, by a resolution passed at a meeting of the Board \ngenerally raise or borrow money by way of deposits, loans, overdrafts, cash \ncredit or by issue of bonds, debentures or debenture-stock (perpetual or \notherwise) or in any other manner, or from any person, firm, company, co-\noperative society, anybody corporate, bank, institution, whether incorporated \nin India or abroad, Government or any authority or any other body for the \npurpose of the Company and may secure the payment of any sums of money \nso received, raised or borrowed; provided that the total amount borrowed by \nthe Company (apart from temporary loans obtained from the Company’s \nBankers in the ordinary course of business) shall not without the consent of \nthe Company in General Meeting exceed the aggregate of the paid up capital \nof the Company and its free reserves that is to say reserves not set apart for \nany specified purpose. POWERS OF THE BOARD The business of the Company shall be managed by the Board who may exercise \nall such powers of the Company and do all such acts and things as may be \nnecessary, unless otherwise restricted by the Act, or by any other law or by \nthe Memorandum or by the Articles required to be exercised by the Company \nin General Meeting. However, no regulation made by the Company in General \nMeeting shall invalidate any prior act of the Board which would have been \nvalid if that regulation had not been made. 168. Powers of the Board Without prejudice to the general powers conferred by the Articles and so as \nnot in any way to limit or restrict these powers, and without prejudice to the \nother powers conferred by these Articles, but subject to the restrictions \ncontained in the Articles, it is hereby, declared that the Directors shall have \nthe following powers, that is to say 169. (1)  Subject to the provisions of the Act, to purchase or otherwise acquire any \nlands, buildings, machinery, premises, property, effects, assets, rights, \ncreditors, royalties, business and goodwill of any person firm or company \ncarrying on the business which this Company is authorised to carry on, in any \npart of India. Certain powers of the \nBoard (2)  Subject to the provisions of the Act to purchase, take on lease for any term \nor terms of years, or otherwise acquire any land or lands, with or without \nbuildings and out-houses thereon, situate in any part of India, at such \nconditions as the Directors may think fit, and in any such purchase, lease or \nacquisition to accept such title as the Directors may believe, or may be advised \nto be reasonably satisfy. (3)  To erect and construct, on the said land or lands, buildings, houses, \nwarehouses and sheds and to alter, extend and improve the same, to let or \nlease the property of the company, in part or in whole for such rent and subject \nto such conditions, as may be thought advisable; to sell such portions of the \nland or buildings of the Company as may not be required for the company; to Page 383 of 402 Sr. No \nParticulars \nmortgage the whole or any portion of the property of the company for the \npurposes of the Company; to sell all or any portion of the machinery or stores \nbelonging to the Company. (4)  At their discretion and subject to the provisions of the Act, the Directors \nmay pay property rights or privileges acquired by, or services rendered to the \nCompany, either wholly or partially in cash or in shares, bonds, debentures or \nother securities of the Company, and any such share may be issued either as \nfully paid up or with such amount credited as paid up thereon as may be \nagreed upon; and any such bonds, debentures or other securities may be \neither specifically charged upon all or any part of the property of the Company \nand its uncalled capital or not so charged. (5)  To insure and keep insured against loss or damage by fire or otherwise for \nsuch period and to such extent as they may think proper all or any part of the \nbuildings, machinery, goods, stores, produce and other moveable property of \nthe Company either separately or co-jointly; also to insure all or any portion of \nthe goods, produce, machinery and other articles imported or exported by the \nCompany and to sell, assign, surrender or discontinue any policies of assurance \neffected in pursuance of this power. (6)  To open accounts with any Bank or Bankers and to pay money into and \ndraw money from any such account from time to time as the Directors may \nthink fit. (7)  To secure the fulfilment of any contracts or engagement entered into by \nthe Company by mortgage or charge on all or any of the property of the \nCompany including its whole or part of its undertaking as a going concern and \nits uncalled capital for the time being or in such manner as they think fit. (8)  To accept from any member, so far as may be permissible by law, a \nsurrender of the shares or any part thereof, on such terms and conditions as \nshall be agreed upon. (9)  To appoint any person to accept and hold in trust, for the Company \nproperty belonging to the Company, or in which it is interested or for any other \npurposes and to execute and to do all such deeds and things as may be \nrequired in relation to any such trust, and to provide for the remuneration of \nsuch trustee or trustees. (10)  To institute, conduct, defend, compound or abandon any legal \nproceeding by or against the Company or its Officer, or otherwise concerning \nthe affairs and also to compound and allow time for payment or satisfaction \nof any debts, due, and of any claims or demands by or against the Company \nand to refer any difference to arbitration, either according to Indian or Foreign \nlaw and either in India or abroad and observe and perform or challenge any \naward thereon. (11)  To act on behalf of the Company in all matters relating to bankruptcy \ninsolvency. (12) To make and give receipts, release and give discharge for moneys payable \nto the Company and for the claims and demands of the Company. (13)  Subject to the provisions of the Act, and these Articles to invest and deal \nwith any moneys of the Company not immediately required for the purpose \nthereof, upon such authority (not being the shares of this Company) or without \nsecurity and in such manner as they may think fit and from time to time to vary \nor realise such investments. Save as provided in Section 187 of the Act, all \ninvestments shall be made and held in the Company’s own name. (14) To execute in the name and on behalf of the Company in favor of any \nDirector or other person who may incur or be about to incur any personal \nliability whether as principal or as surety, for the benefit of the Company, such \nmortgage of the Company’s property (present or future) as they think fit, and \nany such mortgage may contain a power of sale and other powers, provisions, \ncovenants and agreements as shall be agreed upon. (15)  To determine from time to time persons who shall be entitled to sign on \nCompany’s behalf, bills, notes, receipts, acceptances, endorsements, cheques, \ndividend warrants, releases, contracts and documents and to give the Page 384 of 402 Sr. No \nParticulars \nnecessary authority for such purpose, whether by way of a resolution of the \nBoard or by way of a power of attorney or otherwise. (16)  To give to any Director, Officer, or other persons employed by the \nCompany, a commission on the profits of any particular business or \ntransaction, or a share in the general profits of the company; and such \ncommission or share of profits shall be treated as part of the working expenses \nof the Company. (17) To give, award or allow any bonus, pension, gratuity or compensation to \nany employee of the Company, or his widow, children, dependents, that may \nappear just or proper, whether such employee, his widow, children or \ndependents have or have not a legal claim on the Company. DIVIDEND AND RESERVES (1)  \nSubject to the rights of persons, if any, entitled to shares with special \nrights as to dividends, all dividends shall be declared and paid according to the \namounts paid or credited as paid on the shares in respect whereof the \ndividend is paid, but if and so long as nothing is paid upon any of the shares in \nthe Company, dividends may be declared and paid according to the amounts \nof the shares. \n(2)  \nNo amount paid or credited as paid on a share in advance of calls shall \nbe treated for the purposes of this regulation as paid on the share. \n(3)  \nAll dividends shall be apportioned and paid proportionately to the \namounts paid or credited as paid on the shares during any portion or portions \nof the period in respect of which the dividend is paid; but if any share is issued \non terms providing that it shall rank for dividend as from a particular date such \nshare shall rank for dividend accordingly.
